origins: Spanish, ‘coin, money’.

origins: late 18th century: from Italian, from Latin intermedium ‘interval’, neuter of intermedius (see intermediate).

origins: Middle English: from Old French hermine, probably from medieval Latin (mus) Armenius ‘Armenian (mouse)’.

origins: early 18th century: from French, from Spanish caramelo .

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin forensis ‘in open court, public’, from forum (see forum).

origins: late Middle English (in the general sense ‘weak, frail’): from Latin infirmus, from in- ‘not’ + firmus ‘firm’.

origins: late Middle English: from archaic hove  ‘hover, linger’, of unknown origin.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late 19th century: from Latin, from velare ‘to cover’.

origins: Middle English: from Old French mangonel(le ), from medieval Latin manganellus, diminutive of late Latin manganum, from Greek manganon ‘axis, engine of war’.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘difficult to get through’): from cumber + -some1.

origins: late Middle English: from French, via late Latin from Greek hēmikrania, from hēmi- ‘half’ + kranion ‘skull’.

origins: late 16th century: from Old French aloi (noun) and French aloyer (verb), both from Old French aloier, aleier ‘combine’, from Latin alligare ‘bind’. In early use the term denoted the comparative purity of gold or silver; the sense ‘mixture of metals’ arose in the mid 17th century;Etymology Unknown
meaning: mix (metals) to make an alloy;a metal made by combining two or more metallic elements, especially to give greater strength or resistance to corrosion

origins: late Middle English: alteration of the obsolete adjective distract (from Latin distractus ‘pulled apart’), influenced by straught, archaic past participle of stretch.

origins: early 16th century: from Old French linette, from lin ‘flax’ (because the bird feeds on flaxseeds).

origins: mid 17th century: shortening of university, reflecting an archaic pronunciation.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the removal of contaminants from something

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: mid 16th century: via Latin from Greek obeliskos, diminutive of obelos ‘pointed pillar’.

origins: late 19th century: of unknown origin.

origins: mid 17th century: from late Latin indolent-, from in- ‘not’ + dolere ‘suffer or give pain’. The sense ‘idle’ arose in the early 18th century.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘pleasing’): from Old French plaisant ‘pleasing’, from the verb plaisir (see please).

origins: 1930s: a local word in Ghana.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: mid 16th century: from French, from accoutrer ‘clothe, equip’ (see accoutre).

origins: Middle English: from Latin ascribere, from ad- ‘to’ + scribere ‘write’.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin expungere ‘mark for deletion by means of points’, from ex- ‘out’ + pungere ‘to prick’.

origins: mid 18th century. Probably an alteration of revindicate, after French revendiquer to reclaim, claim back as a rightful possession

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English (originally in the sense ‘bathe’): perhaps related to Old Norse batha ‘bathe’.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin dirigere ‘to direct’ + -ible.

origins: late 19th century: French, literally ‘buckled, curled’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: mid 18th century: from French, from sous ‘under’ + terre ‘earth’.

origins: early 17th century: from French, from finance (see finance).

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin recipient- ‘receiving’, from the verb recipere .

origins: late 15th century: from Latin accumulat- ‘heaped up’, from the verb accumulare, from ad- ‘to’ + cumulus ‘a heap’.

origins: Unknown

origins: Italian.

origins: mid 17th century (also in the general sense ‘delay’): from Old French demourage, from the verb demourer (see demur).

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: used to end a conversation, to change the subject, or to resume a subject after interruption;used to confirm or support a point or idea just mentioned;used to indicate that something happened or will happen in spite of something else

origins: late 19th century: from German der Karst, the name of a limestone region in Slovenia.

origins: late 19th century: French, literally ‘work’.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘projecting’): from Latin prominent- ‘jutting out’, from the verb prominere . Compare with eminent.

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin coadjutor, from co- (from Latin cum ‘together with’) + adjutor ‘assistant’ (from adjuvare ‘to help’).

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Old English hnǣgan (verb), of imitative origin; compare with Dutch dialect neijen .

origins: modern Greek, from Latin taberna (see tavern).

origins: mid 19th century: French, from mode ‘fashion’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin oraculum, from orare ‘speak’.

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin horizon, from Greek horizōn (kuklos) ‘limiting (circle)’.

origins: Middle English (denoting a regulation requiring people to extinguish fires at a fixed hour in the evening, or a bell rung at that hour): from Old French cuevrefeu, from cuvrir ‘to cover’ + feu ‘fire’. The current sense dates from the late 19th century.

origins: Middle English headling  (from head + the adverbial suffix -ling ), altered in late Middle English by association with -long.

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin demulcent- ‘stroking caressingly’, from the verb demulcere, from de- ‘away’ + mulcere ‘soothe’.

meaning: inclination or prejudice for or against one person or group, especially in a way considered to be unfair.;a direction diagonal to the weave of a fabric.;(in bowls) the irregular shape given to one side of a bowl.;a steady voltage, magnetic field, or other factor applied to a system or device to cause it to operate over a predetermined range.

origins: early 18th century: probably symbolic; compare with jag1 and cram.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin indigent- ‘lacking’, from the verb indigere, from indi- (strengthened form of in- ‘into’) + egere ‘to need’.

origins: late 17th century: from French imperméable, or from late Latin impermeabilis, from in- ‘not’ + permeabilis (see permeable).

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘obtain unlawfully, seize’; formerly also as incroach ): from Old French encrochier ‘seize, fasten upon’, from en- ‘in, on’ + crochier (from croc ‘hook’, from Old Norse krókr ).

meaning: roentgen(s).;an unspecified alkyl or other organic radical or group.;rook (in recording moves in chess);the gas constant.;the eighteenth letter of the alphabet.;restricted, a rating in the Voluntary Movie Rating System that children under 17 require an accompanying parent or adult guardian for admission.;(in the US) Republican;River (chiefly on maps);Regina or Rex;a figure expressing the rate at which an infectious disease spreads, taken as the average number of cases arising by transmission from a single infected individual;radius;(on a gearshift) reverse.;Réaumur;rule;registered as a trademark.;(giving position or direction) right;recto.;correlation coefficient;electrical resistance.;rand

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘maintenance, support’; hence exhibition (sense 4), mid 17th century): via Old French from late Latin exhibitio(n- ), from Latin exhibere ‘hold out’ (see exhibit).
meaning: a public display of works of art or items of interest, held in an art gallery or museum or at a trade fair.;a display or demonstration of a skill.;(in sport) a game whose outcome does not affect a team's standing, typically one played before the start of a regular season.;a scholarship awarded to a student at a school or university, usually after a competitive examination.

origins: early 20th century: the name of a musician in George du Maurier's novel Trilby (1894), who controls Trilby's stage singing hypnotically.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin respectus, from the verb respicere ‘look back at, regard’, from re- ‘back’ + specere ‘look at’.

meaning: activity requiring physical effort, carried out to sustain or improve health and fitness.;an activity carried out for a specific purpose.;the use or application of a faculty, right, or process.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: mid 17th century: from French feston, from Italian festone ‘festal ornament’, from festum, (plural) festa ‘feast’.

origins: Unknown

origins: late 16th century: from French, literally ‘being born’, present participle of naître, from Latin nasci ‘be born’.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin visus ‘sight’, from videre ‘to see’.

origins: mid 19th century: from Latin cetus ‘whale’ (see Cetacea) + -logy.

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘royal powers’): from medieval Latin, literally ‘royal privileges’, from Latin, neuter plural of regalis ‘regal’.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French patricien, from Latin patricius ‘having a noble father’, from pater, patr- ‘father’.

origins: early 18th century: from Chinese (Mandarin dialect) bĕnjī literally ‘own loom’ or běnzhī literally ‘home-woven’.

origins: Middle English: via Anglo-Norman French from Old French cortoyer ‘be present at court’, from cort (see court).

origins: from Hindi darī .

origins: late Old English frāward  ‘leading away from, away’, based on Old Norse frá (see fro, from).

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin dispositio(n- ), from disponere ‘arrange’ (see dispose).

origins: Middle English: from Old French noriss-, lengthened stem of norir, from Latin nutrire ‘feed, cherish’.

meaning: In Polynesia, especially Hawaii: a chant with a unique vocal melody, composed and performed by a professional chanter, often to commemorate a significant cultural event or to praise a leader.

origins: mid 17th century: perhaps from German wedeln ‘cringe, fawn’, from Wedel ‘tail, fan’.

origins: early 16th century: from French poltron, from Italian poltrone, perhaps from poltro ‘sluggard’.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French nappe ‘tablecloth’ (from Latin mappa : see map) + -kin.

origins: late Middle English (in predicament (sense 2)): from late Latin praedicamentum ‘something predicated’ (rendering Greek katēgoria ‘category’), from Latin praedicare (see predicate). From the sense ‘category’ arose the sense ‘state of being, condition’; hence ‘unpleasant situation’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English: from French catalepsie or late Latin catalepsia, from Greek katalēpsis, from katalambanein ‘seize upon’.
meaning: a medical condition characterized by a trance or seizure with a loss of sensation and consciousness accompanied by rigidity of the body.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from hermite (see hermit).
meaning: the dwelling of a hermit, especially when small and remote.;a major art museum in St Petersburg, Russia, containing among its collections those begun by Catherine the Great.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a measure of electrical power expressed in watts.

origins: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Robert Mayne (1808–1868). From scientific Latin rupicola, specific use of feminine of post-classical Latin rupicolus + -ous
meaning: Of a plant or animal: growing or living on rocks; = rupicoline.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a machine, system, or technique) developed to a high degree of complexity;having, revealing, or proceeding from a great deal of worldly experience and knowledge of fashion and culture

origins: late 18th century: from French, ‘shade, subtlety’, from nuer ‘to shade’, based on Latin nubes ‘cloud’.
meaning: a subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.

origins: early 17th century: from late Latin mephiticus, from mephitis ‘noxious exhalation’.
meaning: (especially of a gas or vapour) foul-smelling; noxious.

origins: late 16th century: from French épithète, or via Latin from Greek epitheton, neuter of epithetos ‘attributed’, from epitithenai ‘add’, from epi ‘upon’ + tithenai ‘to place’.
meaning: an adjective or phrase expressing a quality or attribute regarded as characteristic of the person or thing mentioned.

origins: early 17th century: shortened from Latin plaudite ‘applaud!’ (said by Roman actors at the end of a play), imperative plural of plaudere .
meaning: an expression of praise or approval.

origins: early 17th century (denoting a kind of carbine or musket, thought of as breathing fire): from French dragon ‘dragon’.
meaning: a member of any of several cavalry regiments in the British army.

origins: late 16th century: from Spanish and Portuguese, diminutive of mosca, from Latin musca ‘fly’.
meaning: a slender long-legged fly with aquatic larvae. The bite of the bloodsucking female can transmit a number of serious diseases including malaria and elephantiasis.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an industrial port city in southwestern Washington, on the Columbia River, north of Portland in Oregon; population 163,186 (est. 2008).;a city and port in British Columbia, in southwestern Canada, on the mainland opposite Vancouver Island; population 578,041 (2006). It is the largest city and chief port in western Canada.

origins: Italian, literally ‘a member of a council’.
meaning: a member of a Mafia family who serves as an adviser to the leader and resolves disputes within the family.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a window or doorframe or similar structure) fitted with panes of glass;(of food, fabric, etc.) overlaid or covered with a smooth, shiny coating or finish;(of a person's eyes or expression) showing no interest or animation

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: constructed, arranged, or marked like a net or network

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who performs tricks that deceive the eye; a magician

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a way that is contrary to or forbidden by law, rules, or custom

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin collisio(n- ), from Latin collidere ‘strike together’ (see collide).
meaning: an instance of one moving object or person striking violently against another.;an instance of two or more records being assigned the same identifier or location in memory.

origins: late Middle English (as a verb): from Old French sursis, past participle of Old French surseoir ‘refrain, delay’, from Latin supersedere (see supersede). The change in the ending was due to association with cease; the noun dates from the late 16th century.
meaning: ending; cessation.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin in gratiam ‘into favour’, on the pattern of obsolete Italian ingratiare, earlier form of ingraziare .
meaning: bring oneself into favour with someone by flattering or trying to please them.

origins: late 18th century: from French funambule or Latin funambulus (from funis ‘rope’ + ambulare ‘to walk’) + -ist.
meaning: a tightrope walker.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a nastic movement, such as the closing of petals, that occurs in response to the alternation of day and night

origins: late 16th century: from French bataillon, from Italian battaglione, from battaglia ‘battle’, from Latin (see battle).
meaning: a large body of troops ready for battle, especially an infantry unit forming part of a brigade.

origins: Unknown
meaning: of a plant or plant partá

origins: late 16th century: from Latin speculat- ‘observed from a vantage point’, from the verb speculari, from specula ‘watchtower’, from specere ‘to look’.
meaning: form a theory or conjecture about a subject without firm evidence.;invest in stocks, property, or other ventures in the hope of gain but with the risk of loss.

origins: 1920s: from duo-, on the pattern of monopoly .
meaning: a situation in which two suppliers dominate the market for a commodity or service.

origins: early 17th century: from Italian, from Latin Volcanus ‘Vulcan’.
meaning: a mountain or hill, typically conical, having a crater or vent through which lava, rock fragments, hot vapour, and gas are or have been erupted from the earth's crust.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin multifarius + -ous.
meaning: many and of various types.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a substance that pollutes something, especially water or the atmosphere

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action of expelling someone, especially a tenant, from a property; expulsion

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin ineffabilis, from in- ‘not’ + effabilis (see effable).
meaning: too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: not noticed

origins: late Middle English: from medieval Latin disconsolatus, from dis- (expressing reversal) + Latin consolatus (past participle of consolari ‘to console’).
meaning: very unhappy and unable to be comforted.

origins: late 17th century (as a noun in the dialect sense ‘noise, chatter’): of Anglo-Irish origin; probably related to Irish bodhaire ‘noise’, bodhraim ‘deafen, annoy’. The verb (originally dialect) meant ‘confuse with noise’ in the early 18th century.
meaning: take the trouble to do something.;(of a circumstance or event) worry, disturb, or upset (someone).

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘inconstant, fluctuating’): from French, or from Latin versatilis, from versat- ‘turned about, revolved’, from the verb versare, frequentative of vertere ‘to turn’.
meaning: able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities.;changeable; inconstant.

origins: from French bénédictine or modern Latin benedictinus, from the name Benedictus (see Benedict, St).
meaning: a monk or nun of a Christian religious order following the rule of St Benedict and established c. 540.;a liqueur based on brandy, originally made by Benedictine monks in France.

origins: Middle English (as an adjective following a family name): from Latin, comparative of juvenis ‘young’.
meaning: for or denoting young or younger people.;low or lower in rank or status.

origins: mid 19th century; earliest use found in John Ludlow (1821–1911), lawyer and social activist. From pluto- + -nomy, after economy
meaning: The science of the production and distribution of wealth.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, based on Latin dis- (expressing negation) + the Germanic base of may1.
meaning: cause (someone) to feel concern and distress.

origins: early 17th century: probably from goose + -ander as in dialect bergander ‘shelduck’ (the colouring of the male goosander resembling that of the shelduck).
meaning: a large Eurasian and North American merganser (diving duck), the male of which has a dark green head and whitish underside.

origins: early 19th century: from French, from restaurer ‘provide food for’ (literally ‘restore to a former state’).
meaning: a place where people pay to sit and eat meals that are cooked and served on the premises.

origins: early 20th century: from Greek khalkos ‘copper’ + lithos ‘stone’ + -ic.
meaning: relating to or denoting a period in the 4th and 3rd millennia BC, chiefly in the Near East and south-eastern Europe, during which some weapons and tools were made of copper. This period was still largely Neolithic in character.

origins: mid 19th century: abbreviation of curiosity.
meaning: a rare, unusual, or intriguing object.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a bluish to greenish gem mineral sometimes confused with or substituted for turquoise

origins: late 16th century: from Latin illativus, from illat- ‘brought in’ (see illation).
meaning: of the nature of or stating an inference.;relating to or denoting a case of nouns in some languages used to express motion into something.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a country in northern North America, the second largest country in the world; population 35,900,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Ottawa; official languages, English and French.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: occurring, existing, or operating at the same time; concurrent

origins: late 19th century: blend of happen and circumstance.
meaning: coincidence.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a large, heavy shoe;a foolish, awkward, or clumsy person

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin abominabilis, from abominari (see abominate). The term was once widely believed to be from ab- ‘away from’ + Latin homine (from homo ‘human being’), thus ‘inhuman, beastly’, and frequently spelled abhominable until the 17th century.
meaning: causing moral revulsion.

origins: early 17th century: from modern Latin trigonometria (see trigon, -metry).
meaning: the branch of mathematics dealing with the relations of the sides and angles of triangles and with the relevant functions of any angles.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French equinoxe or Latin aequinoctium, from aequi- ‘equal’ + nox, noct- ‘night’.
meaning: the time or date (twice each year) at which the sun crosses the celestial equator, when day and night are of approximately equal length (about 22 September and 20 March).

origins: via Latin American Spanish, from Nahuatl tzictli .
meaning: the milky latex of the sapodilla tree, formerly chewed by the Aztecs and now used to make chewing gum.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘not migratory’): from French sédentaire or Latin sedentarius, from sedere ‘sit’.
meaning: (of a person) tending to spend much time seated; somewhat inactive.

origins: late Middle English: via French from Old French verd ‘green’, from Latin viridis .
meaning: lush green vegetation.

origins: early 16th century: from French implorer or Latin implorare ‘invoke with tears’.
meaning: beg someone earnestly or desperately to do something.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a state in the northwestern US, on the coast of the Pacific Ocean; population 3,790,060 (est. 2008); capital, Salem. Britain ceded the territory to the US in 1846 and it became the 33rd state in 1859.

origins: Old English rīce  ‘powerful, wealthy’, of Germanic origin, related to Dutch rijk and German reich ; ultimately from Celtic; reinforced in Middle English by Old French riche ‘rich, powerful’.
meaning: having a great deal of money or assets; wealthy.;existing in plentiful quantities; abundant.;producing a large quantity of something.;(of a colour, sound, smell, etc.) pleasantly deep or strong.;interesting because full of variety.;(of a remark) causing ironic amusement or indignation.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: just; only

origins: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French proffrir, from Latin pro- ‘before’ + offerre ‘to offer’.
meaning: hold out or put forward (something) to someone for acceptance.

origins: from Indonesian tempe .
meaning: an Indonesian dish made by deep-frying fermented soya beans.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a tub, usually installed in a bathroom, in which to bathe.

origins: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin aqueus, from Latin aqua ‘water’.
meaning: of or containing water.

origins: mid 16th century: from Old French, pet form of the given name Robert .
meaning: a small Old World thrush related to the chats, typically having a brown back with red on the breast or other colourful markings.;any of a number of birds that resemble the European robin, especially in having a red breast.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the status of a fellow of a college or society;friendly association, especially with people who share one's interests

origins: late Middle English: via medieval Latin from Arabic rahj al-ġār ‘arsenic’, literally ‘dust of the cave’.
meaning: a soft reddish mineral consisting of arsenic sulphide, formerly used as a pigment and in fireworks.

origins: late Middle English: of Scandinavian origin.
meaning: take or move (someone or something) somewhere suddenly and quickly.;beat or stir (a substance, especially cream or eggs) with a light, rapid movement.

origins: mid 18th century: probably via Portuguese from Hindi.
meaning: a large coloured handkerchief, typically with white spots, worn tied around the head or neck.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French artillerie, from artiller, alteration of atillier ‘equip, arm’, probably a variant of atirier, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + tire ‘rank, order’.
meaning: large-calibre guns used in warfare on land.

origins: late 18th century: from French épaulette, diminutive of épaule ‘shoulder’, from Latin spatula in the late Latin sense ‘shoulder blade’.
meaning: an ornamental shoulder piece on an item of clothing, especially on the coat or jacket of a military uniform.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: of, typical of, or peculiar to the tropics;of or involving a trope; figurative.

origins: early 19th century: from Latin lacus ‘lake’ (the stem lacustr- influenced by Latin palustris ‘marshy’) + -ine1.
meaning: relating to or associated with lakes.

origins: Old English hwæl, of Germanic origin.
meaning: a very large marine mammal with a streamlined hairless body, a horizontal tail fin, and a blowhole on top of the head for breathing.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: mark with a herringbone pattern;a method of ascending a slope by walking forward in alternate steps with each ski angled outward.;ascend a slope using the herringbone technique;an arrangement or design consisting of columns of short parallel lines, with all the lines in one column sloping one way and all the lines in the next column sloping the other way so as to resemble the bones in a fish, used especially in the weave of cloth or the placing of bricks

origins: late Middle English (denoting a doorkeeper): from Anglo-Norman French usser, from medieval Latin ustiarius, from Latin ostiarius, from ostium ‘door’.
meaning: a person who shows people to their seats, especially in a cinema or theatre or at a wedding.;an assistant teacher.

origins: early 18th century (denoting a sideboard): from French, from Old French bufet ‘stool’, of unknown origin.
meaning: a meal consisting of several dishes from which guests serve themselves.;a room or counter in a station, hotel, or other public building selling light meals or snacks.;a cabinet with shelves and drawers for keeping dinnerware and table linens; a sideboard.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin scrutinium, from scrutari ‘to search’ (originally ‘sort rubbish’, from scruta ‘rubbish’). Early use referred to the taking of individual votes in an election procedure.
meaning: critical observation or examination.

origins: early 16th century: from bounty + -ful.
meaning: large in quantity; abundant.

origins: mid 19th century: from French, from Les Baux (the name of a village near Arles in SE France, near which it was first found) + -ite1.
meaning: an amorphous clayey rock that is the chief commercial ore of aluminium. It consists largely of hydrated alumina with variable proportions of iron oxides.

origins: 1920s (originally US): of unknown origin.
meaning: nonsense.

origins: Middle English: from Old French rai, based on Latin radius ‘spoke, ray’. The verb dates from the late 16th century.
meaning: each of the lines in which light (and heat) may seem to stream from the sun or any luminous body, or pass through a small opening.;any of a set of straight lines passing through one point.;a thing that is arranged radially.

origins: Old English hrōst, related to Dutch roest ; of unknown ultimate origin.
meaning: (of a bird or bat) settle or congregate for rest or sleep.

origins: mid 17th century (originally in the sense ‘making a joyful noise’): from Latin jubilant- ‘calling, hallooing’, from the verb jubilare (see jubilate).
meaning: feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph.

origins: Middle English: probably of Dutch or Low German origin and related to Dutch hobbelen ‘rock from side to side’. hobble (sense 2 of the verb) is a variant of hopple.
meaning: walk in an awkward way, typically because of pain from an injury.;tie or strap together (the legs of a horse or other animal) to prevent it from straying.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: bitter hostility; rancor;the severity or harmfulness of a disease or poison

origins: late Middle English: from French ignominieux, or Latin ignominiosus, from ignominia (see ignominy).
meaning: deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French complainte, feminine past participle of complaindre ‘to lament’ (see complain).
meaning: a statement that something is unsatisfactory or unacceptable.;an illness or medical condition, especially a relatively minor one.

origins: late 16th century (describing a pig or pork infected with measles): from measles + -y1. The current sense dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: ridiculously small or few.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin varicosus, from varix (see varix).
meaning: (of a vein, especially in the leg) swollen, twisted, and lengthened, as a result of poor circulation.

origins: late 19th century: from Greek koinē (dialektos) ‘common (language)’.
meaning: the common language of the Greeks from the close of the classical period to the Byzantine era.

origins: 1960s: from baro- + Greek iatros ‘physician’ + -ics.
meaning: the branch of medicine that deals with the study and treatment of obesity.

origins: late Middle English: apparently from a variant of paragraph, remodelled after the more familiar words pill1 and crow1.
meaning: a symbol (¶) used to mark a new paragraph or section of text.

origins: mid 19th century: from Maori, imitative of its cry.
meaning: a large flightless New Zealand rail with heavily built legs and feet.

origins: mid 16th century: from Old French saciete, from Latin satietas, from satis ‘enough’.
meaning: the feeling or state of being sated.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a machine or device which automatically regulates the humidity of the air in a room or building.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who attends a conference or other gathering

origins: Middle English: from Old French losenge, probably derived from the base of Spanish losa, Portuguese lousa ‘slab’, late Latin lausiae (lapides ) ‘stone slabs’.
meaning: a rhombus or diamond shape.

origins: Middle English: of obscure origin.
meaning: each of a pair of organs in the abdominal cavity of mammals, birds, and reptiles, that excrete urine.;nature or temperament.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French abandoner, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + bandon ‘control’ (related to ban1). The original sense was ‘bring under control’, later ‘give in to the control of, surrender to’ (abandon (sense 3 of the verb)).
meaning: cease to support or look after (someone); desert.;give up completely (a practice or a course of action).;allow oneself to indulge in (a desire or impulse).

origins: Middle English endite, indite, from Anglo-Norman French enditer, based on Latin indicere ‘proclaim, appoint’, from in- ‘towards’ + dicere ‘pronounce, utter’.
meaning: formally accuse of or charge with a crime.

origins: Unknown
meaning: having the shape of a small star;radiating like a star

origins: late 19th century: from Grand Panjandrum, an invented phrase in a nonsense verse (1755) by S. Foote.
meaning: a person who has or claims to have a great deal of authority or influence.

origins: mid 18th century: from French, of unknown origin.
meaning: (of a bullet or other projectile) rebound off a surface.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: sharpness and directness in speech

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a formal or literary word for ignorance

origins: early 17th century: French, ‘running’, present participle of courir .
meaning: represented as running.

origins: mid 19th century: from attributive use of Chinook.
meaning: a warm dry wind which blows down the east side of the Rocky Mountains at the end of winter.;a large North Pacific salmon that is an important commercial food fish.

origins: mid 17th century (originally as failer, in the senses ‘non-occurrence’ and ‘cessation of supply’): from Anglo-Norman French failer for Old French faillir (see fail).
meaning: lack of success.;the neglect or omission of expected or required action.;the action or state of not functioning.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a loose outer garment resembling a coat and extending to the knee and worn in Japan

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin perceptibilis, from Latin percipere ‘seize, understand’ (see perceive).
meaning: (especially of a slight movement or change of state) able to be seen or noticed.

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘well-balanced state of mind’): from Latin aequilibrium, from aequi- ‘equal’ + libra ‘balance’.
meaning: a state in which opposing forces or influences are balanced.

origins: 1930s: from modern Latin Brucella + -osis: named after Sir David Bruce (1855–1931), the Scottish physician who identified the bacterium.
meaning: a bacterial disease typically affecting cattle and causing undulant fever in humans.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin formatio(n- ), from formare ‘to form’ (see form).
meaning: the action of forming or process of being formed.;a thing that has been formed.

origins: late 16th century: from Italian violino, diminutive of viola (see viola1).
meaning: a stringed musical instrument of treble pitch, played with a horsehair bow. The classical European violin was developed in the 16th century. It has four strings and a body of characteristic rounded shape, narrowed at the middle and with two f-shaped soundholes.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: modern or up to date;(prenominal) facetious or derogatory

word: having recently become the thing specified

origins: Middle English (denoting a small flat bread roll): of Scandinavian origin; related to Swedish kaka and Danish kage .
meaning: an item of soft sweet food made from a mixture of flour, fat, eggs, sugar, and other ingredients, baked and sometimes iced or decorated.;an item of savoury food formed into a flat round shape, and typically baked or fried.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, from ecclesiastical Latin parochialis ‘relating to an ecclesiastical district’, from parochia (see parish).
meaning: relating to a Church parish.;having a limited or narrow outlook or scope.

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French scaloun, based on Latin Ascalonia (caepa ) ‘(onion) of Ascalon’, a port in ancient Palestine.
meaning: a long-necked onion with a small bulb, in particular a spring onion.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, ‘whirling’, from vertere ‘to turn’.
meaning: a sensation of whirling and loss of balance, associated particularly with looking down from a great height, or caused by disease affecting the inner ear or the vestibular nerve; giddiness.

origins: Unknown
meaning: very superior in air or in attitude

origins: mid 16th century: from Portuguese índigo, via Latin from Greek indikon, from indikos ‘Indian (dye)’ (see Indic).
meaning: a tropical plant of the pea family, which was formerly widely cultivated as a source of dark blue dye.;the dark blue dye obtained from the indigo plant.

origins: late 18th century: Japanese.
meaning: a Japanese zither about six feet long, with thirteen strings passed over small movable bridges.

origins: mid 18th century: from Dutch wenteltrap, literally ‘winding stair’.
meaning: a marine mollusc which has a tall spiral shell with many whorls that are ringed with oblique ridges.

origins: mid 19th century: from tri- ‘three’ + Greek skelos ‘leg’.
meaning: a Celtic symbol consisting of three legs or lines radiating from a centre.

origins: mid 16th century (denoting a tidal inlet of any size): from Latin aestuarium ‘tidal part of a shore’, from aestus ‘tide’.
meaning: the tidal mouth of a large river, where the tide meets the stream.

origins: mid 17th century: from French céleri, from Italian dialect selleri, based on Greek selinon ‘parsley’.
meaning: a cultivated plant of the parsley family, with closely packed succulent leaf stalks which are used as a salad or cooked vegetable.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin vacatio(n- ), from vacare ‘be unoccupied’ (see vacate).
meaning: a fixed holiday period between terms in universities and law courts.;the action of leaving something one previously occupied.

origins: early 17th century: via late Latin from Greek suzugia, from suzugos ‘yoked, paired’, from sun- ‘with, together’ + the stem of zeugnunai ‘to yoke’.
meaning: a conjunction or opposition, especially of the moon with the sun.;a pair of connected or corresponding things.

origins: mid 19th century: from French guillochis, denoting the ornamentation, or guilloche, a carving tool.
meaning: ornamentation resembling braided or interlaced ribbons.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: like ambrosia; delicious; fragrant;of or fit for the gods; divine

origins: Etymology Unknown;Middle English: from Old French descord (noun), descorder (verb), from Latin discordare, from discors ‘discordant’, from dis- (expressing negation, reversal) + cor, cord- ‘heart’
meaning: (of people) disagree;disagreement between people;lack of harmony between notes sounding together

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of igneous rock) poured out when molten and later solidified.;expressing feelings of gratitude, pleasure, or approval in an unrestrained or heartfelt manner

origins: late Middle English: from Latin intricat- ‘entangled’, from the verb intricare, from in- ‘into’ + tricae ‘tricks, perplexities’.
meaning: very complicated or detailed.

origins: from late Latin Beëlzebub, translating Hebrew ba‘al zĕḇūḇ ‘lord of flies’, the name of a Philistine god (2 Kings 1:2), and Greek Beelzeboul ‘the Devil’ (Matt. 12:24)
meaning: a name for the Devil.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘of uncertain occurrence’): from Latin contingere ‘befall’, from con- ‘together with’ + tangere ‘to touch’. The noun sense was originally ‘something happening by chance’, then ‘a person's share resulting from a division, a quota’; the current sense dates from the early 18th century.
meaning: subject to chance.;occurring or existing only if (certain circumstances) are the case; dependent on.

origins: Italian, from pappare ‘eat hungrily’.
meaning: pasta in the form of broad flat ribbons, usually served with a meat sauce.

origins: Middle English: from Old French apertenance, based on late Latin appertinere ‘belong to’ (see appertain).
meaning: an accessory or other item associated with a particular activity or style of living.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin altercatio(n- ), from the verb altercari (see altercate).
meaning: a noisy argument or disagreement, especially in public.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action of obtaining or procuring something

origins: late 16th century; earliest use found in Tarltons Newes out of Purgatorie. From word + monger
meaning: Originally: a person who deals in strange, pedantic, or empty words (depreciative). Now also: a person skilled in the use of words.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin morosus ‘peevish’, from mos, mor- ‘manner’.
meaning: sullen and ill-tempered.

origins: Middle English (in prowess (sense 2)): from Old French proesce, from prou ‘valiant’. Sense 1 dates from the early 20th century.
meaning: skill or expertise in a particular activity or field.;bravery in battle.

origins: Middle English: from Old French moneie, from Latin moneta ‘mint, money’, originally a title of the goddess Juno, in whose temple in Rome money was minted.
meaning: a current medium of exchange in the form of coins and banknotes; coins and banknotes collectively.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin pius ‘dutiful, pious’ + -ous.
meaning: devoutly religious.;(of a hope) sincere but unlikely to be fulfilled.

origins: Middle English: from Old Norse lit-mosi, from litr ‘dye’ + mosi ‘moss’.
meaning: a dye obtained from certain lichens that is red under acid conditions and blue under alkaline conditions.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: free from echo

origins: Middle English: from Old French tigre, from Latin tigris, from Greek.
meaning: a very large solitary cat with a yellow-brown coat striped with black, native to the forests of Asia but becoming increasingly rare.;used in names of tiger moths and striped butterflies, e.g. scarlet tiger, plain tiger.;another term for Tamil Tigers.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a covering or coating on a structure or material

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a manner characterized by extreme happiness or joy

origins: late 18th century: the name of a specific kind of kangaroo in an Aboriginal language of North Queensland.
meaning: a large plant-eating marsupial with a long powerful tail and strongly developed hindlimbs that enable it to travel by leaping, found only in Australia and New Guinea.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘use a word in more than one sense’): from late Latin aequivocat- ‘called by the same name’, from the verb aequivocare, from aequivocus (see equivocal).
meaning: use ambiguous language so as to conceal the truth or avoid committing oneself.

origins: late 15th century: from Old French desgorger, from des- (expressing removal) + gorge ‘throat’.
meaning: pour (something) out.;remove the sediment from (a sparkling wine) after fermentation.

origins: late 16th century: from ecclesiastical Latin cooperat- ‘worked together’, from the verb cooperari, from co- ‘together’ + operari ‘to work’.
meaning: work jointly towards the same end.

origins: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Robert Burton (1577–1640), writer. From Dulcinea (more fully Dulcinea del Toboso), the name (formed on Spanish dulce sweet) which Don Quixote gives to his (imaginary) mistress in Cervantes' Don Quixote
meaning: A person regarded as embodying the idealized attributes of the literary character Dulcinea; specifically a mistress, a lady love, a sweetheart.

origins: mid 19th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: depart quickly or hurriedly; run away.

origins: late 16th century: via late Latin from Greek, ‘separation, expansion’, from diastellein, from dia ‘apart’ + stellein ‘to place’.
meaning: the phase of the heartbeat when the heart muscle relaxes and allows the chambers to fill with blood.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a way that is impossible to stop or prevent

origins: late 19th century: apparently a diminutive of piano1.
meaning: a piano equipped to be played automatically using a piano roll.

origins: late 18th century: French, from the verb colporter, probably an alteration of comporter, from Latin comportare ‘carry with one’.
meaning: a person who sells books, newspapers, and similar literature.

origins: late 19th century: alteration of capsicine, the name of a substance formerly thought to have the same property.
meaning: a compound that is responsible for the pungency of capsicums.

origins: early 19th century: French, literally ‘coming back’, present participle (used as a noun) of revenir .
meaning: a person who has returned, especially supposedly from the dead.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: not spoiled or made impure

origins: Old English trīewth, trēowth  ‘faithfulness, constancy’ (see true, -th2).
meaning: the quality or state of being true.

origins: Japanese, from kan ‘Chinese’ + ji ‘character’.
meaning: a system of Japanese writing using Chinese characters, used primarily for content words.

origins: Unknown
meaning: átináŚsymboláSn

origins: modern Latin (genus name), named after Pedro Jaime Esteve (1500–66), Spanish physician and botanist.
meaning: a shrub native to tropical and subtropical America, whose leaves may be used as a calorie-free substitute for sugar.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘collapse of a building’): from Old French ruine, from Latin ruina, from ruere ‘to fall’.
meaning: the physical destruction or disintegration of something or the state of disintegrating or being destroyed.

origins: early 19th century: from modern Latin medium aevum ‘middle age’ + -al.
meaning: relating to the Middle Ages.

origins: mid 16th century: from lull + bye-bye, a sound used as a refrain in lullabies; compare with bye-byes.
meaning: a quiet, gentle song sung to send a child to sleep.

origins: late 19th century: named after Charles-Augustin de Coulomb (1736–1806), French military engineer.
meaning: the SI unit of electric charge, equal to the quantity of electricity conveyed in one second by a current of one ampere.

origins: French, diminutive of profit ‘profit’.
meaning: a small ball of soft, sweet choux pastry filled with cream and covered with chocolate sauce, served as a dessert.

origins: 1930s: imitative.
meaning: clear the throat noisily.

origins: early 16th century: from Latin, variant of spathula, diminutive of spatha (see spathe).
meaning: an implement with a broad, flat, blunt blade, used for mixing and spreading things, especially in cooking and painting.;a thin, flat wooden or metal instrument used in medical examinations, for holding down the tongue or taking cell samples.

origins: late Middle English doucet, from Old French doucet, diminutive of doux, from Latin dulcis ‘sweet’. The Latin form influenced the modern spelling.
meaning: (especially of sound) sweet and soothing (often used ironically).

origins: late Middle English: from the medieval Latin phrase proviso (quod) ‘it being provided (that)’, from Latin providere ‘foresee, provide’.
meaning: a condition or qualification attached to an agreement or statement.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French cinnamome (from Greek kinnamōmon ), and Latin cinnamon (from Greek kinnamon ), both from a Semitic language and perhaps based on Malay.
meaning: an aromatic spice made from the peeled, dried, and rolled bark of a SE Asian tree.;the tree which yields cinnamon.

origins: 1970s: abbreviation.
meaning: a barbecue.

origins: early 20th century: from epi- ‘in addition’ + oxy-2.
meaning: any of a class of adhesives, plastics, or other materials that are polymers of epoxides.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin camisia ‘shirt or nightgown’.
meaning: a dress hanging straight from the shoulders, popular in the 1920s.

origins: Middle English: from Old French polie, probably from a medieval Greek diminutive of polos ‘pivot, axis’.
meaning: a wheel with a grooved rim around which a cord passes, which acts to change the direction of a force applied to the cord and is used to raise heavy weights.

origins: early 18th century: from late Latin, from Latin tapete ‘carpet’.
meaning: a reflective layer of the choroid in the eyes of many animals, causing them to shine in the dark.

origins: late Middle English (as an adjective): from late Latin criminalis, from Latin crimen, crimin- (see crime).
meaning: a person who has committed a crime.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘expressing or involving a curse’): via Old French from Latin execrabilis, from exsecrari ‘to curse’ (see execrate).
meaning: extremely bad or unpleasant.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a narrative of the miraculous deeds of a god or hero

origins: late Middle English: from Old French prolixe or Latin prolixus ‘poured forth, extended’, from pro- ‘outward’ + liquere ‘be liquid’.
meaning: (of speech or writing) using or containing too many words; tediously lengthy.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin infringere, from in- ‘into’ + frangere ‘to break’.
meaning: actively break the terms of (a law, agreement, etc.).;act so as to limit or undermine (something); encroach on.

origins: late 17th century (in the sense ‘shelter’): from French; probably from Germanic bases meaning ‘hamlet’ and ‘enclosure’.
meaning: a large building with an extensive floor area, typically for housing aircraft.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin avaritia, from avarus ‘greedy’.
meaning: extreme greed for wealth or material gain.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the state of being nonchalant

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of an organ or other body part) turned or pushed inward on itself.;of, denoting, or typical of an introvert.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin votivus, from votum (see vote). The original sense was ‘expressing a desire’, preserved in votive Mass.
meaning: offered or consecrated in fulfilment of a vow.

origins: Unknown
meaning: any of various yellow pigments (as Naples yellow)

origins: Middle English naperon, from Old French, diminutive of nape, nappe ‘tablecloth’, from Latin mappa ‘napkin’. The n was lost by wrong division of a napron ; compare with adder1.
meaning: a protective garment worn over the front of one's clothes and tied at the back.;a small area adjacent to another larger area or structure.;an endless conveyor made of overlapping plates.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who carries out a harmful, illegal, or immoral act

origins: late 18th century: named after Blarney, a castle near Cork in Ireland, where there is a stone said to give the gift of persuasive speech to anyone who kisses it.
meaning: talk which aims to charm, flatter, or persuade (often considered typical of Irish people).

origins: late Middle English (denoting the foremost part of an army): shortening of Old French avan(t)garde, from avant ‘before’ + garde ‘guard’.
meaning: a group of people leading the way in new developments or ideas.;the foremost part of an advancing army or naval force.

origins: mid 16th century: alteration (probably by association with accompany) of Middle English complice  ‘an associate’, via Old French from late Latin complex, complic- ‘allied’, from com- ‘together’ + the root of plicare ‘to fold’.
meaning: a person who helps another commit a crime.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘hack, mangle’): from Old Norse hǫggva ‘hew’.
meaning: dispute or bargain persistently, especially over the cost of something.

origins: late 16th century. From classical Latin adversāria things written on one side of the page, notes, observations (Cicero), in post-classical Latin also commonplace book, use as noun (short for scripta adversāria) of neuter plural of adversārius
meaning: With plural agreement: miscellaneous remarks and observations; notes, miscellanea. With singular agreement: a book consisting of these, a commonplace book.

origins: early 19th century: from Latin fenestrare (see fenestrate) + -ed1.
meaning: provided with a window or windows.;having perforations, apertures, or transparent areas.

origins: from gyro- ‘relating to rotation’, on the pattern of helicopter .
meaning: a small, light single-seater autogiro.

origins: Italian, plural of calamaro, from medieval Latin calamarium ‘pen case’, from Greek kalamos ‘pen’ (with reference to the squid's long tapering internal shell and its ink). The variant calamares is Spanish.
meaning: squid served as food.

origins: late 16th century: from French tulipe, via Turkish from Persian dulband ‘turban’, from the shape of the expanded flower.
meaning: a bulbous spring-flowering plant of the lily family, with boldly coloured cup-shaped flowers.

origins: mid 18th century: from Greek autodidaktos ‘self-taught’, from autos ‘self’ + didaskein ‘teach’.
meaning: a self-taught person.

origins: from French, of unknown origin.
meaning: an item of sweet food made by baking a mixture of stiffly beaten egg whites and sugar until crisp.;a light mixture of stiffly beaten egg whites and sugar, baked until crisp or used as a topping for desserts.

origins: Middle English (as a noun): from Latin lapidarius (in late Latin ‘stonecutter’), from lapis, lapid- ‘stone’. The adjective dates from the early 18th century.
meaning: relating to the engraving, cutting, or polishing of stones and gems.

origins: 1920s: from German, from Latin dictatum ‘something dictated’, neuter past participle of dictare .
meaning: an order or decree imposed by someone in power without popular consent.

origins: late 16th century (denoting an unauthorized trader trespassing on the rights of a trade monopoly): from inter- ‘amid’ + -loper as in archaic landloper ‘vagabond’ (from Middle Dutch landlooper ).
meaning: a person who becomes involved in a place or situation where they are not wanted or are considered not to belong.

origins: late 16th century: from French compatriote, from late Latin compatriota (translating Greek sumpatriōtēs ), from com- ‘together with’ + patriota (see patriot).
meaning: a fellow citizen or national of a country.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘scroll, explanatory note, appendix’): from Old French cedule, from late Latin schedula ‘slip of paper’, diminutive of scheda, from Greek skhedē ‘papyrus leaf’. The verb dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: a plan for carrying out a process or procedure, giving lists of intended events and times.;an appendix to a formal document or statute, especially as a list, table, or inventory.;(with reference to the British system of income tax) any of the forms (named ‘A’, ‘B’, etc.) issued for completion and relating to the various classes into which taxable income is divided.

origins: mid 16th century: archaic past participle of stay1.
meaning: sedate, respectable, and unadventurous.

origins: Middle English (also in the sense ‘oblige by oath’): from Old French conjurer ‘to plot or exorcise’, from Latin conjurare ‘band together by an oath, conspire’ (in medieval Latin ‘invoke’), from con- ‘together’ + jurare ‘swear’.
meaning: cause (a spirit or ghost) to appear by means of a magic ritual.;implore (someone) to do something.

origins: mid 16th century (originally also calicut ): alteration of Calicut, where the fabric originated.
meaning: a type of cotton cloth, typically plain white or unbleached.

origins: Unknown
meaning: áviolating convention or propriety; bizarre

origins: early 20th century: from French, feminine adjective meaning ‘of Limousin’, originally denoting a caped cloak worn in Limousin (see Limousin1): originally the driver's seat of the car was outside in a separate compartment, covered with a canopy.
meaning: a large, luxurious car, especially one driven by a chauffeur who is separated from the passengers by a partition.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin arduus ‘steep, difficult’ + -ous.
meaning: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.

origins: late 16th century (as an adjective in the sense ‘feeble’): from obsolete French, in Old French fieble (see feeble). Both noun senses also formerly occurred as senses of the word feeble and all date from the 17th century.
meaning: a minor weakness or eccentricity in someone's character.;the part of a sword blade from the middle to the point.

origins: late 16th century (originally denoting the great auk): possibly of Welsh origin, from pen gwyn ‘white head’.
meaning: a large flightless seabird of the southern hemisphere, with black upper parts and white underparts and wings developed into flippers for swimming under water.

origins: Middle English: from Old French oncle, from late Latin aunculus, alteration of Latin avunculus ‘maternal uncle’ (see avuncular).
meaning: the brother of one's father or mother or the husband of one's aunt.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: regular variation in magnitude or position around a central point.;movement back and forth at a regular speed

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin provincialis ‘belonging to a province’ (see province).
meaning: of or concerning a province of a country or empire.;of or concerning the regions outside the capital city of a country, especially when regarded as unsophisticated or narrow-minded.

origins: late 17th century: from French morille, from Dutch morilje ; related to German Morchel ‘fungus’.
meaning: a widely distributed edible fungus which has a brown oval or pointed fruiting body with an irregular honeycombed surface bearing the spores.

origins: early 19th century: humorously from bump, on the pattern of fractious .
meaning: irritatingly self-assertive.

origins: Italian.
meaning: a type of flat Italian bread made with yeast and olive oil and flavoured with herbs.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin, literally ‘further, more distant’.
meaning: existing beyond what is obvious or admitted; intentionally hidden.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: involving or of the nature of mutual accusations or counteraccusations

origins: late 19th century; earliest use found in The Century Dictionary. From phyto- + -philous
meaning: Especially of an insect or other invertebrate: living in association with plants.

origins: from Russian kulebyaka .
meaning: a Russian pie of fish or meat, cabbage or other vegetables, and herbs.

origins: mid 16th century: from French clandestin or Latin clandestinus, from clam ‘secretly’.
meaning: kept secret or done secretively, especially because illicit.

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French pé de grue ‘crane's foot’, a mark used to denote succession in pedigrees.
meaning: the record of descent of an animal, showing it to be pure-bred.;the recorded ancestry or lineage of a person or family.

origins: late Middle English: from medieval Latin syringa, from syrinx (see syrinx).
meaning: a tube with a nozzle and piston or bulb for sucking in and ejecting liquid in a thin stream, used for cleaning wounds or body cavities, or fitted with a hollow needle for injecting or withdrawing fluids.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: able to be allocated

origins: mid 18th century: from Italian, from impresa ‘undertaking’.
meaning: a person who organizes and often finances concerts, plays, or operas.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin, literally ‘royal palace’, from Greek basilikē, feminine of basilikos ‘royal’, from basileus ‘king’.
meaning: a large oblong hall or building with double colonnades and a semicircular apse, used in ancient Rome as a law court or for public assemblies.

origins: Unknown
meaning: mountain range in southwestern Kyrgyzstan; highest peak 19,554 feet (5960 meters)

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: local area network.

origins: Italian.
meaning: pasta squares stuffed with a variety of fillings, like small ravioli.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a poisonous Philippine tree (Semecarpus perrottetii) of the family Anacardiaceae that has hardwood and yields an illuminating resin

origins: Spanish, perhaps related to guayaba ‘guava’ or guayabo ‘guava tree’.
meaning: an open-necked Cuban or Mexican shirt with two breast pockets and two pockets over the hips, typically having short sleeves and worn untucked.

origins: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘concise table of headings of a discourse’): modern Latin, originally a misreading of Latin sittybas, accusative plural of sittyba, from Greek sittuba ‘title slip, label’.
meaning: the subjects in a course of study or teaching.;(in the Roman Catholic Church) a summary of points decided by papal decree regarding heretical doctrines or practices.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: champagne;(of a person) full of cheerful high spirits;containing bubbles

origins: late 18th century: originally black and pidgin English imitating Spanish sabe usted ‘you know’.
meaning: shrewdness and practical knowledge; the ability to make good judgements.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: causing or characterized by swollen inflamed lymph nodes in the armpit or groin

origins: early 17th century: from medieval Latin authenticat- ‘established as valid’, from the verb authenticare, from late Latin authenticus ‘genuine’ (see authentic).
meaning: prove or show (something) to be true, genuine, or valid.

origins: late 17th century: from French brillant ‘shining’, present participle of briller, from Italian brillare, probably from Latin beryllus (see beryl).
meaning: (of light or colour) very bright.;exceptionally clever or talented.;excellent; marvellous.

origins: mid 17th century (as a noun): from modern Latin, neuter (used as a noun) of the Latin adjective maximus, superlative of magnus ‘great’. The adjectival use dates from the early 19th century.
meaning: as great, high, or intense as possible or permitted.

origins: Old English hleahtor, of Germanic origin; related to German Gelächter, also to laugh.
meaning: the action or sound of laughing.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the programs and other operating information used by a computer

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an irregular rising and falling in number or amount; a variation

origins: late 18th century: from French, from Catalan alberginia, from Arabic al-bāḏinjān (based on Persian bādingān, from Sanskrit vātiṃgaṇa ).
meaning: the purple egg-shaped fruit of a tropical Old World plant, which is eaten as a vegetable.;the large plant of the nightshade family which bears aubergines.

origins: Old English fōdor, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch voeder and German Futter, also to food.
meaning: food, especially dried hay or straw, for cattle and other livestock.

origins: late 19th century: modern Latin, from Latin claustrum ‘lock, bolt’ + -phobia.
meaning: extreme or irrational fear of confined places.

origins: late 18th century: from Telugu pandikokku, literally ‘pig-rat’.
meaning: a mainly insectivorous marsupial native to Australia and New Guinea.

origins: late 16th century (originally denoting a beetle of any kind): from Latin scarabaeus, from Greek skarabeios .
meaning: a large dung beetle of the eastern Mediterranean area, regarded as sacred in ancient Egypt.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin inevitabilis, from in- ‘not’ + evitabilis ‘avoidable’ (from evitare ‘avoid’).
meaning: certain to happen; unavoidable.

origins: late Middle English (denoting the humerus): from Latin; related to ell1.
meaning: the thinner and longer of the two bones in the human forearm, on the side opposite to the thumb.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the language of the Teutons.;relating to the Teutons.;denoting the Germanic branch of the Indo-European language family.

origins: Middle English: alteration of the dialect verb slidder, frequentative from the base of slide.
meaning: move smoothly over a surface with a twisting or oscillating motion.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an island in Venice, Italy, that contains the old mercantile quarter of medieval Venice. The Rialto Bridge, completed in 1591, crosses the Grand Canal between Rialto and the San Marco Islands.;a city in southwestern California, west of San Bernardino; population 98,700 (est. 2008).

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: fearlessly

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin apiarium, from apis ‘bee’.
meaning: a place where bees are kept; a collection of beehives.

origins: Mexican Spanish, literally ‘little strips’.
meaning: a dish of Mexican origin consisting of strips of spiced beef or chicken, chopped vegetables, and grated cheese, wrapped in a soft tortilla and often served with sour cream.

origins: mid 19th century: French.
meaning: a maker or seller of pastries and cakes.

origins: mid 17th century: via French from Latin geometricus, from Greek geōmetrikos, from geōmetrēs (see geometer).
meaning: relating to geometry, or according to its methods.;characterized by or decorated with regular lines and shapes.

origins: Middle English: from Old French oignon, based on Latin unio(n- ), denoting a kind of onion.
meaning: a swollen edible bulb used as a vegetable, having a pungent taste and smell and composed of several concentric layers.;the plant that produces the onion, with long rolled or straplike leaves and spherical heads of greenish-white flowers.

origins: early 18th century: perhaps from dialect scun  ‘skim along’, influenced by Dutch words beginning with sch- .
meaning: a sailing ship with two or more masts, typically with the foremast smaller than the mainmast.;a glass for drinking a large measure of sherry.

origins: Unknown
meaning: maker of cameos

origins: Middle English (in citation (sense 2)): from Old French, from Latin citatio(n- ), from citare ‘cite’.
meaning: a quotation from or reference to a book, paper, or author, especially in a scholarly work.;a mention of a praiseworthy act in an official report, especially that of a member of the armed forces in wartime.;a summons to appear in court.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘dependent on one's will or pleasure, discretionary’): from Latin arbitrarius, from arbiter ‘judge, supreme ruler’, perhaps influenced by French arbitraire .
meaning: based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.;(of power or a ruling body) unrestrained and autocratic in the use of authority.;(of a constant or other quantity) of unspecified value.

origins: early 20th century: abbreviation of federal. The abbreviation fed had previously been used in the late 18th century to denote a member of the Federalist Party, who advocated a union of American colonies after the War of Independence.
meaning: a federal agent or official, especially a member of the FBI.;short for Federal Reserve.

origins: mid 19th century: from French, from Greek gleukos ‘sweet wine’, related to glukus ‘sweet’.
meaning: a simple sugar which is an important energy source in living organisms and is a component of many carbohydrates.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: filled with bitter criticism or malice

origins: Old English grōwan (originally referring chiefly to plants), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch groeien, also to grass and green.
meaning: (of a living thing) undergo natural development by increasing in size and changing physically.;become larger or greater over a period of time; increase.;become gradually or increasingly.

origins: early 17th century: from French sépulchral or Latin sepulchralis, from sepulcrum (see sepulchre).
meaning: relating to a tomb or interment.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: secure or fasten from the underside, especially by a rope or chain passed underneath.

origins: mid 18th century: from Creek, from ito ‘tree’ + opilwa ‘swamp’.
meaning: a North American or Asian tree of damp and swampy habitats, which yields useful timber.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin rex, reg- ‘king’ + -cide, probably suggested by French régicide .
meaning: the action of killing a king.

origins: early 18th century: modern Latin, from con- ‘together with’ + dominium ‘right of ownership’ (see dominion). condominium (sense 1) dates from the 1960s.
meaning: a building or complex of buildings containing a number of individually owned apartments or houses.;the joint control of a state's affairs by other states.

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘original, former, primitive and undeveloped’): from Latin pristinus ‘former’. The senses ‘unspoilt’ and ‘spotless’ date from the 1920s.
meaning: in its original condition; unspoilt.

origins: late 15th century: from Old French larcin, from Latin latrocinium, from latro(n- ) ‘robber’, earlier ‘mercenary soldier’, from Greek latreus .
meaning: theft of personal property. In English law larceny was replaced as a statutory crime by theft in 1968.

origins: early 18th century: from French, from Latin minuscula (littera) ‘somewhat smaller (letter)’.
meaning: extremely small; tiny.;of or in lower-case letters, as distinct from capitals or uncials.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the disappearance of ice from a previously glaciated region

origins: Middle English: from Anglo-Latin peta, perhaps of Celtic origin.
meaning: a brown deposit resembling soil, formed by the partial decomposition of vegetable matter in the wet acidic conditions of bogs and fens, and often cut out and dried for use as fuel and in gardening.

origins: Old English eliotropus (originally applied to various plants whose flowers turn towards the sun), via Latin from Greek hēliotropion ‘plant turning its flowers to the sun’, from hēlios ‘sun’ + trepein ‘to turn’. The spelling was influenced by French héliotrope .
meaning: a plant of the borage family, cultivated for its fragrant purple or blue flowers which are used in perfume.

origins: Middle English: from Latin (first word of the Mass), accusative of requies ‘rest’.
meaning: (especially in the Roman Catholic Church) a Mass for the repose of the souls of the dead.

origins: early 20th century (originally denoting the car of an airship): from French, from late Latin navicella, diminutive of Latin navis ‘ship’.
meaning: a streamlined casing on the outside of an aircraft or motor vehicle, especially one housing an aircraft engine.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or denoting pinnipeds.;a carnivorous aquatic mammal of the order Pinnipedia, such as a seal or walrus.

origins: 1990s: from fashion + -ista.
meaning: a designer of haute couture.;a devoted follower of fashion.

origins: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Robert Lovell (?1630–1690), naturalist. From classical Latin rubefacient-, rubefaciēns, present participle of rubefacere; compare -facient;Etymology Unknown
meaning: Producing redness of the skin (especially as a method of counterirritation); of or relating to this property.;A rubefacient medicinal preparation.

origins: early 20th century: from catalysis, on the pattern of analyst .
meaning: a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.

origins: late Middle English bitore, from Old French butor, based on Latin butio ‘bittern’ + taurus ‘bull’ (because of its call). The - n was added in the 16th century, perhaps by association with hern, obsolete variant of heron.
meaning: a large marshbird of the heron family, which is typically smaller than a heron, with brown streaked plumage. The larger kinds are noted for the deep booming call of the male in the breeding season.

origins: late 18th century: via French from Greek a- ‘without’ + khrōmatikos (from khrōma ‘colour’).
meaning: relating to, using, or denoting lenses that transmit light without separating it into constituent colours.;without colour.

origins: early 19th century: back-formation from malingerer, apparently from French malingre, perhaps formed as mal- ‘wrongly’ + haingre ‘weak’, probably of Germanic origin.
meaning: pretend to be ill in order to escape duty or work.

origins: mid 19th century: from modern Latin Thylacinus (genus name), from Greek thulakos ‘pouch’.
meaning: a doglike carnivorous marsupial with stripes across the rump, found only in Tasmania. There have been no confirmed sightings since one was captured in 1933, and it is probably now extinct.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin praescient- ‘knowing beforehand’, from the verb praescire, from prae ‘before’ + scire ‘know’.
meaning: having or showing knowledge of events before they take place.

origins: Unknown
meaning: hyphenated a traditional Burmese musical ensemble consisting largely of drums and gongs

origins: late 15th century: medieval Latin, from Latin verbum ‘word’. Compare with literatim.
meaning: in exactly the same words as were used originally.

origins: early 16th century: from Latin colubrinus, from coluber ‘snake’.
meaning: relating to or resembling a snake.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or adhering to the doctrine of utilitarianism;an adherent of utilitarianism.;designed to be useful or practical rather than attractive

origins: early 17th century: from French, from par terre ‘on the ground’.
meaning: a level space in a garden occupied by an ornamental arrangement of flower beds.;the part of the ground floor of a theatre auditorium behind the orchestra pit, especially the part beneath the balconies.

origins: mid 19th century. Probably from scientific Latin angiitis from post-classical Latin angio- + -itis
meaning: Inflammation of blood vessels; vasculitis.

origins: early 20th century: from Latin insula ‘island’ + -in1.
meaning: a hormone produced in the pancreas by the islets of Langerhans, which regulates the amount of glucose in the blood. The lack of insulin causes a form of diabetes.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin labefactio(n- ), from labefacere ‘weaken’, from labi ‘to fall’ + facere ‘make’.
meaning: deterioration or downfall.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin inchoatus, past participle of inchoare, variant of incohare ‘begin’.
meaning: just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.;(of an offence, such as incitement or conspiracy) anticipating or preparatory to a further criminal act.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a solid formed from a gel by drying with unhindered shrinkageáŚ compareáaerogel

origins: late Middle English: from lay2 + -ity.
meaning: lay people, as distinct from the clergy.;ordinary people, as distinct from professionals or experts.

origins: late 18th century: from Hindi nainsukh, from nain ‘eye’ + sukh ‘pleasure’.
meaning: a fine, soft cotton fabric, originally from South Asia.

origins: Old English inweardlīce  (see inward, -ly2).
meaning: within the mind.

origins: Old English giernan, from a Germanic base meaning ‘eager’.
meaning: have an intense feeling of longing for something, typically something that one has lost or been separated from.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: excessively greedy

origins: Middle English: from Old French ter(e)bentine, from Latin ter(e)binthina (resina) ‘(resin) of the turpentine tree’, from terebinthus (see terebinth).
meaning: a volatile pungent oil distilled from gum turpentine or pine wood, used in mixing paints and varnishes and in liniment.;any of a number of trees which yield turpentine or a similar resin.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin ossiculum, diminutive of os ‘bone’.
meaning: a very small bone, especially one of those in the middle ear.

origins: mid 16th century: from French, diminutive of caboche ‘head’.
meaning: a gem that has been polished but not faceted.

origins: from the modern Latin genus name Penicillium (see penicillium) + -in1.
meaning: an antibiotic or group of antibiotics produced naturally by certain blue moulds, now usually prepared synthetically. Penicillin was discovered in 1928 and during the Second World War became the first antibiotic to be used by doctors.;a blue mould of a type that produces penicillin.

origins: early 19th century: from Latin, literally ‘open mouth’, from rict- ‘gaped’, from the verb ringi .
meaning: a fixed grimace or grin.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: behaviour is bold or daring.very tense or anxious

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin matrimonium, based on mater, matr- ‘mother’.
meaning: the state of being married; marriage.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a story or event recorded by a camera as a set of moving images and shown in a theater or on television; a motion picture

origins: late 15th century: perhaps from Old French beegueule ‘open-mouthed’, from beer ‘open wide’ + gueule ‘throat’.
meaning: a small hound of a breed with a short coat, used for hunting hares.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin manumittere, literally ‘send forth from the hand’, from manus ‘hand’ + mittere ‘send’.
meaning: release from slavery; set free.

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin palatium ‘palace’ (see palace) + -al.
meaning: resembling a palace in being spacious and splendid.

origins: early 20th century (originally denoting a five-cent piece): of unknown origin.
meaning: a bus or other vehicle carrying passengers for a low fare.

origins: late 16th century: perhaps partly from Latin quando ‘when’.
meaning: a state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation.

origins: mid 17th century: French, from coiffer ‘arrange the hair’, in Old French‘cover with a coif’ (see coif).
meaning: a person's hairstyle.

origins: 1960s: perhaps named after Hiram Codd, who invented a bottle for fizzy drinks (1875); the derivation remains unconfirmed.
meaning: nonsense.

origins: early 16th century: from Middle Low German weddersins, from Middle High German widersinnes, from wider ‘against’ + sin ‘direction’; the second element was associated with Scots sin ‘sun’.
meaning: in a direction contrary to the sun's course, considered as unlucky; anticlockwise.

origins: early 16th century (originally Scots): of unknown origin.
meaning: a ghost or ghostlike image of someone, especially one seen shortly before or after their death.

origins: Unknown
meaning: the action of making forcible entry

origins: Middle English: from Old French, ‘grape’, from an alteration of Latin racemus ‘grape bunch’.
meaning: a partially dried grape.

origins: Middle English: from Old French proverbe, from Latin proverbium, from pro- ‘(put) forth’ + verbum ‘word’.
meaning: a short, well-known pithy saying, stating a general truth or piece of advice.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French eternite, from Latin aeternitas, from aeternus ‘without beginning or end’ (see eternal).
meaning: infinite or unending time.

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘wealthy’): from Latin opulent- ‘wealthy, splendid’, from opes ‘wealth’.
meaning: ostentatiously costly and luxurious.

origins: early 16th century: from French anxiété or Latin anxietas, from anxius (see anxious).
meaning: a feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease about something with an uncertain outcome.;strong desire or concern to do something or for something to happen.

origins: early 16th century: from French vétéran or Latin veteranus, from vetus ‘old’.
meaning: a person who has had long experience in a particular field.

origins: Middle English: from Latin, from Greek pous, pod- ‘foot’ + agra ‘seizure’.
meaning: gout of the foot, especially the big toe.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘natural or proper’): from Latin genuinus, from genu ‘knee’ (with reference to the Roman custom of a father acknowledging paternity of a newborn child by placing it on his knee); later associated with genus ‘birth, race, stock’.
meaning: truly what something is said to be; authentic.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin ursinus, from ursus ‘bear’.
meaning: relating to or resembling bears.

origins: late 19th century: named after J. P. Joule (see Joule, James Prescott).
meaning: the SI unit of work or energy, equal to the work done by a force of one newton when its point of application moves one metre in the direction of action of the force, equivalent to one 3600th of a watt-hour.

origins: Unknown
meaning: capable of being rescinded

origins: mid 18th century: Italian, literally ‘in the fresh (air)’.
meaning: (especially with reference to eating) in the open air.

origins: Italian, from arpeggiare ‘play the harp’, from arpa ‘harp’.
meaning: the notes of a chord played in rapid succession, either ascending or descending.

origins: late Middle English (in the senses ‘serving as conclusive evidence of’ and ‘making manifest’): from Old French demonstratif, -ive, from Latin demonstrativus, from demonstrare ‘point out’ (see demonstrate).
meaning: (of a person) unrestrained in showing feelings, especially those of affection.;serving as conclusive evidence of something.;(of a determiner or pronoun) indicating the person or thing referred to (e.g. this, that, those ).

origins: late 19th century: from Greek krupton, neuter of kruptos ‘hidden’.
meaning: the chemical element of atomic number 36, a member of the noble gas series. It is obtained by distillation of liquid air, and is used in some kinds of electric light.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the quality of being cheerful and full of energy; exuberance

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or situated in the back of the head

origins: Old English ǣmtig, ǣmetig  ‘at leisure, empty’, from ǣmetta  ‘leisure’, perhaps from ā  ‘no, not’ + mōt ‘meeting’ (see moot).
meaning: containing nothing; not filled or occupied.;(of words or a gesture) lacking meaning or sincerity.;having no value or purpose.

origins: Etymology Unknown
