meaning: a follower or adherent of the works of Swiss psychologist Carl Jung;relating to or characteristic of the Swiss psychologist Carl Jung or his works

origins: early 20th century: from modern Latin Mustelidae (plural), from Latin mustela ‘weasel’.
meaning: a mammal of the weasel family ( Mustelidae ), distinguished by having a long body, short legs, and musky scent glands under the tail.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a widely distributed, commercially important tuna that has yellow anal and dorsal fins.

origins: Unknown
meaning: confinement to a sickbed

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, diminutive of helme, of Germanic origin; related to helm2.
meaning: a hard or padded protective hat, various types of which are worn by soldiers, police officers, motorcyclists, sports players, and others.;the arched upper part (galea) of the corolla in some flowers, especially those of the mint and orchid families.;a predatory mollusc with a squat heavy shell, which lives in tropical and temperate seas.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French augmenter (verb), augment (noun), or late Latin augmentare, from Latin augere ‘to increase’;Etymology Unknown
meaning: make (something) greater by adding to it; increase;a vowel prefixed to past tenses of verbs in Greek and other Indo-European languages.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: billion.;the chemical element boron.;bass.;magnetic flux density.;black (used in describing grades of pencil lead);(used in recording moves in chess) bishop;the seventh note of the diatonic scale of C major.;bomber (in designations of US aircraft types);barn(s).;(in personal ads) black.;basso.;born (used to indicate a date of birth);the second letter of the alphabet.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action of officially absolving someone from blame; vindication;the release of someone from a duty or obligation.

origins: late 16th century (denoting an area of flat ground on top of a rampart): from French, from Italian spianata, from Latin explanatus ‘flattened, levelled’, from explanare (see explain).
meaning: a long, open, level area, typically beside the sea, along which people may walk for pleasure.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin oblongus ‘longish’.
meaning: a rectangular object or flat figure with unequal adjacent sides.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French arenge, from medieval Latin harenga, perhaps of Germanic origin. The spelling was later altered to conform with French harangue (noun), haranguer (verb).
meaning: a lengthy and aggressive speech.

origins: Italian, literally ‘drowned’, past participle of affogare ‘to drown’.
meaning: an Italian dessert consisting of vanilla ice cream topped with a shot of espresso coffee.

origins: mid 19th century (in an earlier sense). From lateri- + -grade, after post-classical Latin laterigradus, adjective, scientific Latin Laterigradae, former group name (Latreille 1817)
meaning: (Characterized by) walking or running sideways; formerly specifically designating a spider of the group Laterigradae (now disused).

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: of or having indigestion or consequent irritability or depression.;a person who suffers from indigestion or irritability.

origins: Unknown
meaning: resort district of northern Austria located east of Salzburg and containing notable salt deposits; chief town Bad Ischl

origins: mid 19th century: from hyper- ‘beyond, exceeding’ + Greek -trophia ‘nourishment’.
meaning: the enlargement of an organ or tissue from the increase in size of its cells.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin, diminutive of cerebrum.
meaning: the part of the brain at the back of the skull in vertebrates, which coordinates and regulates muscular activity.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: If you forestall someone, you realize what they are likely to do and prevent them from doing it.

origins: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch ik and German ich, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin ego and Greek egō;Etymology Unknown
meaning: the Roman numeral for one.;used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself;the chemical element iodine.;(preceding a highway number) Interstate.;electric current;Island(s) or Isle(s) (chiefly on maps).;the ninth letter of the alphabet.;Independent.;the imaginary quantity equal to the square root of minus one.;(in metaphysics) the subject or object of self-consciousness; the ego.

origins: late 16th century: from French élégiaque, or via late Latin, from Greek elegeiakos, from elegeia (see elegy).
meaning: relating to or characteristic of an elegy.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a place where bread and cakes are made or sold

origins: late 18th century: Greek.
meaning: praise and honour received for an achievement.

origins: late 16th century: from French généalogique, via medieval Latin from Greek genealogikos, from genealogia (see genealogy).
meaning: relating to the study or tracing of lines of family descent.

origins: from Latin Neapolitanus, from Latin Neapolis ‘Naples’, from Greek neos ‘new’ + polis ‘city’.
meaning: a native or inhabitant of Naples.

origins: late 15th century: from French, or from Latin elegans, elegant-, related to eligere ‘choose, select’ (see elect).
meaning: graceful and stylish in appearance or manner.;(of a scientific theory or solution to a problem) pleasingly ingenious and simple.

origins: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Josiah Gregg (1806–1850). From Mexican Spanish piloncillo from Spanish pilón + -cillo, diminutive suffix
meaning: A type of coarse brown sugar, often moulded into a hard cone or block, produced especially in Mexico.

origins: Old English trog, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch trog and German Trog, also to tree.
meaning: a long, narrow open container for animals to eat or drink out of.;a channel used to convey a liquid.;an elongated region of low barometric pressure.;a point of low activity or achievement.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: engaged to be married

origins: late 15th century: from Latin, neuter of modicus ‘moderate’, from modus ‘measure’.
meaning: a small quantity of a particular thing, especially something desirable or valuable.

origins: Old English haldan, healdan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch houden and German halten ; the noun is partly from Old Norse hald ‘hold, support, custody’.
meaning: grasp, carry, or support with one's hands.;keep or detain (someone).;remain secure, intact, or in position without breaking or giving way.;contain or be capable of containing (a specified amount).;have in one's possession.;keep or reserve for someone.;prevent from going ahead or occurring.;arrange and take part in (a meeting or conversation).

origins: late 18th century: from Latin frons, frond- ‘leaf’.
meaning: the leaf or leaflike part of a palm, fern, or similar plant.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: Approbation is approval of something or agreement to it.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a market town in the Netherlands, just north-east of Rotterdam; population 70,857 (2008).;a flat round cheese with a yellow rind, originally made in the town of Gouda in the Netherlands.

origins: Middle English (as a noun denoting something to sleep on; as a verb in the sense ‘lay something down’): from Old French couche (noun), coucher (verb), from Latin collocare ‘place together’ (see collocate).
meaning: a long upholstered piece of furniture for several people to sit on.

origins: from modern Greek pheta .
meaning: a white salty Greek cheese made from the milk of ewes or goats.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin vitiat- ‘impaired’, from the verb vitiare, from vitium (see vice1).
meaning: spoil or impair the quality or efficiency of.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin.
meaning: an open-roofed entrance hall or central court in an ancient Roman house.;each of the two upper cavities of the heart from which blood is passed to the ventricles. The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the veins of the body, the left atrium oxygenated blood from the pulmonary vein.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of an animal cell) capable of differentiation and so forming a new individual, tissue, organ, etc

origins: late Middle English: perhaps from a variant of Old French chatepelose, literally ‘hairy cat’, influenced by obsolete piller  ‘ravager’. The association with ‘cat’ is found in other languages, e.g. Swiss German Teufelskatz (literally ‘devil's cat’), Lombard gatta (literally ‘cat’). Compare with French chaton, English catkin, which resembles a hairy caterpillar.
meaning: the larva of a butterfly or moth, which has a segmented wormlike body with three pairs of true legs and several pairs of appendages similar to legs.;an articulated steel band passing round the wheels of a vehicle for travel on rough ground.

origins: Middle English: from Old French ransoun (noun), ransouner (verb), from Latin redemptio(n- ) ‘ransoming, releasing’ (see redemption). Early use also occurred in theological contexts expressing ‘deliverance’ and ‘atonement’.
meaning: a sum of money demanded or paid for the release of a captive.

origins: late 19th century: from Greek adiabatos ‘impassable’, from a- ‘not’ + dia ‘through’ + batos ‘passable’ (from bainein ‘go’), + -ic.
meaning: relating to or denoting a process or condition in which heat does not enter or leave the system concerned.

origins: mid 19th century: from Spanish, diminutive of camara ‘chamber’.
meaning: a small group of people, especially a group of advisers to a ruler or politician, with a shared purpose.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French porc espin, from Provençal porc espi(n ), from Latin porcus ‘pig’ + spina ‘thorn’.
meaning: a large rodent with defensive spines or quills on the body and tail.

origins: early 17th century: from Italian, from Latin.
meaning: (especially in continental Europe) a large and luxurious country house in its own grounds.;a large country house of Roman times, having an estate and consisting of farm and residential buildings arranged around a courtyard.

origins: modern Latin, from Latin, literally ‘sacred bough’, in medieval Latin‘vervain’.
meaning: a chiefly American herbaceous plant which bears heads of bright showy flowers, widely cultivated as a garden ornamental.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin ruminat- ‘chewed over’, from the verb ruminari .
meaning: think deeply about something.;(of a ruminant) chew the cud.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a composition used by artisans to fill and conceal holes or cracks in wood or metal

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin humor ‘moisture’, from humere (see humid). The original sense was ‘bodily fluid’ (surviving in aqueous humour and vitreous humour ); it was used specifically for any of the cardinal humours (humour (sense 3 of the noun)), whence ‘mental disposition’ (thought to be caused by the relative proportions of the humours). This led, in the 16th century, to the senses ‘mood’ (humour (sense 2 of the noun)) and ‘whim’, hence to humour someone ‘to indulge a person's whim’. humour (sense 1 of the noun) dates from the late 16th century.
meaning: the quality of being amusing or comic, especially as expressed in literature or speech.;a mood or state of mind.;each of the four chief fluids of the body (blood, phlegm, yellow bile (choler), and black bile (melancholy)) that were thought to determine a person's physical and mental qualities by the relative proportions in which they were present.

origins: mid 17th century: from French peloton ‘platoon’, literally ‘small ball’, diminutive of pelote .
meaning: a subdivision of a company of soldiers, usually forming a tactical unit that is commanded by a subaltern or lieutenant and divided into three sections.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a marine invertebrate of the phylum Echinodermata, such as a starfish, sea urchin, or sea cucumber.

origins: Old English leccan  ‘to water’, of West Germanic origin. The current sense dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: (with reference to a soluble chemical or mineral) drain away from soil, ash, or similar material by the action of percolating liquid, especially rainwater.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the chemical element nickel.

origins: late 19th century: from late Latin, neuter (used as a noun) of cinerarius ‘of ashes’.
meaning: a place where a cinerary urn is kept.

origins: early 21st century: from geo- + cache.
meaning: an activity or pastime in which an item, or a container holding a number of items, is hidden at a particular location for GPS users to find by means of coordinates posted on the internet.

origins: early 16th century: French, later form of rondel (see rondel).
meaning: a poem of ten or thirteen lines with only two rhymes throughout and with the opening words used twice as a refrain.

origins: Unknown
meaning: any of several trees of the genusáShorea

origins: late Middle English: from Old French crisolite, from medieval Latin crisolitus, from Latin chrysolithus, based on Greek khrusos ‘gold’ + lithos ‘stone’.
meaning: a yellowish-green or brownish variety of olivine, used as a gemstone.

origins: Middle English: from Old Norse vǫndr, probably of Germanic origin and related to wend and wind2.
meaning: a long, thin stick or rod.;a handheld electronic device which can be passed over a barcode to read the encoded data.;one of the suits in some tarot packs, corresponding to batons in others.

origins: Middle English: from Old French estomac, stomaque, via Latin from Greek stomakhos ‘gullet’, from stoma ‘mouth’. The early sense of the verb was ‘be offended at, resent’ (early 16th century).
meaning: the internal organ in which the major part of the digestion of food occurs, being (in humans and many mammals) a pear-shaped enlargement of the alimentary canal linking the oesophagus to the small intestine.;an appetite for food or drink.

origins: French, from bavarder ‘to chatter’, from bavard ‘talkative’, from bave ‘drivel’.
meaning: idle gossip.

origins: Algonquian.
meaning: a hut consisting of an oval frame covered with brushwood or grass, formerly used by nomadic peoples in the western and south-western US.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a high official in certain Muslim countries, esp in the former Ottoman Empire. Viziers served in various capacities, such as that of provincial governor or chief minister to the sultan

origins: Late Middle English: via Latin from Greek amugdalē ‘almond’.
meaning: a roughly almond-shaped mass of grey matter inside each cerebral hemisphere, involved with the experiencing of emotions.

origins: mid 18th century (as a noun in the sense ‘a word expressing an attribute’): from French attributif, -ive, from attribut ‘an attribute’, from Latin attribuere ‘add to’ (see attribute).
meaning: (of an adjective or noun) modifying a noun and part of the same noun phrase, in English generally preceding the noun, for example old in the old dog (but not in the dog is old ) and expiry in expiry date.

origins: late 16th century (first used in the Latin form and denoting an actor using mime): from French pantomime or Latin pantomimus, from Greek pantomimos ‘imitator of all’ (see panto-, mime).
meaning: a theatrical entertainment, mainly for children, which involves music, topical jokes, and slapstick comedy and is based on a fairy tale or nursery story, usually produced around Christmas.;a dramatic entertainment, originating in Roman mime, in which performers express meaning through gestures accompanied by music.;an absurdly exaggerated piece of behaviour.

origins: mid 17th century: from Greek pathos ‘suffering’; related to paskhein ‘suffer’ and penthos ‘grief’.
meaning: a quality that evokes pity or sadness.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: either of the plants from which chia seeds are obtained.;the small oval dark or pale brown seed of a flowering plant of the mint family, used in various foods to add fiber and micronutrients.

origins: from Latin fidō ‘I trust’.
meaning: a generic name for a pet dog.

origins: mid 16th century: via late Latin from Greek, from tautologos ‘repeating what has been said’, from tauto- ‘same’ + -logos (see -logy).
meaning: the saying of the same thing twice over in different words, generally considered to be a fault of style (e.g. they arrived one after the other in succession ).

origins: mid 19th century: from Greek Aramaios ‘of Aram’ (the biblical name of Syria) + -ic.
meaning: a branch of the Semitic family of languages, especially the language of Syria used as a lingua franca in the Near East from the 6th century BC. It replaced Hebrew locally as the language of the Jewish people, and though displaced by Arabic in the 7th century AD, it still has about 200,000 speakers in scattered communities.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin sciatica (passio) ‘(affliction) of sciatica’, feminine of sciaticus, from Greek iskhiadikos (see sciatic).
meaning: pain affecting the back, hip, and outer side of the leg, caused by compression of a spinal nerve root in the lower back, often owing to degeneration of an intervertebral disc.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin firmamentum, from firmare ‘fix, settle’.
meaning: the heavens or sky.

origins: early 17th century: Latin, from apparare ‘make ready for’, from ad- ‘towards’ + parare ‘make ready’.
meaning: the technical equipment or machinery needed for a particular activity or purpose.;the complex structure of a particular organization or system.;a collection of notes, variant readings, and other matter accompanying a printed text.

origins: late Middle English (as a noun denoting a member of a religious order who held property): from late Latin proprietarius ‘proprietor’, from proprietas (see property).
meaning: relating to an owner or ownership.;(of a product) marketed under and protected by a registered trade name.

origins: mid 19th century (originally in crinoline (sense 2), early crinolines being made of such material): from French, formed irregularly from Latin crinis ‘hair’ + linum ‘thread’.
meaning: a stiffened or hooped petticoat worn to make a long skirt stand out.;a stiff fabric made of horsehair and cotton or linen thread, used for stiffening petticoats or as a lining.

origins: Middle English (in the theological sense): from Old French, or from late Latin revelatio(n- ), from revelare ‘lay bare’ (see reveal1). Sense 1 dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: a surprising and previously unknown fact that has been disclosed to others.;the divine or supernatural disclosure to humans of something relating to human existence.

origins: late 19th century: imitative.
meaning: the rhythmical sound of deep-toned brass instruments in a band.

origins: Old English thiccet  (see thick, -et1).
meaning: a dense group of bushes or trees.

origins: late Middle English: from Middle Low German, Middle Dutch bricke, brike ; probably reinforced by Old French brique ; of unknown ultimate origin.
meaning: a small rectangular block typically made of fired or sun-dried clay, used in building.;a large and relatively heavy mobile phone, typically an early model with limited functionality.;a generous, helpful, and reliable person.

origins: late 17th century: from medieval Latin registrarius, from registrum (see register).
meaning: an official responsible for keeping a register or official records.;a middle-ranking hospital doctor undergoing training as a specialist.

origins: French, ‘false’.
meaning: made in imitation; artificial.

origins: early 17th century: via late Latin from Greek, from epi ‘upon’ + derma ‘skin’.
meaning: the surface epithelium of the skin, overlying the dermis.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the joining or merging of elements to form one mass or whole

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: one who studies primates

origins: early 17th century: French, from bouter ‘to thrust’.
meaning: a sudden outburst or outbreak.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘seize by legal authority’): from Old French atachier or estachier ‘fasten, fix’, based on an element of Germanic origin related to stake1; compare with attack.
meaning: join or fasten (something) to something else.;attribute importance or value to.;seize (a person or property) by legal authority.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the sport or activity of jumping from an aircraft and performing acrobatic maneuvers in the air during free fall before landing by parachute.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an affluent unincorporated suburb in central Maryland, north of Washington, DC. It is home to the National Institutes of Health; population 55,277 (2000).

origins: 1960s (denoting a traditional folk dance): from Punjabi bhāngrā .
meaning: a type of popular music combining Punjabi folk traditions with Western pop music.

origins: Middle English wæs hæil  ‘be in (good) health!’: from Old Norse ves heill (compare with hail2). The drinking formula wassail (and the reply drinkhail ‘drink good health’) were probably introduced by Danish-speaking inhabitants of England, and then spread, so that by the 12th century the usage was considered by the Normans to be characteristic of Englishmen.
meaning: spiced ale or mulled wine drunk during celebrations for Twelfth Night and Christmas Eve.

origins: mid 16th century: via late Latin from Greek, from aporos ‘impassable’, from a- ‘without’ + poros ‘passage’.
meaning: an irresolvable internal contradiction or logical disjunction in a text, argument, or theory.

origins: from Spanish, from azul ‘blue’.
meaning: a kind of glazed coloured tile traditionally used in Spanish and Portuguese buildings.

origins: early 18th century; earliest use found in John Moyle (d. 1714), naval surgeon. From retrocedent: see -ence
meaning: Movement backwards; recession, regression, or retrogression.

origins: Middle English: from Old French esches, plural of eschec ‘a check’ (see check1).
meaning: a board game of strategic skill for two players, played on a chequered board on which each playing piece is moved according to precise rules. The object is to put the opponent's king under a direct attack from which escape is impossible ( checkmate ).

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of wool, flax, or cotton) having been prepared for manufacture with a comb;(of hair) having been untangled or arranged by the drawing of a comb through it

origins: 1940s: said to have been coined by the nine-year-old nephew of E. Kasner (1878–1955), American mathematician, at Kasner's request.
meaning: equivalent to ten raised to the power of a hundred (10100).

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin servitudo, from servus ‘slave’.
meaning: the state of being a slave or completely subject to someone more powerful.;the subjection of property to an easement.

origins: Middle English: frequentative (verb) or diminutive (noun) of spark1.
meaning: shine brightly with flashes of light.;be vivacious and witty.

origins: mid 16th century: from Portuguese melaço, from late Latin mellacium ‘must’, based on mel ‘honey’.
meaning: thick, dark brown juice obtained from raw sugar during the refining process.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French verveine, from Latin verbena (see verbena).
meaning: a widely distributed herbaceous plant with small blue, white, or purple flowers and a long history of use as a magical and medicinal herb.

origins: Old English los  ‘destruction’, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse los ‘breaking up of the ranks of an army’ and loose; later probably a back-formation from lost, past participle of lose.
meaning: the fact or process of losing something or someone.

origins: Old English wyrsa, wiersa (adjective), wiers (adverb), of Germanic origin; related to war.
meaning: of poorer quality or lower standard; less good or desirable.;more ill or unhappy.

origins: late 17th century: from Latin effervescent- ‘boiling up’, from the verb effervescere (see effervesce).
meaning: (of a liquid) giving off bubbles; fizzy.;vivacious and enthusiastic.

origins: Italian; the form bolognaise is via French.
meaning: relating to Bologna or its people.;denoting a sauce of minced beef, tomato, onion, and herbs, typically served with pasta.

origins: Middle English (in the senses ‘preparedness’ and ‘place in readiness’): from Old French arei (noun), areer (verb), based on Latin ad- ‘towards’ + a Germanic base meaning ‘prepare’.
meaning: display or arrange (things) in a particular way.;dress someone in (the clothes specified).;impanel (a jury).

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a student, typically having the highest academic achievements of the class, who delivers the valedictory at a graduation ceremony.

origins: French, from arrondir ‘make round’.
meaning: a subdivision of a French department, for local government administration.

origins: late Middle English: from French injurieux or Latin injuriosus, from injuria ‘a wrong’ (see injury).
meaning: causing or likely to cause damage or harm.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin venerabilis, from the verb venerari (see venerate).
meaning: accorded a great deal of respect, especially because of age, wisdom, or character.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person employed to look after technical equipment or do practical work in a laboratory

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in an unceasingly intense or harsh way

origins: late 17th century: from late Latin immiscibilis, from in- ‘not’ + miscibilis (see miscible).
meaning: (of liquids) not forming a homogeneous mixture when mixed.

origins: mid 19th century: from French, literally ‘half-cup’.
meaning: a small coffee cup.

origins: 1950s: an arbitrary formation.
meaning: a form of polyester resin used to make heat-resistant plastic films and sheets. It is made by copolymerizing ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: travel or ride on a scooter;a vehicle typically ridden as a recreation, consisting of a footboard mounted on two wheels and a long steering handle, propelled by resting one foot on the footboard and pushing the other against the ground.;a light two-wheeled open motor vehicle on which the driver sits over an enclosed engine with legs together and feet resting on a floorboard.

origins: late Middle English; earliest use found in William Langland (c1325–c1390), poet. From Anglo-Norman ruele, Middle French, French ruelle narrow street, alley, space between the side of a bed and the wall, bedroom used for social or literary receptions, a reception of this kind from rue + -elle
meaning: The passage or space between a bed and the wall; (hence also) the side or part of a bed next to the wall.;In France or French-speaking regions: a small street; a lane, alley.;This space, or the area around the bed generally, where a distinguished person received favoured guests while in bed, especially where (in 17th and 18th century. France) a lady of fashion held morning receptions. So in extended use: an audience or reception of this kind; a (social or literary) gathering in a ruelle.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a trite and unoriginal idea or remark, typically intended to soothe or placate;a compound of bromine with another element or group, especially a salt containing the anion Br⁻ or an organic compound with bromine bonded to an alkyl radical.;a reproduction or piece of typesetting on bromide paper.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin, literally ‘mixed fodder’, from far ‘corn’.
meaning: a confused mixture.

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘cardoon’): from Latin, from Greek kaktos ‘cardoon’.
meaning: a succulent plant with a thick fleshy stem which typically bears spines, lacks leaves, and has brilliantly coloured flowers. Cacti are native to arid regions of the New World and are cultivated elsewhere, especially as pot plants.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: that which can be paidback

origins: Middle English: from Old French moustarde, from Latin mustum ‘must’ (mustard being originally prepared with grape must).
meaning: a hot-tasting yellow or brown paste made from the crushed seeds of certain plants, typically eaten with meat or used as a cooking ingredient.;the yellow-flowered Eurasian plant of the cabbage family whose seeds are used to make mustard.;a brownish yellow colour.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a coming together of two or more people, by chance or arrangement;an assembly of people, especially the members of a society or committee, for discussion or entertainment

origins: 1920s: from Norwegian, literally ‘sloping track’.
meaning: a ski race down a winding course marked out by poles.

origins: late Middle English: from French, or from Latin inviolabilis, from in- ‘not’ + violabilis ‘able to be violated’ (from the verb violare ).
meaning: never to be broken, infringed, or dishonoured.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: to move rapidly; group of ships;to fade away smoothly; glide

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘do an action repeatedly’): from Latin reiterat- ‘gone over again’, from the verb reiterare, from re- ‘again’ + iterare ‘do a second time’.
meaning: say something again or a number of times, typically for emphasis or clarity.

origins: late 16th century: from Portuguese pagode, perhaps based on Persian butkada ‘temple of idols’, influenced by Prakrit bhagodī ‘divine’.
meaning: (in India and East Asia) a Hindu or Buddhist temple, typically in the form of a many-tiered tower.

origins: 1930s: euphemistic alteration of bollocking;Etymology Unknown
meaning: exuberantly lively and amusing;a severe reprimand

origins: late Middle English: from Old French goujon, from Latin gobio(n- ), from gobius ‘goby’.
meaning: a small edible European freshwater fish, often used as bait by anglers.;a credulous or easily fooled person.

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin nox, noct- ‘night’ + ambulare ‘to walk’ + -ist.
meaning: a sleepwalker.

origins: late 19th century: named after Lord Kelvin (see Kelvin, 1st Baron).
meaning: the SI base unit of thermodynamic temperature (equivalent in size to the degree Celsius), first introduced as the unit used in the Kelvin scale.

origins: early 20th century: a local word.
meaning: a large browsing mammal of the giraffe family that lives in the rainforests of northern Democratic Republic of Congo (Zaire). It has a dark chestnut coat with stripes on the hindquarters and upper legs.

origins: Middle English: from Old French universite, from Latin universitas ‘the whole’, in late Latin‘society, guild’, from universus (see universe).
meaning: a high-level educational institution in which students study for degrees and academic research is done.

origins: late 19th century: from literate, on the pattern of illiteracy .
meaning: the ability to read and write.

origins: Middle English: from Old French e(s)meraud, ultimately via Latin from Greek ( s)maragdos, via Prakrit from Semitic (compare with Hebrew bāreqeṯ, from bāraq ‘flash, sparkle’).
meaning: a bright green precious stone consisting of a chromium-rich variety of beryl.;a bright green colour.;a slender-bodied green moth, the colour of which tends to fade as the moth ages.;a hawker dragonfly with a metallic green body.;a small hummingbird with bright metallic green plumage and darker wings and tail, found mainly in the area of the Caribbean and Central America.

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin raucus ‘hoarse’ + -ous.
meaning: making or constituting a disturbingly harsh and loud noise.

origins: late Middle English (as a term in ecclesiastical law): from medieval Latin paenitentiarius, from Latin paenitentia ‘repentance’. The North American usage dates from the early 19th century.
meaning: a prison for people convicted of serious crimes.;(in the Roman Catholic Church) a priest appointed to administer penance.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘surge up, overflow’): from Old French redonder, from Latin redundare ‘surge’, from re(d)- ‘again’ + unda ‘a wave’.
meaning: contribute greatly to (a person's credit or honour).;come back upon; rebound on.

origins: early 20th century: French, from monter ‘to mount’.
meaning: the technique of selecting, editing, and piecing together separate sections of film to form a continuous whole.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French residu, from Latin residuum ‘something remaining’ (see residuum).
meaning: a small amount of something that remains after the main part has gone or been taken or used.

origins: late Middle English: via late Latin from Greek koimētērion ‘dormitory’, from koiman ‘put to sleep’.
meaning: a large burial ground, especially one not in a churchyard.

origins: early 17th century (denoting a poll tax): from Latin, applied to the registration of citizens and property in ancient Rome, usually for taxation, from censere ‘assess’. The current sense dates from the mid 18th century.
meaning: an official count or survey, especially of a population.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin pictura, from pict- ‘painted’ (from the verb pingere ).
meaning: a painting or drawing.;an impression of something formed from a description.;a person or thing resembling another closely.

origins: early 17th century: apparently from obsolete wistly ‘intently’, influenced by wishful.
meaning: having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing.

origins: Middle English: from Old French vyn egre, based on Latin vinum ‘wine’ + acer ‘sour’.
meaning: a sour-tasting liquid containing acetic acid, obtained by fermenting dilute alcoholic liquids, typically wine, cider, or beer, and used as a condiment or for pickling.

origins: Unknown
meaning: A Dreikanter isáa type of ventifact that typically forms in desert or periglacial environmentsádue to the abrasive action of blowing sand

origins: late 16th century (denoting fighting against God): from Greek theomakhia, from theos ‘god’ + -makhia ‘fighting’.
meaning: a war or struggle against God or among or against the gods.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: causing one to feel unsettled

origins: mid 19th century: from the name of The Mistick Krewe of Comus, the first such organization, krewe representing an archaic variant spelling of crew1.
meaning: (in the US) an organization or association that stages a parade or other event for a carnival celebration. Krewes are associated especially with Mardi Gras in New Orleans.

origins: mid 19th century (in an earlier sense). From retino- + -scopy
meaning: A method for determining the refraction of the eye by projecting a beam of light into it and observing the movements of the illuminated area of the retina and the light reflected back through the pupil.

origins: Unknown
meaning: put together with neat proprietyá:áof elegant style

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: high-sounding but with little meaning; inflated

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the process of washing out an organ or wound with a continuous flow of water or medication;the supply of water to land or crops to help growth, typically by means of channels

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin proletarius (from proles ‘offspring’), denoting a person having no wealth in property, who only served the state by producing offspring, + -an.
meaning: relating to the proletariat.

origins: early 17th century: from Mexican Spanish jícama, from Nahuatl xicama .
meaning: the crisp white-fleshed edible tuber of the yam bean, used especially in Mexican cooking.

origins: Unknown
meaning: of, relating to, or characteristic of the English poet John Skelton, his writings, or Skeltonics

origins: mid 16th century: from French casaque ‘long coat’, from Italian casacca ‘riding coat’, probably from Turkic kazak ‘vagabond’. Compare with Cossack.
meaning: a full-length garment worn by certain Christian clergy, members of church choirs, and others having an office or role in a church.

origins: Old English dox  ‘dark, swarthy’ and doxian ‘darken in colour’, of Germanic origin; related to Old High German tusin ‘darkish’; compare with dun1 The noun dates from the early 17th century The change in form from -x to -sk occurred in Middle English.
meaning: the darker stage of twilight.

origins: Middle English (in scrivener (sense 1 of the noun)): shortening of Old French escrivein, from Latin scriba (see scribe). scrivener (sense 2 of the noun) dates from the early 17th century.
meaning: a clerk, scribe, or notary.;a person who invested money at interest for clients and lent funds to those who wanted to raise money on security.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin appropriatus, past participle of appropriare ‘make one's own’, from ad- ‘to’ + proprius ‘own, proper’;Etymology Unknown
meaning: devote (money or assets) to a special purpose;suitable or proper in the circumstances;take (something) for one's own use, typically without the owner's permission

origins: mid 19th century: from French thalassique, from Greek thalassa ‘sea’.
meaning: relating to the sea.

origins: early 16th century (originally Scots and northern English, denoting an earthenware bowl): probably of Scandinavian origin; compare with Norwegian mugge, Swedish mugg ‘pitcher with a handle’.
meaning: a large cup, typically cylindrical with a handle and used without a saucer.;a person's face.;a stupid or gullible person.;a violent criminal or troublemaker.

origins: Unknown
meaning: evanescence or impermanence of existence

origins: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin originat- ‘caused to begin’, from Latin origo, origin- ‘source, origin’.
meaning: have a specified beginning.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the fact of being a member of a group

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an incision in the windpipe made to relieve an obstruction to breathing

origins: 1930s: of unknown origin.
meaning: an unnecessary, wasteful, or fraudulent project.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: used or intended to publicly acknowledge a significant or happy day or event;feeling or expressing happiness and pride

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: composed of globules.;globe-shaped; spherical

origins: late Middle English (describing persons who were equal in power or rank): via Old French from late Latin aequivalent- ‘being of equal worth’, from the verb aequivalere, from aequi- ‘equally’ + valere ‘be worth’.
meaning: equal in value, amount, function, meaning, etc.

origins: mid 17th century. Apparently a back-formation from pillory, or perhaps from inflected forms of pillory
meaning: pillory.

origins: Middle English: from Old French trompette, diminutive of trompe (see trump2). The verb dates from the mid 16th century.
meaning: a brass musical instrument with a flared bell and a bright, penetrating tone. The modern instrument has the tubing looped to form a straight-sided coil, with three valves.;a North American pitcher plant.

origins: late Middle English (as an adjective): from Latin laureatus, from laurea ‘laurel wreath’, from laurus ‘laurel’.
meaning: a person who is honoured with an award for outstanding creative or intellectual achievement.

origins: mid 17th century: from French, from ramifier ‘form branches’ (see ramify).
meaning: a complex or unwelcome consequence of an action or event.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: showing defiance

origins: late 19th century: coined in German from modern Greek enzumos ‘leavened’, from en- ‘within’ + Greek zumē ‘leaven’.
meaning: a substance produced by a living organism which acts as a catalyst to bring about a specific biochemical reaction.

origins: mid 18th century: French, from Latin in odio(n- ), from mihi in odio est ‘it is hateful to me’. Compare with annoy.
meaning: a feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction arising from a lack of occupation or excitement.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘tenure, property held by tenure’): via Old French from medieval Latin tenementum, from tenere ‘to hold’.
meaning: (especially in Scotland or the US) a room or a set of rooms forming a separate residence within a house or block of flats.;a piece of land held by an owner.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the ability to move or be moved freely and easily

origins: late Middle English: from Old French scisme, via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek skhisma ‘cleft’, from skhizein ‘to split’.
meaning: a split or division between strongly opposed sections or parties, caused by differences in opinion or belief.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: cooked in a sauce of lemon, parsley and butter

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or resembling saccades

origins: Old English steorra, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch ster, German Stern, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin stella and Greek astēr .
meaning: a fixed luminous point in the night sky which is a large, remote incandescent body like the sun.;a conventional or stylized representation of a star, typically having five or more points.;a very famous or talented entertainer or sports player.;a planet, constellation, or configuration regarded as influencing a person's fortunes or personality.;used in names of starfishes and similar echinoderms with five or more radiating arms, e.g. cushion star, brittlestar.

origins: mid 16th century (in the senses ‘dither’ and ‘haggle’): of unknown origin.
meaning: avoid (someone or something) by a sudden quick movement.;expose (one area of a print) less than the rest during processing or enlarging.;(of a bell in change-ringing) move one place contrary to the normal sequence, and then back again in the following round.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: If you describe someone or something as soppy, you mean that they are foolishly sentimental.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a woman who is a singer of comic roles in opera

origins: late Middle English: from Old French cocombre, coucombre, from Latin cucumis, cucumer- .
meaning: a long, green-skinned fruit with watery flesh, usually eaten raw in salads or pickled.;the climbing plant of the gourd family that yields cucumbers, native to the Chinese Himalayan region. It is widely cultivated but very rare in the wild.

origins: Old English wæfs, wæps, wæsp, of West Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin vespa ; perhaps related to weave1 (from the weblike form of its nest).
meaning: a social winged insect which has a narrow waist and a sting and is typically yellow with black stripes. It constructs a paper nest from wood pulp and raises the larvae on a diet of insects.;a solitary winged insect with a narrow waist, mostly distantly related to the social wasps and including many parasitic kinds.

origins: early 16th century (in the sense ‘devotion to religious observances’): from Old French piete, from Latin pietas ‘dutifulness’, from pius (see pious).
meaning: the quality of being religious or reverent.

origins: Old English ofspring  (see off, spring).
meaning: a person's child or children.

origins: Unknown
meaning: to provide with or support on gimbals

origins: late Middle English (in the general sense ‘small container’): via French from Latin capsula, diminutive of capsa (see case2).
meaning: a small case or container, especially a round or cylindrical one.;a tough sheath or membrane that encloses an organ or other structure in the body, such as a kidney or a synovial joint.;the foil or plastic covering the cork of a wine bottle.;a dry fruit that releases its seeds by bursting open when ripe, such as a pea pod.;the spore-producing structure of mosses and liverworts, typically borne on a stalk.;(of a piece of writing) shortened but retaining the essence of the original; condensed.

origins: Old English war(e)nung  (see warn, -ing1).
meaning: a statement or event that warns of something or that serves as a cautionary example.

origins: Middle English sclate, sklate, shortening of Old French esclate, feminine synonymous with esclat ‘piece broken off’ (see slat).
meaning: a fine-grained grey, green, or bluish-purple metamorphic rock easily split into smooth, flat plates.;a flat plate of slate formerly used for writing on in schools.;a bluish-grey colour.;a list of candidates for election to a post or office, typically a group sharing a set of political views.;a board showing the identifying details of a take in a film, held in front of the camera at the beginning and end of the take.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to Morocco or its people;a native or inhabitant of Morocco, or a person of Moroccan descent

origins: Latin, plural of geminus ‘twin’. Geminorum is the genitive form of Gemini;Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person born when the sun is in the sign of Gemini.;a northern constellation (the Twins), said to represent the mythological twins Castor and Pollux, whose names are given to its two brightest stars.;used with preceding Greek letter or numeral to designate a star in the Gemini constellation;the third sign of the zodiac, which the sun enters about May 21.;a series of twelve manned orbiting space missions, launched by the US in the 1960s in preparation for the Apollo program.

origins: mid 16th century: modern Latin, from Greek ekkhumōsis ‘escape of blood’, from ekkhumonathai ‘force out blood’.
meaning: a discoloration of the skin resulting from bleeding underneath, typically caused by bruising.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the layer of the earth's atmosphere above the troposphere, extending to about 32 miles (50 km) above the earth's surface (the lower boundary of the mesosphere).

origins: mid 17th century (denoting a heap or an accumulation): from Latin, ‘heap’.
meaning: cloud forming rounded masses heaped on each other above a flat base at fairly low altitude.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a musical instrument with reed pipes that are sounded by the pressure of wind emitted from a bag squeezed by the player's arm. Bagpipes are associated especially with Scotland, but are also used in folk music in Ireland, Northumberland, and France.

origins: late Old English hittan (in the sense ‘come upon, find’), from Old Norse hitta ‘come upon, meet with’, of unknown origin.
meaning: bring one's hand or a tool or weapon into contact with (someone or something) quickly and forcefully.;(of a missile or a person aiming one) strike (a target).;cause harm or distress to.;reach (a particular level, point, or figure).;propel (a ball) with a bat, racket, stick, etc. to score runs or points in a game.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin mediterraneus ‘inland’ (from medius ‘middle’ + terra ‘land’) + -an.
meaning: of or characteristic of the Mediterranean Sea, the countries bordering it, or their inhabitants.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person whose behavior or views do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.;a member of a Protestant church in England that dissents from the established Anglican Church.;of or characterized by behavior or views that do not conform to prevailing ideas or practices.;relating to Nonconformists or their principles and practices.

origins: Unknown
meaning: any of a class (Bdelloidea) ofárotifersáthat reproduce byáparthenogenesisáand are known to only exist as females

origins: Middle English (denoting material for making clothes): shortening of Old French estoffe ‘material, furniture’, estoffer ‘equip, furnish’, from Greek stuphein ‘draw together’.
meaning: matter, material, articles, or activities of a specified or indeterminate kind that are being referred to, indicated, or implied.;the basic constituents or characteristics of something or someone.;woollen fabric, especially as distinct from silk, cotton, and linen.;(in sport) spin given to a ball to make it vary its course.

origins: Persian, from pašm ‘wool’.
meaning: a shawl made from fine-quality goat's wool.

origins: late Middle English: from French, from tenir ‘to hold’, from Latin tenere .
meaning: a projecting piece of wood made for insertion into a mortise in another piece.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action of mooring a boat or ship to the shore or to an anchor

origins: late 18th century: from Dutch ijsberg, from ijs ‘ice’ + berg ‘hill’.
meaning: a large floating mass of ice detached from a glacier or ice sheet and carried out to sea.

origins: early 19th century; earliest use found in Blackwood's Magazine. From omni- + classical Latin legent-, legēns, present participle of legere to read
meaning: Reading everything, familiar with all or a great amount of literature.

origins: Japanese, literally ‘living flowers’, from ikeru ‘keep alive’ + hana ‘flower’.
meaning: the art of Japanese flower arrangement, with formal display according to strict rules.

origins: late Middle English (as a term in astronomy): from Latin retrogradus, from retro ‘backwards’ + gradus ‘step’ (from gradi ‘to walk’).
meaning: directed or moving backwards.;reverting to an earlier and inferior condition.;(of the order of something) reversed; inverse.;(of a metamorphic change) resulting from a decrease in temperature or pressure.

origins: early 20th century: from realty + -or1.
meaning: a person who acts as an agent for the sale and purchase of buildings and land; an estate agent.

origins: mid 18th century: from French persifler ‘to banter’, based on siffler ‘to whistle’.
meaning: light and slightly contemptuous mockery or banter.

origins: late 15th century: from Latin sacrosanctus, from sacro ‘by a sacred rite’ (ablative of sacrum ) + sanctus ‘holy’.
meaning: (especially of a principle, place, or routine) regarded as too important or valuable to be interfered with.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin salivat- ‘(having) produced saliva’, from the verb salivare, from saliva (see saliva).
meaning: secrete saliva, especially in anticipation of food.;display great relish at the sight or prospect of something.

origins: mid 17th century (denoting a French inn): from Old French, literally ‘wooden structure’, via Middle Dutch from Old Picard camberet ‘little room’. Current senses date from the early 20th century.
meaning: entertainment held in a nightclub or restaurant while the audience eat or drink at tables.

origins: late Middle English deynseyn, via Anglo-Norman French from Old French deinz ‘within’ (from Latin de ‘from’ + intus ‘within’) + -ein (from Latin -aneus ‘-aneous’). The change in the form of the word was due to association with citizen.
meaning: a person, animal, or plant that lives or is found in a particular place.

origins: 1920s: modern Latin, from Greek homoios ‘like’ + -stasis.
meaning: the tendency towards a relatively stable equilibrium between interdependent elements, especially as maintained by physiological processes.

origins: early 20th century: from French trichotillomanie, from Greek thrix, trikhos ‘hair’ + tillein ‘pull out (hair)’ + -mania.
meaning: a compulsive desire to pull out one's hair.

origins: Middle English: from Old French herbergere, from herbergier ‘provide lodging for’, from herberge ‘lodging’, from Old Saxon heriberga ‘shelter for an army, lodging’ (from heri ‘army’ + a Germanic base meaning ‘fortified place’), related to harbour. The term originally denoted a person who provided lodging, later one who went ahead to find lodgings for an army or for a nobleman and his retinue, hence, a herald (mid 16th century).
meaning: a person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another.

origins: Japanese.
meaning: a variety of rich, naturally fermented soy sauce.

origins: Middle English: from Old French letues, laitues, plural of laitue, from Latin lactuca, from lac, lact- ‘milk’ (because of its milky juice).
meaning: a cultivated plant of the daisy family, with edible leaves that are eaten in salads.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘strike forcibly against’): probably symbolic of forceful movement and related to Swedish and Danish daska .
meaning: run or travel somewhere in a great hurry.;strike or fling (something) somewhere with great force, especially so as to have a destructive effect; hurl.

origins: mid 19th century: from Hawaiian.
meaning: basaltic lava forming smooth undulating or ropy masses.

origins: late 19th century; earliest use found in Liberal. From Sino- + -phile;Etymology Unknown
meaning: Friendly to, or having great admiration for, China or Chinese people, culture, etc.;A supporter or admirer of China or of Chinese people, culture, etc.

origins: early 16th century: from late Latin interrogativus, from Latin interrogare (see interrogate).
meaning: having the force of a question.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a vast semiarid region of North Africa, to the south of the Sahara, that forms a transitional zone at the south of the desert and comprises the northern part of the region known as Sudan.

origins: mid 17th century: from French repartie ‘replied promptly’, feminine past participle of repartir, from re- ‘again’ + partir ‘set off’.
meaning: conversation or speech characterized by quick, witty comments or replies.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a Chinese sculling oar with a fixed fulcrum

origins: late Middle English: from Latin furunculus, literally ‘petty thief’, also ‘knob on a vine’ (regarded as stealing the sap), from fur ‘thief’.
meaning: technical term for boil2.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘clamorous, vociferous’): from Latin obstreperus (from obstrepere, from ob- ‘against’ + strepere ‘make a noise’) + -ous.
meaning: noisy and difficult to control.

origins: Old English strēaw, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stroo and German Stroh, also to strew.
meaning: dried stalks of grain, used especially as fodder or as material for thatching, packing, or weaving.;a thin hollow tube of paper or plastic for sucking drink from a glass or bottle.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: not open to discussion or modification

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘equality of value or standing’): from Latin, ‘equal’, also ‘equality’. The golf term dates from the late 19th century.
meaning: the number of strokes a first-class player should normally require for a particular hole or course.;the face value of a share or other security, as distinct from its market value.

origins: late 16th century: Italian, from Latin, ‘pearl barley’ (a sense of polenta in Old English).
meaning: maize flour as used in Italian cooking; cornmeal.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin crudelis, related to crudus (see crude).
meaning: wilfully causing pain or suffering to others, or feeling no concern about it.

origins: late 17th century: from earlier botanic (from French botanique, based on Greek botanikos, from botanē ‘plant’) + -y3.
meaning: the scientific study of the physiology, structure, genetics, ecology, distribution, classification, and economic importance of plants.

origins: late 17th century: from medieval Latin castellatus, from Latin castellum (see castle).
meaning: having battlements.

origins: early 18th century: from Kimbundu, perhaps via Portuguese.
meaning: a deep-toned xylophone of African origin.

origins: late 19th century (originally US): from Fédora, the title of a drama (1882) written by the French dramatist Victorien Sardou (1831–1908).
meaning: a low, soft felt hat with a curled brim and the crown creased lengthways.

origins: mid 16th century: perhaps an alteration of dialect tusk  ‘tuft’, of unknown origin.
meaning: a small area of grass that is thicker or longer than the grass growing around it.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, accusative of darz, dars, from a West Germanic word meaning ‘spear, lance’.
meaning: move or run somewhere suddenly or rapidly.;shoot (an animal) with a dart, typically in order to administer a drug.

origins: late 15th century: from Old French arrumage, from arrumer ‘stow (in a hold)’, from Middle Dutch ruim ‘room’. In early use the word referred to the arranging of items such as casks in the hold of a ship, giving rise (early 17th century) to the verb sense ‘make a search of (a vessel’).
meaning: search unsystematically and untidily through something.

origins: Middle English patron  ‘something serving as a model’, from Old French (see patron). The change in sense is from the idea of a patron giving an example to be copied. Metathesis in the second syllable occurred in the 16th century. By 1700 patron ceased to be used of things, and the two forms became differentiated in sense.
meaning: a repeated decorative design.;a model or design used as a guide in needlework and other crafts.;an example for others to follow.

origins: mid 16th century (in meiosis (sense 2)): modern Latin, from Greek meiōsis, from meioun ‘lessen’, from meiōn ‘less’. meiosis (sense 1) dates from the early 20th century.
meaning: a type of cell division that results in four daughter cells each with half the number of chromosomes of the parent cell, as in the production of gametes and plant spores.;another term for litotes.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French frontiere, based on Latin frons, front- ‘front’.
meaning: a line or border separating two countries.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the branch of knowledge that deals with interpretation, especially of the Bible or literary texts.

origins: late 18th century: diminutive of lory, on the pattern of parakeet .
meaning: a small bird of the lory family, found chiefly in New Guinea.

origins: mid 19th century: from Maori.
meaning: a flightless New Zealand bird with hairlike feathers, having a long downcurved bill with sensitive nostrils at the tip.;a New Zealander.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a vessel) not or no longer attached to a mooring

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a tendency to be too ready to believe that something is real or true

origins: mid 17th century: Latin, from ad ‘to’ + gnomen, nomen ‘name’.
meaning: a fourth name occasionally given as an honour to an ancient Roman citizen.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the name proposed in the 1840s by Mormon settlers for what became Utah.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an artist or writer who is an exponent of the avant-garde movement in art and literature which sought to release the creative potential of the unconscious mind;relating to the avant-garde movement in art and literature which sought to release the creative potential of the unconscious mind or its exponents

origins: early 17th century: from Latin unanimus (from unus ‘one’ + animus ‘mind’) + -ous.
meaning: (of two or more people) fully in agreement.

origins: late Middle English (originally denoting a book containing the appointed times of daily prayers): from Old French jurnal, from late Latin diurnalis (see diurnal).
meaning: a newspaper or magazine that deals with a particular subject or professional activity.;a daily record of news and events of a personal nature; a diary.;the part of a shaft or axle that rests on bearings.

origins: mid 16th century (denoting the withdrawal of plebeians from ancient Rome in order to compel the patricians to redress their grievances): from French sécession or Latin secessio(n- ), from secedere ‘go apart’ (see secede).
meaning: the action of withdrawing formally from membership of a federation or body, especially a political state.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a hairstyle in which the hair is washed but not combed and twisted while wet into tight braids or ringlets hanging down on all sides

origins: Middle English (as a verb): from Old French amunter, from amont ‘upward’, literally ‘uphill’, from Latin ad montem . The noun use dates from the early 18th century.
meaning: a quantity of something, especially the total of a thing or things in number, size, value, or extent.

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘adequate sea room’): probably from a nautical use of bear1 + -th2.
meaning: a ship's allotted place at a wharf or dock.;a fixed bunk on a ship, train, or other means of transport.;(often in a sporting context) a position in an organization or event.

origins: late Middle English: from French, from Latin adolescentia, from adolescere ‘grow to maturity’ (see adolescent).
meaning: the period following the onset of puberty during which a young person develops from a child into an adult.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French epitaphe, via Latin from Greek epitaphion ‘funeral oration’, neuter of ephitaphios ‘over or at a tomb’, from epi ‘upon’ + taphos ‘tomb’.
meaning: a phrase or form of words written in memory of a person who has died, especially as an inscription on a tombstone.

origins: Japanese.
meaning: oriental rape of a variety with finely cut leaves that are eaten in salads.

origins: mid 18th century: French, from s'emboucher ‘discharge itself by the mouth’, from emboucher ‘put in or to the mouth’, from em- ‘into’ + bouche ‘mouth’.
meaning: the way in which a player applies their mouth to the mouthpiece of a brass or wind instrument, especially as it affects the production of the sound.;the mouth of a river or valley.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin levitas, from levis ‘light’.
meaning: the treatment of a serious matter with humour or lack of due respect.

origins: French, literally ‘revenge’
meaning: a policy or movement aimed at achieving the return of a nation's lost territory (frequently with reference to France's desire to regain Alsace–Lorraine after its annexation in the Franco-Prussian War)

origins: late Middle English: from Old French contumelieus, from Latin contumeliosus, from contumelia ‘abuse, insult’ (see contumely).
meaning: (of behaviour) scornful and insulting; insolent.

origins: 1960s; earliest use found in The Times. From Brigadoon, the name of a fictional Scottish Highland village which materializes for only one day every hundred years, in the 1947 musical of that name by A. J. Lerner and F. Loewe, which was the basis of a popular film adaptation of 1954
meaning: In allusive use. A place, person, or phenomenon likened in some way to Brigadoon, especially on account of its mythical or idealized nature, its (romanticized) Scottishness, or its rare, fleeting appearance or occurrence.

origins: Unknown
meaning: to moisten (foods, especially meat) at intervals with melted butter, fat, pan drippings, or other liquids especially during the cooking process to prevent drying and to add flavor

origins: mid 16th century: from Old French douagiere, from douage ‘dower’, from douer ‘endow’, from Latin dotare ‘endow’ (see dower).
meaning: a widow with a title or property derived from her late husband.

origins: late Middle English (denoting oratorical or literary style): from Latin elocutio(n- ), from eloqui ‘speak out’ (see eloquence).
meaning: the skill of clear and expressive speech, especially of distinct pronunciation and articulation.

origins: early 17th century: from Greek (see Exodus).
meaning: a mass departure of people.

origins: early 18th century: from Latin moribundus, from mori ‘to die’.
meaning: (of a person) at the point of death.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a flash or sparkle of light

origins: early 17th century: from tatters or tattered: ending unexplained.
meaning: tattered or dilapidated.

origins: Middle English: from Old French or Latin, from Greek ēkhō, related to ēkhē ‘a sound’.
meaning: (of a sound) be repeated or reverberate after the original sound has stopped.;(of an object or event) be reminiscent of or have shared characteristics with.;send a copy of (an input signal or character) back to its source or to a screen for display.;(of a defender) play a higher card followed by a lower one in the same suit, as a signal to request one's partner to lead that suit.

origins: Unknown
meaning: liver sausage

origins: Unknown
meaning: a flat roof or platform on the top of a house or other building

origins: Sanskrit, from a ‘non-, without’ + hiṃsā ‘violence’.
meaning: (in the Hindu, Buddhist, and Jainist tradition) respect for all living things and avoidance of violence towards others.

origins: Unknown
meaning: divination by means of a mirror

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin exstinguere, from ex- ‘out’ + stinguere ‘quench’. Compare with distinguish.
meaning: cause (a fire or light) to cease to burn or shine.

origins: late 16th century: from Spanish, diminutive of armado ‘armed man’, from Latin armatus, past participle of armare ‘to arm’.
meaning: a nocturnal insectivorous mammal that has large claws for digging and a body covered in bony plates. Armadillos are native to Central and South America and one kind is spreading into the southern US.

origins: from Pashto afghānī .
meaning: a native or inhabitant of Afghanistan, or a person of Afghan descent.;another term for Pashto.;a woollen blanket or shawl, typically one knitted or crocheted in strips or squares.;short for Afghan coat or Afghan hound.

origins: early 20th century: from French, from empenner ‘to feather an arrow’, from em- ‘in’ + penne ‘a feather’ (from Latin penna ).
meaning: an arrangement of stabilizing surfaces at the tail of an aircraft.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the temporary disappearance of one celestial body as it moves out of sight behind another body

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin angustia ‘tightness’, (plural) ‘straits, distress’, from angustus ‘narrow’.
meaning: severe mental or physical pain or suffering.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of the eyes) unfocused or filmy from sleep or tiredness

origins: late 19th century: apparently named after J. T. Gurney of Boston, Massachusetts, patentee of a new cab design in 1883.
meaning: a wheeled stretcher used for transporting hospital patients.

origins: mid 16th century: via Latin from Greek tropos ‘turn, way, trope’, from trepein ‘to turn’.
meaning: a figurative or metaphorical use of a word or expression.

origins: late 17th century (originally as a fencing term, denoting a thrust made at an inopportune moment): French, originally ‘motion out of time’, from contre- ‘against’ + temps ‘time’.
meaning: a minor dispute or disagreement.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin debilitat- ‘weakened’, from the verb debilitare, from debilitas (see debility).
meaning: make (someone) very weak and infirm.

origins: mid 19th century: from Tanger (former name of Tangier) + -ine1. The fruit, exported from Tangier, was originally called the tangerine orange .
meaning: a small citrus fruit with a loose skin, especially one of a variety with deep orange-red skin.;the citrus tree which bears the tangerine.

origins: Mexican Spanish, literally ‘little pieces of meat’.
meaning: (in Mexican cooking) braised or roasted pork served shredded in small pieces, often as a filling in tacos, burritos, etc.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a plant) growing from a bulb;fat, round, or bulging

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a rhythmic manner;in a way that relates to rhythm

origins: late Middle English: from Old French onereus, from Latin onerosus, from onus, oner- ‘burden’.
meaning: (of a task or responsibility) involving a great deal of effort, trouble, or difficulty.

origins: modern Latin, named after Sir T. Stamford Raffles (see Raffles, Sir Stamford).
meaning: a parasitic plant which lacks chlorophyll and bears a single very large flower which smells of carrion, native to Malaysia and Indonesia.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin gibbosus, from Latin gibbus ‘hump’.
meaning: (of the moon) having the illuminated part greater than a semicircle and less than a circle.

origins: late Middle English tenetz, tenes  ‘real tennis’, apparently from Old French tenez ‘take, receive’ (called by the server to an opponent), imperative of tenir .
meaning: a game in which two or four players strike a ball with rackets over a net stretched across a court. The usual form (originally called lawn tennis ) is played with a felt-covered hollow rubber ball on a grass, clay, or artificial surface.

origins: Middle English: from Old French gobelin, possibly related to German Kobold (see kobold) or to Greek kobalos ‘mischievous goblin’. In medieval Latin Gobelinus occurs as the name of a mischievous spirit, said to haunt Évreux in northern France in the 12th century.
meaning: (in folklore and fantasy fiction) a mischievous, ugly creature resembling a dwarf.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin antiquarius (see antiquary).
meaning: relating to or dealing in antiques or rare books.;relating to the study of antiquities.

origins: late 19th century: from Wiradhuri gugubarra .
meaning: a very large Australasian kingfisher that feeds on terrestrial prey such as reptiles and birds.

origins: Old English beginnan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German beginnen .
meaning: perform or undergo the first part of (an action or activity).;not have any chance or likelihood of doing a specified thing.

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin pugil ‘boxer’ + -ist.
meaning: a boxer, especially a professional one.

origins: 1980s: from SABR, acronym from S  ociety for A  merican B  aseball R  esearch, + metrics.
meaning: the application of statistical analysis to baseball records, especially in order to evaluate and compare the performance of individual players.

origins: early 20th century (originally US, as a trade name): from escalade ‘climb a wall by ladder’ (from escalade), on the pattern of elevator .
meaning: a moving staircase consisting of an endlessly circulating belt of steps driven by a motor, which conveys people between the floors of a public building.

origins: mid 17th century: based on Arabic ṭilsam, apparently from an alteration of late Greek telesma ‘completion, religious rite’, from telein ‘complete, perform a rite’, from telos ‘result, end’.
meaning: an object, typically an inscribed ring or stone, that is thought to have magic powers and to bring good luck.

origins: early 17th century (denoting a century): from Latin centenarius ‘containing a hundred’, based on Latin centum ‘a hundred’.
meaning: the hundredth anniversary of a significant event.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the large plant of the nightshade family that bears the eggplant fruit.;the purple egg-shaped fruit of a tropical Old World plant, which is eaten as a vegetable.

origins: Middle English: from Old French cucu, imitative of its call.
meaning: a long-tailed, medium-sized bird, typically with a grey or brown back and barred or pale underparts. Many cuckoos lay their eggs in the nests of small songbirds.;a mad person.

origins: late 18th century (originally Bob o'Lincoln, Bob Lincoln ): imitative of its call.
meaning: a North American songbird of the American blackbird family, with a bill resembling that of a finch. The male has black, buff, and white plumage.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a process for altering tone values, removing distracting parts, and shifting emphasis in monochrome photographic prints by the use of oil paints

origins: late 16th century: from Turkish kahveh, from Arabic qahwa, probably via Dutch koffie .
meaning: a hot drink made from the roasted and ground seeds (coffee beans) of a tropical shrub.;the shrub which yields coffee seeds, native to the Old World tropics.

origins: Middle English (in trespass (sense 2 of the verb)): from Old French trespasser ‘pass over, trespass’, trespas ‘passing across’, from medieval Latin transpassare (see trans-, pass1).
meaning: enter someone's land or property without permission.;commit an offence against (a person or a set of rules).

origins: mid 18th century: modern Latin, from Greek ekzema, from ekzein ‘boil over, break out’, from ek- ‘out’ + zein ‘boil’.
meaning: a medical condition in which patches of skin become rough and inflamed with blisters which cause itching and bleeding.

origins: early 19th century: from French millionnaire, from million (see million).
meaning: a person whose assets are worth one million pounds or dollars or more.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French train (masculine), traine (feminine), from trahiner (verb), from Latin trahere ‘pull, draw’. Early noun senses were ‘trailing part of a robe’ and ‘retinue’; the latter gave rise to ‘line of travelling people or vehicles’, later ‘a connected series of things’. The early verb sense ‘cause a plant to grow in a desired shape’ was the basis of the sense ‘instruct’.
meaning: teach (a person or animal) a particular skill or type of behaviour through practice and instruction over a period of time.;point or aim something, typically a gun or camera, at.;go by train.;entice (someone).

origins: Middle English: from Old French bescuit, based on Latin bis ‘twice’ + coctus, past participle of coquere ‘to cook’ (so named because originally biscuits were cooked in a twofold process: first baked and then dried out in a slow oven so that they would keep).
meaning: a small baked unleavened cake, typically crisp, flat, and sweet.;porcelain or other pottery which has been fired but not glazed.;a light brown colour.;a small flat piece of wood used to join two larger pieces of wood together, fitting into slots in each.

origins: Middle English: from Old French criquet, from criquer ‘to crackle’, of imitative origin.
meaning: an insect related to the grasshoppers but with shorter legs. The male produces a characteristic musical chirping sound.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘mournful’, also ‘pitiable, regrettable’): from Old French, or from Latin lamentabilis, from the verb lamentari (see lament).
meaning: (of circumstances or conditions) very bad; deplorable.;full of or expressing sorrow or grief.

origins: 1990s: blend of net1 and etiquette.
meaning: the correct or acceptable way of using the internet.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin inglorius (from in- (expressing negation) + gloria ‘glory’) + -ous.
meaning: (of an action or situation) causing shame or a loss of honour.;not famous or renowned.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin temeritas, from temere ‘rashly’.
meaning: excessive confidence or boldness; audacity.

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘bring together again’): from French rallier, from re- ‘again’ + allier ‘to ally’.
meaning: (of troops) come together again in order to continue fighting after a defeat or dispersion.;recover or cause to recover in health, spirits, or poise.;drive in a rally.

origins: early 18th century: from French, or from modern Latin armistitium, from arma ‘arms’ (see arm2) + -stitium ‘stoppage’.
meaning: an agreement made by opposing sides in a war to stop fighting for a certain time; a truce.

origins: mid 18th century: imitative of the call of Pipilo erythrophthalmus .
meaning: a North American songbird of the bunting family, typically with brownish plumage but sometimes black and rufous.

origins: mid 19th century: from Victoria + -an;Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to the reign of Queen Victoria;a person from the Australian state of Victoria;relating to the Australian state of Victoria;a person who lived during the Victorian period

origins: Old English fæger  ‘pleasing, attractive’, of Germanic origin; related to Old High German fagar .
meaning: treating people equally without favouritism or discrimination.;(of hair or complexion) light; blonde.;considerable though not outstanding in size or amount.;(of weather) fine and dry.;beautiful.

origins: from Hindi mahārājā, from Sanskrit mahā ‘great’ + rājan ‘raja, king’.
meaning: an Indian prince.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French corosif, -ive, from medieval Latin corrosivus, from Latin corros- ‘gnawed through’, from the verb corrodere (see corrode).
meaning: tending to cause corrosion.

origins: early 18th century: from French, from Italian mezzanino, diminutive of mezzano ‘middle’, from Latin medianus ‘median’.
meaning: a low storey between two others in a building, typically between the ground and first floors.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: dactylic verse.;of or using dactyls

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin constrict- ‘bound tightly together’, from the verb constringere (see constrain).
meaning: make narrower, especially by encircling pressure.

origins: Middle English: a variant of travail, and originally in the same sense.
meaning: go from one place to another, typically over a distance of some length.;(of an object or radiation) move, typically in a constant or predictable way.;take more than the allowed number of steps (typically two) while holding the ball without dribbling it.

origins: Japanese, from teppan ‘steel plate’ + yaki ‘to fry, grill, sear’.
meaning: a Japanese dish of meat, fish, or both, fried with vegetables on a hot steel plate forming the centre of the table.

origins: early 18th century: from obsolete French reconnoître, from Latin recognoscere ‘know again’ (see recognize).
meaning: make a military observation of (a region).

origins: early 19th century: formed irregularly from Greek mesos ‘middle’ + -ial.
meaning: relating to or directed towards the middle line of a body.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a large birdcage

origins: late 16th century: from French, from Italian mostaccio, from Greek mustax, mustak- .
meaning: a strip of hair left to grow above the upper lip.

origins: mid 16th century (originally in nautical use denoting a small hillock on the coast): of unknown origin.
meaning: a hillock or knoll.

origins: mid 19th century: from Greek rheos ‘stream’ + -stat.
meaning: an electrical instrument used to control a current by varying the resistance.

origins: mid 16th century: via late Latin from Greek, from epentithenai ‘insert’, from epi ‘in addition’ + en- ‘within’ + tithenai ‘to place’.
meaning: the insertion of a sound or letter within a word, e.g. the b in thimble.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin capillaris, from capillus ‘hair’, influenced by Old French capillaire .
meaning: any of the fine branching blood vessels that form a network between the arterioles and venules.;a tube that has an internal diameter of hairlike thinness.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: vehement or impassioned in expression

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French reprisaille, from medieval Latin reprisalia (neuter plural), based on Latin repraehens- ‘seized’, from the verb repraehendere (see reprehend). The current sense dates from the early 18th century.
meaning: an act of retaliation.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: rough and bad-mannered; coarse

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the quality of being strident.

origins: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Quarterly Journal of Microscopical Science. From post-classical Latin limicola + -ous, originally after scientific Latin Limicolae
meaning: Mud-loving, mud-dwelling; inhabiting or frequenting mud or the shoreline; specifically designating a limicoline bird or worm. Compare limicole, limicoline.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a substance which can be made to explode, especially any of those used in bombs or shells;able or likely to shatter violently or burst apart, as when a bomb explodes

origins: mid 16th century: via late Latin from Greek kakhexia, from kakos ‘bad’ + hexis ‘habit’.
meaning: weakness and wasting of the body due to severe chronic illness.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin honorificus, from honor ‘honour’.
meaning: given as a mark of respect but having few or no duties.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: former;formerly

origins: Unknown
meaning: a rare mineral áconsisting essentially of a sodium calcium zirconium silicate containing also fluorine and occurring as pale yellow tabular triclinic crystals.

origins: late Old English hwearf, of Germanic origin.
meaning: a level quayside area to which a ship may be moored to load and unload.

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘expulsion’): from medieval Latin propulsio(n-), from Latin propellere ‘drive before (oneself)’.
meaning: the action of driving or pushing forwards.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: one who studies earthquakes
