origins: early 16th century; earliest use found in John Irland (c1440–1495), theologian. From post-classical Latin obedientialis, adjective and noun from classical Latin oboedientia + -ālis
meaning: Of, relating to, or characterized by obedience, especially to God or the Church.;Of an obligation: arising by operation of law rather than out of a contract.

origins: Old English lǣst, lǣsest, of Germanic origin; related to less.
meaning: smallest in amount, extent, or significance.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a small or young lamb.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: one who pilfers; plunderer; pirate

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin exiguus ‘scanty’ (from exigere ‘weigh exactly’) + -ous.
meaning: very small in size or amount.

origins: late Middle English: from French tranquille or Latin tranquillus .
meaning: free from disturbance; calm.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘become united’): alteration (probably influenced by the past participle) of well2 in the obsolete sense ‘melt or weld heated metal’.
meaning: join together (metal parts) by heating the surfaces to the point of melting with a blowpipe, electric arc, or other means, and uniting them by pressing, hammering, etc.;cause to combine and form a harmonious or effective whole.

origins: 1940s: from Greek, literally ‘ash, ashes’.
meaning: rock fragments and particles ejected by a volcanic eruption.

origins: early 18th century: from French, earlier denoting an association of tenants, based on Middle Low German kote ‘cote’.
meaning: a small group of people with shared interests or tastes, especially one that is exclusive of other people.

origins: late Middle English tortu, tortuce : from Old French tortue and Spanish tortuga, both from medieval Latin tortuca, of uncertain origin. The current spelling dates from the mid 16th century.
meaning: a slow-moving typically herbivorous land reptile of warm climates, enclosed in a scaly or leathery domed shell into which it can retract its head and thick legs.;another term for testudo.

origins: late 16th century (denoting woollen worsted fabric made in Jersey): from Jersey.
meaning: a knitted garment with long sleeves, worn over the upper body.;an animal of a breed of light brown dairy cattle from Jersey.

origins: Middle English: from Old French espaigneul ‘Spanish (dog)’, from Latin Hispaniolus ‘Spanish’.
meaning: a dog of a breed with a long silky coat and drooping ears.

origins: mid 16th century (denoting a figure of speech): from Latin schema, from Greek (see schema). An early sense was ‘diagram of the position of celestial objects’, giving rise to ‘diagram, outline’, whence the current senses. The unfavourable notion ‘plot’ arose in the mid 18th century.
meaning: a large-scale systematic plan or arrangement for attaining a particular object or putting a particular idea into effect.;an estate of social housing.

origins: Middle English (also in the sense ‘accessory’): from Old French ournement, from Latin ornamentum ‘equipment, ornament’, from ornare ‘adorn’. The verb dates from the early 18th century;Etymology Unknown
meaning: a thing used to make something look more attractive but usually having no practical purpose, especially a small object such as a figurine.;make (something) look more attractive by adding decorative items

origins: mid 17th century: via late Latin from Greek agōnistikos, from agōnistēs ‘contestant’ (see agonist).
meaning: polemical; combative.;relating to or acting as an agonist.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a hiding place, especially one used by someone who has broken the law

origins: Middle English: from an Old Northern French variant of Old French chenil, from Latin canis ‘dog’.
meaning: a small shelter for a dog.;a pack of dogs.

origins: Middle English: from Old French rescoure from Latin re- (expressing intensive force) + excutere ‘shake out, discard’.
meaning: save (someone) from a dangerous or difficult situation.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French obscur, from Latin obscurus ‘dark’, from an Indo-European root meaning ‘cover’.
meaning: not discovered or known about; uncertain.;not clearly expressed or easily understood.

origins: late 17th century: from Latin longaevus, from longus ‘long’ + aevum ‘age’.
meaning: living a long time.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: having straight parallel sides and a circular or oval cross-section; in the shape or form of a cylinder

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a tall, reedlike marsh plant with a dark brown, velvety cylindrical head of numerous tiny flowers.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin salubris (from salus ‘health’) + -ous.
meaning: health-giving; healthy.

origins: early 16th century: from Latin resuscitat- ‘raised again’, from the verb resuscitare, from re- ‘back’ + suscitare ‘raise’.
meaning: revive (someone) from unconsciousness or apparent death.

origins: late Middle English (in umbrage (sense 2)): from Old French, from Latin umbra ‘shadow’. An early sense was ‘shadowy outline’, giving rise to ‘ground for suspicion’, whence the current notion of ‘offence’.
meaning: offence or annoyance.;shade or shadow, especially as cast by trees.

origins: Yiddish, literally ‘ball’.
meaning: (in Jewish cooking) a kind of savoury pudding of potatoes or other vegetables.;a spoilt and materialistic young woman, typically Jewish, with a distinctive nasal accent.

origins: early 19th century: from French ottomane, feminine of ottoman ‘Ottoman’.
meaning: a low upholstered seat without a back or arms that typically serves also as a box, with the seat hinged to form a lid.;a heavy ribbed fabric made from silk and either cotton or wool.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from medieval Latin trepalium ‘instrument of torture’, from Latin tres ‘three’ + palus ‘stake’.
meaning: engage in painful or laborious effort.

origins: mid 16th century: from French, from Latin astringent- ‘pulling tight’, from the verb astringere, from ad- ‘towards’ + stringere ‘bind, pull tight’.
meaning: causing the contraction of skin cells and other body tissues.;(of taste or smell) slightly acidic or bitter.;sharp or severe in manner or style.

origins: Greek, from diaspeirein ‘disperse’, from dia ‘across’ + speirein ‘scatter’. The term originated in the Septuagint (Deuteronomy 28:25) in the phrase esē diaspora en pasais basileias tēs gēs ‘thou shalt be a dispersion in all kingdoms of the earth’.
meaning: the dispersion of the Jewish people beyond Israel.

origins: early 20th century: the first element from the name of A. B. Dräger (1870–1928), German inventor of a type of breathing apparatus.
meaning: a member of a crew trained for underground rescue work.

origins: early 16th century: alteration of gambade (see gambado1), via French from Italian gambata ‘trip up’, from gamba ‘leg’.
meaning: run or jump about playfully.

origins: 1960s: from Greek kleptēs ‘thief’ + -crat.
meaning: a ruler who uses their power to steal their country's resources.

origins: late Middle English (in the geometrical sense): via Latin from Greek puramis, puramid-, of unknown ultimate origin.
meaning: a monumental structure with a square or triangular base and sloping sides that meet in a point at the top, especially one built of stone as a royal tomb in ancient Egypt.;an object, shape, or arrangement in the form of a pyramid.;a system of financial growth achieved by a small initial investment, with subsequent investments being funded by using unrealized profits as collateral.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: very enthusiastically or passionately

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin arrogant- ‘claiming for oneself’, from the verb arrogare (see arrogate).
meaning: having or revealing an exaggerated sense of one's own importance or abilities.

origins: mid 19th century: from propionic acid + -ane2.
meaning: a flammable hydrocarbon gas of the alkane series, present in natural gas and used as bottled fuel.

origins: Unknown
meaning: an uneven yarn of three plies one of which forms loops at intervals that is made in various weights of the principal clothing fibers

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: inflammation of the cornea of the eye.

origins: Old English burg, burh  ‘fortress, citadel’, later ‘fortified town’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch burg and German Burg . Compare with burgh.
meaning: a town or district which is an administrative unit.

origins: Middle English: from Old French parchemin, from a blend of late Latin pergamina ‘writing material from Pergamum’ and Parthica pellis ‘Parthian skin’ (a kind of scarlet leather).
meaning: a stiff, flat, thin material made from the prepared skin of an animal, usually a sheep or goat, and used as a durable writing surface in ancient and medieval times.

origins: Old English sēothan  ‘make or keep boiling’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zieden .
meaning: (of a liquid) boil or be turbulent as if boiling.;(of a person) be filled with intense but unexpressed anger.;(of a place) be crowded with people or things moving about in a rapid or hectic way.

origins: Unknown
meaning: to moisten (foods, especially meat) at intervals with melted butter, fat, pan drippings, or other liquids especially during the cooking process to prevent drying and to add flavor

origins: Italian, plural of vermicello, diminutive of verme ‘worm’, from Latin vermis .
meaning: pasta in the form of long slender threads.;shreds of chocolate used to decorate cakes or other sweet foods.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin illustris ‘clear, bright’ + -ous.
meaning: well known, respected, and admired for past achievements.

origins: late Middle English (denoting each of ten parts of a literary work): via Old French and late Latin from Greek deka ‘ten’. decade (sense 1) dates from the early 17th century.
meaning: a period of ten years.;each of the five divisions of each chapter of the rosary.;a range of electrical resistances, frequencies, or other quantities spanning from one to ten times a base value.

origins: early 19th century: from Philistine, originally with reference to a confrontation between university students and townspeople in Jena, Germany, in the late 17th century; a sermon on the conflict quoted ‘the Philistines are upon you’ (Judges 16), which led to an association between the townspeople and those hostile to culture.
meaning: a person who is hostile or indifferent to culture and the arts.

origins: 1950s: contraction of formula translation .
meaning: a high-level computer programming language used especially for scientific calculations.

origins: mid 18th century: from Italian, literally ‘seashore’.
meaning: a coastal region with a subtropical climate and vegetation.

origins: 1950s: blend of Labrador and poodle
meaning: a dog that is bred as a cross between a Labrador and a poodle.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an intense but short-lived passion or admiration for someone or something

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a way that arouses suspicion, distrust, or uncertainty;with hesitation or doubt

origins: Middle English knokel (originally denoting the rounded shape when a joint such as the elbow or knee is bent), from Middle Low German, Middle Dutch knökel, diminutive of knoke ‘bone’. In the mid 18th century the verb knuckle (down) expressed setting the knuckles down to shoot the taw in a game of marbles, hence the notion of applying oneself with concentration.
meaning: a part of a finger at a joint where the bone is near the surface, especially where the finger joins the hand.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin herbaceus ‘grassy’ (from herba ‘grass, herb’) + -ous.
meaning: denoting or relating to herbs (in the botanical sense).

origins: late 19th century: from French.
meaning: a small magnifying glass used by jewellers and watchmakers.

origins: Maori, Hawaiian, and other Polynesian languages.
meaning: a Maori or Polynesian (especially Hawaiian) woman.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: you guess what it is on the basis of your intuition or feelings, rather than on the basis of knowledge.

origins: modern Latin, from Latin Amaryllis (from Greek Amarullis ), a name for a country girl in pastoral poetry.
meaning: a bulbous plant with showy trumpet-shaped flowers and strap-shaped leaves.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an expressive vocal phrase or passage consisting of several notes sung to one syllable

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin deliquescere ‘dissolve’, from de- ‘down’ + liquescere ‘become liquid’ (from liquere ‘be liquid’).
meaning: (of organic matter) become liquid, typically during decomposition.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French (chien) terrier ‘earth (dog)’, from medieval Latin terrarius, from Latin terra ‘earth’.
meaning: a small dog of a breed originally used for turning out foxes and other burrowing animals from their earths.;a member of the Territorial Army.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin olfactare (frequentative of olfacere ‘to smell’) + -ory2.
meaning: relating to the sense of smell.

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin, literally ‘felt cap’.
meaning: the cap of a mushroom or toadstool.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin, from Greek katakhrēsis, from katakhrēsthai ‘misuse’, from kata- ‘down’ (expressing the sense ‘wrongly’) + khrēsthai ‘use’.
meaning: the use of a word in an incorrect way, for example the use of mitigate for militate.

origins: late 19th century: from sub- ‘below’ + Latin limen, limin- ‘threshold’ + -al.
meaning: (of a stimulus or mental process) below the threshold of sensation or consciousness; perceived by or affecting someone's mind without their being aware of it.

origins: late 19th century: Spanish, literally ‘direct, straight’.
meaning: a storm system that moves a long distance rapidly and brings winds which can devastate an area several miles wide.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a soup made usually of meat stock often in combination and condensed by boiling, highly seasoned, cleared, and strained

origins: Old English īegland, from īeg  ‘island’ (from a base meaning ‘watery, watered’) + land. The change in the spelling of the first syllable in the 16th century was due to association with the unrelated word isle.
meaning: a piece of land surrounded by water.;a thing regarded as resembling an island, especially in being isolated, detached, or surrounded in some way.;a detached portion of tissue or group of cells.

origins: Old English tōth (plural tēth ), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch tand and German Zahn, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin dent-, Greek odont- .
meaning: each of a set of hard, bony enamel-coated structures in the jaws of most vertebrates, used for biting and chewing.;a projecting part on a tool or other instrument, especially one of a series that function or engage together, such as a cog on a gearwheel or a point on a saw.;an appetite or liking for a particular thing.;roughness given to a surface to allow colour or glue to adhere.

origins: mid 19th century: via American Spanish (diminutive form) from Nahuatl ocotl ‘torch’.
meaning: a spiny scarlet-flowered desert shrub of the south-western US and Mexico, which is sometimes planted as a hedge.

origins: early 18th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: an uncontrolled outburst of anger and frustration, typically in a young child.

origins: early 19th century: formed irregularly from Greek heuriskein ‘find’.
meaning: enabling someone to discover or learn something for themselves.

origins: Old English cyrnel, diminutive of corn1.
meaning: a softer, usually edible part of a nut, seed, or fruit stone contained within its shell.;the central or most important part of something.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a machine used to resurface ice for skating.

origins: mid 16th century: from Old Norse bylgja .
meaning: a large undulating mass of something, typically cloud, smoke, or steam.

origins: Unknown
meaning: bearing or producing fruit

origins: late Middle English: from Old French gantelet, diminutive of gant ‘glove’, of Germanic origin.
meaning: a strong glove with a long, loose wrist.

origins: late 16th century: from French comportement, from the verb comporter, from Latin comportare (see comport1).
meaning: behaviour; bearing.

origins: Latin American Spanish, probably from Araucanian kauču ‘friend’.
meaning: a cowboy from the South American pampas.

origins: early 20th century: modern Latin, from Greek mitos ‘thread’ + khondrion (diminutive of khondros ‘granule’).
meaning: an organelle found in large numbers in most cells, in which the biochemical processes of respiration and energy production occur. It has a double membrane, the inner part being folded inwards to form layers (cristae).

origins: Unknown
meaning: full of fervor

origins: late Middle English: from Latin disparatus ‘separated’, from the verb disparare, from dis- ‘apart’ + parare ‘to prepare’; influenced in sense by Latin dispar ‘unequal’.
meaning: essentially different in kind; not able to be compared.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French magicien, from late Latin magica (see magic).
meaning: a person with magical powers.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: Water or another liquid that is tepid is slightly warm.;it lacks enthusiasm.

origins: Greek, literally ‘slender U’, from psilos ‘slender’, referring to the need to distinguish upsilon from the diphthong oi : in late Greek the two had the same pronunciation.
meaning: the twentieth letter of the Greek alphabet ( Υ, υ ), transliterated as ‘u’ or (chiefly in English words derived through Latin) as ‘y’.

origins: French, literally ‘crunch in the mouth’
meaning: a decorative dessert consisting of cream puff pastry and crystallized fruit or other confectionery items arranged in a cone and held together by a caramel sauce.

origins: mid 19th century: from Hebrew kāšēr ‘proper’.
meaning: (of food, or premises in which food is sold, cooked, or eaten) satisfying the requirements of Jewish law.;genuine and legitimate.

origins: late Middle English (as a term in astronomy): from late Latin diurnalis, from Latin diurnus ‘daily’, from dies ‘day’.
meaning: of or during the day.;daily; of each day.

origins: Middle English (denoting a flag raised on a pole as a rallying point, the authorized exemplar of a unit of measurement, or an upright timber): shortening of Old French estendart, from estendre ‘extend’; in standard (sense 4 of the noun, sense 5 of the noun, sense 6 of the noun), influenced by the verb stand.
meaning: a level of quality or attainment.;something used as a measure, norm, or model in comparative evaluations.;(especially with reference to jazz or blues) a tune or song of established popularity.;a military or ceremonial flag carried on a pole or hoisted on a rope.;a tree or shrub that grows on an erect stem of full height.;an upright water or gas pipe.

origins: late 16th century: from obsolete French rebuffer (verb), rebuffe (noun), from Italian ri- (expressing opposition) + buffo ‘a gust, puff’, of imitative origin.
meaning: reject (someone or something) in an abrupt or ungracious manner.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the capital of Burkina Faso; population 1,149,000 (est. 2007).

origins: mid 17th century: from Greek thrēnōidia, from thrēnos ‘wailing’ + ōidē ‘song’.
meaning: a lament.

origins: early 17th century: from French furtif, -ive or Latin furtivus, from furtum ‘theft’.
meaning: attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble; secretive.

origins: early 16th century: imitative.
meaning: laugh lightly and repeatedly in a silly way, from amusement, nervousness, or embarrassment.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘preliminary design, tabulated statement’): from Latin projectum ‘something prominent’, neuter past participle of proicere ‘throw forth’, from pro- ‘forth’ + jacere ‘to throw’. Early senses of the verb were ‘plan’ and ‘cause to move forward’;Etymology Unknown
meaning: an individual or collaborative enterprise that is carefully planned to achieve a particular aim;a government-subsidized housing development with relatively low rents;make a projection of (the earth, sky, etc.) on a plane surface.;throw or cause to move forward or outward;present or promote (a particular view or image);estimate or forecast (something) on the basis of present trends or data;extend outward beyond something else; protrude;draw straight lines from a center of or parallel lines through every point of (a given figure) to produce a corresponding figure on a surface or a line by intersecting the surface.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (especially of a person or their appearance) messy and dirty

origins: late 16th century: from Latin annotat- ‘marked’, from the verb annotare, from ad- ‘to’ + nota ‘a mark’.
meaning: add notes to (a text or diagram) giving explanation or comment.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the job of supervising or taking care of something, such as an organization or property

origins: late Middle English: from Old French sobriete or Latin sobrietas, from sobrius (see sober).
meaning: the state of being sober.;the quality of being staid or solemn.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or characteristic of Icarus, especially in being excessively ambitious

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an instrument resembling a carpenter's brace and bit formerly used to remove circular sections of bone

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin pinnaculum, diminutive of pinna ‘wing, point’.
meaning: the most successful point; the culmination.;a high, pointed piece of rock.

origins: Italian, from French glissant, present participle of glisser ‘to slip, slide’.
meaning: a continuous slide upwards or downwards between two notes.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a device formerly used for driving machinery, consisting of a large wheel with steps fitted into its inner surface. It was turned by the weight of people or animals treading the steps.

origins: early 18th century: from French, from Latin minuscula (littera) ‘somewhat smaller (letter)’.
meaning: extremely small; tiny.;of or in lower-case letters, as distinct from capitals or uncials.

origins: Middle English: from holy + obsolete hock ‘mallow’, of unknown origin. It originally denoted the marsh mallow which has medicinal uses (hence, perhaps, the use of ‘holy’); the current sense dates from the mid 16th century.
meaning: a tall Eurasian plant of the mallow family, with large showy flowers.

origins: mid 16th century: from per + cent, perhaps an abbreviation of pseudo-Latin per centum .
meaning: by a specified amount in or for every hundred.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a small rough clay study for a larger sculptureáŚused especially of baroque sculpture

origins: late Middle English: early form of Bethlehem, referring to the hospital of St Mary of Bethlehem in London, used as an institution for the insane.
meaning: a scene of uproar and confusion.;an institution for the care of mentally ill people.

origins: Italian.
meaning: pasta in the shape of small tubes.

origins: Unknown
meaning: having eight eyes

origins: early 16th century: via Latin from Greek epitomē, from epitemnein ‘abridge’, from epi ‘in addition’ + temnein ‘to cut’.
meaning: a person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality or type.;a summary of a written work; an abstract.

origins: Old English ǣlc ; related to Dutch elk and German jeglich, based on a West Germanic phrase meaning ‘ever alike’ (see aye2, alike).
meaning: used to refer to every one of two or more people or things, regarded and identified separately.

origins: early 17th century: from dialect rasp, abbreviation of obsolete raspis  ‘raspberry’ (also used as a collective), of unknown origin, + berry.
meaning: an edible soft fruit related to the blackberry, consisting of a cluster of reddish-pink drupelets.;the plant which yields the raspberry, forming tall stiff prickly stems or ‘canes’.;a deep reddish-pink colour.;a sound made with the tongue and lips, expressing derision or contempt.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, from justicier ‘bring to trial’, from medieval Latin justitiare, from Latin justitia ‘equity’, from justus (see just).
meaning: (of a state or action) subject to trial in a court of law.

origins: late Middle English (as a term in astrology): from Old French saturnin, from medieval Latin Saturninus ‘of Saturn’ (identified with lead by the alchemists and associated with slowness and gloom by astrologers).
meaning: (of a person or their manner) gloomy.;relating to lead.

origins: mid 17th century: via medieval Latin from Greek dēlētērios ‘noxious’ + -ous.
meaning: causing harm or damage.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French porosité, late Latin porositas, based on Latin porus ‘pore’
meaning: the quality or degree of having minute spaces or holes through which liquid or air may pass

origins: mid 16th century (originally denoting the observation of bird flight in divination): from French, or from Latin auspicium, from auspex ‘observer of birds’, from avis ‘bird’ + specere ‘to look’.
meaning: a divine or prophetic token.

origins: Middle English (first used as a noun in the sense ‘mockery, scorn’): perhaps of Scandinavian origin.
meaning: speak to someone or about something in a scornfully derisive or mocking way.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin calumnia .
meaning: the making of false and defamatory statements about someone in order to damage their reputation; slander.

origins: 1940s (originally in military use): abbreviation of will comply .
meaning: expressing compliance or agreement, especially acceptance of instructions received by radio.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French velin, from veel (see veal).
meaning: fine parchment made originally from the skin of a calf.

origins: mid 16th century: from Spanish flamengo, earlier form of flamenco (see flamenco); associated, because of its colour, with Latin flamma ‘a flame’.
meaning: a tall wading bird with mainly pink or scarlet plumage and long legs and neck. It has a heavy bent bill that is held upside down in the water in order to filter-feed on small organisms.

origins: Japanese, probably from Portuguese tempêro ‘seasoning’.
meaning: a Japanese dish of fish, shellfish, or vegetables, fried in batter.

origins: Unknown
meaning: used of a judge who expresses doubt about a decision reached by the court

origins: late 17th century (as a verb): perhaps a frequentative of the verb scum.
meaning: modify (a painting or colour) by applying a very thin coat of opaque paint to give a softer or duller effect.

origins: late Middle English (denoting a writer of tragedies): from Old French tragediane, from tragedie (see tragedy).
meaning: an actor who specializes in tragic roles.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French cicatriser, from cicatrice ‘scar’ (see cicatrix).
meaning: (with reference to a wound) heal by scar formation.

origins: Old English pere, peru, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch peer, from Latin pirum .
meaning: a yellowish- or brownish-green edible fruit that is typically narrow at the stalk and wider towards the base, with sweet, slightly gritty flesh.;the Eurasian tree which bears the pear.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the use of skill to bring something about or create something;a device, especially in literary or artistic composition, which gives a sense of artificiality

origins: early 17th century: from medieval Latin diaphanus, from Greek diaphanēs, from dia ‘through’ + phainein ‘to show’.
meaning: (especially of fabric) light, delicate, and translucent.

origins: late Middle English (originally in the sense ‘hardened in sin, impenitent’): from Latin obduratus, past participle of obdurare, from ob- ‘in opposition’ + durare ‘harden’ (from durus ‘hard’).
meaning: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin opprobriosus, from opprobrium (see opprobrium).
meaning: (of language) expressing scorn or criticism.

origins: Unknown
meaning: market coffee prepared by drying the beans in the sun

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a group of about 500 islands off the northwestern coast of Scotland. The Inner Hebrides are separated from the Outer Hebrides by the Little Minch.

origins: early 18th century: imitative of its call.
meaning: a North and Central American nightjar with a distinctive call.

origins: late Middle English trice ‘a tug’, figuratively ‘an instant’, from Middle Dutch trīsen ‘pull sharply’, related to trīse ‘pulley’
meaning: in an instant

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘victorious’): from Old French, or from Latin triumphant- ‘celebrating a triumph’, from the verb triumphare (see triumph).
meaning: having won a battle or contest; victorious.

origins: late Middle English: from French dent-de-lion, translation of medieval Latin dens leonis ‘lion's tooth’ (because of the jagged shape of the leaves).
meaning: a widely distributed weed of the daisy family, with a rosette of leaves and large bright yellow flowers followed by globular heads of seeds with downy tufts.

origins: early 18th century: from Tupi kyynha, quiynha, later associated with Cayenne.
meaning: a pungent hot-tasting red powder prepared from ground dried chilli peppers.

origins: late Middle English (as a noun in the sense ‘request, demand’): from Old French, or from Latin requisitio(n- ), from requirere ‘search for’ (see require). The verb dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: an official order laying claim to the use of property or materials.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: existing, formed, or taking place underwater

origins: 1930s: modern Latin, from Greek deuteros ‘second’.
meaning: a stable isotope of hydrogen with a mass approximately twice that of the usual isotope.

origins: early 19th century: from Afrikaans kommandeer, from Dutch commanderen, from French commander ‘to command’ (see command).
meaning: officially take possession or control of (something), especially for military purposes.

origins: Japanese, from Okinawa dialect.
meaning: a Japanese martial arts weapon consisting of two hardwood sticks joined together by a chain, rope, or thong.

origins: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘deadly, characterized by great slaughter’): from Latin internecinus, based on inter- ‘among’ + necare ‘to kill’.
meaning: destructive to both sides in a conflict.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an industrial and commercial city in southern Brazil, in São Paulo state; population 319,100 (est. 2007).

origins: from Greek rhuton, neuter of rhutos ‘flowing’; related to rhein ‘to flow’.
meaning: a type of drinking container used in ancient Greece, typically having the form of an animal's head or a horn, with the hole for drinking from located at the lower or pointed end.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French outrageus, from outrage ‘excess’ (see outrage).
meaning: shockingly bad or excessive.;very bold and unusual and rather shocking.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: speculate or theorize about fundamental or serious issues, especially in a tedious or pompous way

origins: early 17th century: from French système or late Latin systema, from Greek sustēma, from sun- ‘with’ + histanai ‘set up’.
meaning: a set of things working together as parts of a mechanism or an interconnecting network; a complex whole.;a set of principles or procedures according to which something is done; an organized scheme or method.;the prevailing political or social order, especially when regarded as oppressive and intransigent.;a set of staves in a musical score joined by a brace.

origins: 1930s: from sterol + -oid.
meaning: any of a large class of organic compounds with a characteristic molecular structure containing four rings of carbon atoms (three six-membered and one five). They include many hormones, alkaloids, and vitamins.

origins: French, earlier guiriot, perhaps from Portuguese criado .
meaning: a member of a class of travelling poets, musicians, and storytellers who maintain a tradition of oral history in parts of West Africa.

origins: mid 19th century (in use earlier with reference to St James): from modern Latin Jacobaeus (from ecclesiastical Latin Jacobus ‘James’, from Greek Iakōbos ‘Jacob’) + -an.
meaning: relating to the reign of James I of England.

origins: Unknown
meaning: barbecue

origins: mid 16th century: from medieval Latin, from Old Italian tarantola ‘tarantula’, from the name of the seaport Taranto. Compare with tarantella and tarantism.
meaning: a very large hairy spider found chiefly in tropical and subtropical America, some kinds of which are able to catch small lizards, frogs, and birds.;a large black wolf spider of southern Europe, whose bite was formerly believed to cause tarantism.

origins: Middle English (in condemn (sense 2)): from Old French condemner, from Latin condemnare, from con- (expressing intensive force) + damnare ‘inflict loss on’ (see damn).
meaning: express complete disapproval of; censure.;sentence (someone) to a particular punishment, especially death.

origins: late Middle English (denoting a narrow hanging section of a decoratively slashed garment): of unknown origin; compare with dag. The verb dates from the early 17th century.
meaning: a label attached to someone or something for the purpose of identification or to give other information.;a small piece or part that is attached to a main body.;a frequently repeated quotation or stock phrase.

origins: Old English betera (adjective), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch beter and German besser, also to best.
meaning: more desirable, satisfactory, or effective.;partly or fully recovered from illness, injury, or mental stress.

origins: Unknown
meaning: tenderlyáŚused as a direction in music

origins: mid 16th century: from Spanish patata, variant of Taino batata ‘sweet potato’. The English word originally denoted the sweet potato and gained its current sense in the late 16th century.
meaning: a starchy plant tuber which is one of the most important food crops, cooked and eaten as a vegetable.;the plant of the nightshade family which produces potatoes on underground runners.;a large hole in a sock or stocking, especially one in the heel.

origins: late Middle English: from sheath.
meaning: put (a weapon such as a knife or sword) into a sheath.;encase (something) in a close-fitting or protective covering.

origins: late 17th century (denoting a sovereign): of obscure origin.
meaning: one pound sterling.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: acutely distressing

origins: early 18th century: from French (earlier ‘clump of trees’), from a dialect variant of Old French bos ‘wood’. bouquet (sense 2) dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: an attractively arranged bunch of flowers, especially one presented as a gift or carried at a ceremony.;the characteristic scent of a wine or perfume.

origins: Middle English (denoting a designer and constructor of fortifications and weapons; formerly also as ingineer ): in early use from Old French engigneor, from medieval Latin ingeniator, from ingeniare ‘contrive, devise’, from Latin ingenium (see engine); in later use from French ingénieur or Italian ingegnere, also based on Latin ingenium, with the ending influenced by -eer.
meaning: a person who designs, builds, or maintains engines, machines, or structures.;a person who controls an engine, especially on an aircraft or ship.;a skilful contriver or originator of something.

origins: Unknown
meaning: of cream : whipped and usually sweetened and flavored with vanilla; of foods : prepared or garnished with whipped cream

origins: late 16th century: from French acrostiche, from Greek akrostikhis, from akron ‘end’ + stikhos ‘row, line of verse’. The change in the ending was due to association with -ic.
meaning: a poem, word puzzle, or other composition in which certain letters in each line form a word or words.

origins: early 20th century: from Japanese.
meaning: a goldfish of an ornamental variety, having black spots, red patches, and long fins and tail.

origins: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘rhetorical device involving repetition of a word or phrase’): via late Latin from Greek analēpsis, from ana ‘up’ + lambanein ‘take’.
meaning: a literary device in narrative, in which a past event is narrated at a point later than its chronological place in a story.;ascension into heaven.

origins: mid 18th century: from French, literally ‘something stitched’, from brocher ‘to stitch’ (see broach1).
meaning: a small book or magazine containing pictures and information about a product or service.

origins: late 18th century (as a dialect term meaning ‘a bound or spring’): related to Swedish spritta .
meaning: run at full speed over a short distance.

origins: Unknown
meaning: blackfly

origins: Old English: archaic plural of brother.
meaning: fellow Christians or members of a male religious order.

origins: Old English hīeran, hēran, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hooren and German hören .
meaning: perceive with the ear the sound made by (someone or something).;be told or informed of.

origins: Old English scead(u)we (noun), oblique case of sceadu (see shade), sceadwian ‘screen or shield from attack’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schaduw and German Schatten (nouns), from an Indo-European root shared by Greek skotos ‘darkness’.
meaning: a dark area or shape produced by a body coming between rays of light and a surface.;used in reference to proximity, ominous oppressiveness, or sadness and gloom.;an inseparable attendant or companion.;short for eyeshadow.

origins: late 19th century: from Spanish, denoting the season of spring, from Latin primus ‘first, earliest’ + ver ‘spring’ (alluding to the tree's early flowering).
meaning: the hard, light-coloured timber of a Central American tree.

origins: Unknown
meaning: diamond

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a plantation of grapevines, typically producing grapes used in winemaking.

origins: early 19th century: named after Chihuahua.
meaning: a very small dog of a smooth-haired large-eyed breed originating in Mexico.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: denoting or relating to a period of a thousand years;a person born between the early 1980s and the late 1990s; a member of Generation Y;relating to or denoting people born between the early 1980s and the late 1990s

origins: late 16th century: from Latin grandiloquus, literally ‘grand-speaking’, from grandis ‘grand’ + loqui ‘speak’. The ending was altered in English by association with eloquent.
meaning: pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress.

origins: Italian, from bruscare ‘to toast’.
meaning: toasted Italian bread drenched in olive oil and served typically with garlic or tomatoes.

origins: late Old English grotan (plural): related to grit and grits.
meaning: hulled or crushed grain, especially oats.

origins: early 17th century (as an adjective): from Latin detergent- ‘wiping away’, from the verb detergere, from de- ‘away from’ + tergere ‘to wipe’.
meaning: a water-soluble cleansing agent which combines with impurities and dirt to make them more soluble, and differs from soap in not forming a scum with the salts in hard water.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘bind by oath’): from Old French obliger, from Latin obligare, from ob- ‘towards’ + ligare ‘to bind’.
meaning: make (someone) legally or morally bound to do something.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin abstemius, (from ab- ‘from’ + a word related to temetum ‘alcoholic drink’) + -ous.
meaning: indulging only very moderately in something, especially food and drink.

origins: modern Latin, from Greek hudro- ‘water’ + angeion ‘vessel’ (from the cup shape of its seed capsule).
meaning: a shrub or climbing plant with rounded or flattened flowering heads of small florets, native to Asia and America.

origins: mid 16th century (as a verb): imitative.
meaning: the characteristic harsh sound made by a duck.

origins: late Middle English: from the rare word fester  ‘fistula’, later ‘festering sore’, or Old French festrir (verb), both from Old French festre (noun), from Latin fistula ‘pipe, reed, fistula’.
meaning: (of a wound or sore) become septic; suppurate.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin triplus (see triple).
meaning: consisting of three parts; threefold.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: capable of being reconciled; compatible

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a supernatural viscous substance that is supposed to exude from the body of a medium during a spiritualistic trance and form the material for the manifestation of spirits.;the more viscous, clear outer layer of the cytoplasm in amoeboid cells.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a physician or surgeon qualified to practice in obstetrics.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin, ‘brooch’, perhaps related to figere ‘to fix’. The bone is so named because the shape it makes with the tibia resembles a clasp, the fibula being the pin.
meaning: the outer and usually smaller of the two bones between the knee and the ankle (or the equivalent joints in other terrestrial vertebrates), parallel with the tibia.;a brooch or clasp.

origins: mid 18th century: from Scottish Gaelic sporan .
meaning: a small pouch worn around the waist so as to hang in front of the kilt as part of men's Scottish Highland dress.

origins: mid 17th century (used literally as in abysmal (sense 2)): from abysm. abysmal (sense 1) dates from the early 19th century.
meaning: extremely bad; appalling.;very deep.

origins: early 19th century: from Malay.
meaning: a tree-dwelling Asian civet with a coarse blackish coat and a muscular prehensile tail.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a geologic formation or stratum that confines water in an adjacent aquifer

origins: late 16th century (as a noun): from obsolete French favorit, from Italian favorito, past participle of favorire ‘to favour’, from Latin favor (see favour).
meaning: preferred to all others of the same kind.

origins: early 16th century: from late Latin captivat- ‘taken captive’, from the verb captivare, from captivus (see captive).
meaning: attract and hold the interest and attention of; charm.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the giving or offering of a bribe

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: having the same ancestor; closely related

origins: late Middle English: from Latin intellectualis, from intellectus ‘understanding’, from intellegere ‘understand’ (see intelligent).
meaning: relating to the intellect.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the study of human societies and cultures and their development.

origins: Middle English: from Old French vencus, venquis (past participle and past tense of veintre ), vainquiss- (lengthened stem of vainquir ), from Latin vincere ‘conquer’.
meaning: defeat thoroughly.

origins: 1950s: blend of dopa and amine.
meaning: a compound present in the body as a neurotransmitter and a precursor of other substances including adrenaline.

origins: Middle English: from obsolete gast ‘terrify’, from Old English gǣstan, of Germanic origin; related to ghost. The gh spelling is by association with ghost. The sense ‘objectionable’ dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: causing great horror or fear.;extremely unwell.;very objectionable, bad, or unpleasant.

origins: Old English (denoting various plants supposed to cure madness), from Old French ellebre, elebore or medieval Latin eleborus, via Latin from Greek helleboros .
meaning: a poisonous winter-flowering Eurasian plant of the buttercup family, typically having coarse divided leaves and large white, green, or purplish flowers.

origins: Middle English: from Old French baubel ‘child's toy’, of unknown origin.
meaning: a small, showy trinket or decoration.;a baton formerly used as an emblem by jesters.

origins: early 19th century: via French from Latin, literally ‘for all’, dative plural of omnis .
meaning: a volume containing several books previously published separately.;a bus.

origins: Unknown
meaning: artistic wood carving

origins: Middle English (as a verb): from Old French eskirmiss-, lengthened stem of eskirmir, from a Germanic verb meaning ‘defend’.
meaning: an episode of irregular or unpremeditated fighting, especially between small or outlying parts of armies or fleets.

origins: late 18th century: from French, from tarse ‘tarsus’, with reference to the animal's long tarsal bones.
meaning: a small insectivorous, tree-dwelling, nocturnal primate with very large eyes, a long tufted tail, and very long hindlimbs, native to the islands of SE Asia.

origins: Old English smeortan (verb), of West Germanic origin; related to German schmerzen ; the adjective is related to the verb, the original sense (late Old English) being ‘causing sharp pain’; from this arose ‘keen, brisk’, whence the current senses of ‘mentally sharp’ and ‘neat in a brisk, sharp style’.
meaning: (of a person) clean, tidy, and well dressed.;having or showing a quick-witted intelligence.;(of a device) programmed so as to be capable of some independent action.;quick; brisk.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or Latin machinatio-, from machinat- ‘contrived’ (see machinate).
meaning: a plot or scheme.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: sticking out; projecting

origins: mid 16th century: from French épilepsie, or via late Latin from Greek epilēpsia, from epilambanein ‘seize, attack’, from epi ‘upon’ + lambanein ‘take hold of’.
meaning: a neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

origins: mid 16th century: from obsolete French coronel (earlier form of colonel ), from Italian colonnello ‘column of soldiers’, from colonna ‘column’, from Latin columna . The form coronel, source of the modern pronunciation, was usual until the mid 17th century.
meaning: a rank of officer in the army and in the US air force, above a lieutenant colonel and below a brigadier or brigadier general.

origins: Old English cē(a)ce, cēoce  ‘cheek, jaw’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch kaak .
meaning: either side of the face below the eye.;talk or behaviour regarded as rude or lacking in respect.

origins: late 18th century: modern Latin, irregular diminutive of variola.
meaning: technical term for chickenpox.

origins: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin, literally ‘power’, from Latin posse ‘be able’.
meaning: a body of men summoned by a sheriff to enforce the law.;a group of people who have a common characteristic or occupation.

origins: Norwegian.
meaning: an enormous mythical sea monster said to appear off the coast of Norway.

origins: late 19th century: from French, fanciful formation based on bel ‘beautiful’.
meaning: a small, decorative ornament or trinket.

origins: Italian, literally ‘using force’.
meaning: (especially as a direction) with sudden emphasis.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a rough draft

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to rabbis or to Jewish law or teachings

origins: late Middle English: from Old French (Picard) caboche ‘head’, variant of Old French caboce, of unknown origin.
meaning: a cultivated plant eaten as a vegetable, having thick green or purple leaves surrounding a spherical heart or head of young leaves.;a person who leads a dull or inactive life.

origins: late Middle English (as a verb meaning ‘lament, cry out’): alteration of earlier yomer, from Old English geōmrian ‘to lament’, suggested by Middle Dutch jammeren .
meaning: talk foolishly or incessantly.

origins: Old English frēosan (in the phrase hit frēoseth ‘it is freezing’), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vriezen and German frieren, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin pruina ‘hoar frost’ and frost.
meaning: (with reference to a liquid) turn or be turned into ice or another solid as a result of extreme cold.;store (something) at a very low temperature in order to preserve it.;become suddenly motionless or paralysed with fear or shock.;hold (something) at a fixed level or in a fixed state for a period of time.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the state of being famous or well known for some bad quality or deed

origins: late 15th century (in the sense ‘advise against’): from Latin dissuadere, from dis- (expressing reversal) + suadere ‘advise, persuade’.
meaning: persuade (someone) not to take a particular course of action.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, dialect variant of cive, from Latin cepa ‘onion’.
meaning: a small Eurasian plant related to the onion, with purple-pink flowers and long tubular leaves which are used as a culinary herb.

origins: Unknown
meaning: hyphenated something that is or is felt to be the best of its kind  especially : a usually large and valuable diamond

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: continually;lasting or permanent;for all future time; for always

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the state or condition of being free from being observed or disturbed by other people

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to a three-hundredth anniversary; tricentennial;the three-hundredth anniversary of a significant event; a tricentennial

origins: late 16th century: from Irish seamróg ‘trefoil’ (diminutive of seamar ‘clover’).
meaning: a low-growing clover-like plant with three-lobed leaves, used as the national emblem of Ireland.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the branch of zoology that deals with fishes.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French copieux or Latin copiosus, from copia ‘plenty’.
meaning: abundant in supply or quantity.

origins: 1940s: from ( acetani)lid(e ) + -caine (from cocaine).
meaning: another term for lignocaine.

origins: Middle English (originally denoting a criminal): from Old French, or from Latin vagabundus, from vagari ‘wander’.
meaning: a person who wanders from place to place without a home or job.

origins: Middle English: from Old French merveillus, from merveille (see marvel).
meaning: causing great wonder; extraordinary.

origins: early 17th century: from late Latin condensatio(n- ), from condensare ‘press close together’ (see condense).
meaning: water which collects as droplets on a cold surface when humid air is in contact with it.;the conversion of a vapour or gas to a liquid.;a concise version of something, especially a text.

origins: late 17th century: from late Latin appositivus ‘subsidiary’.
meaning: relating to apposition; appositional.

origins: mid 19th century (as a verb): alteration of chassé.
meaning: walk in an ostentatious yet casual manner, typically with exaggerated movements of the hips and shoulders.;perform the sashay.

origins: Old English rūn  ‘a secret, mystery’; not recorded between Middle English and the late 17th century, when it was reintroduced under the influence of Old Norse rúnir, rúnar ‘magic signs, hidden lore’.
meaning: a letter of an ancient Germanic alphabet, related to the Roman alphabet.;a section of the Kalevala or of an ancient Scandinavian poem.

origins: late 16th century: from medieval Latin Balticus, from late Latin Balthae ‘dwellers near the Baltic Sea’.
meaning: relating to the Baltic Sea or the region surrounding it.;denoting or relating to a branch of the Indo-European family of languages consisting of Lithuanian, Latvian, and Old Prussian.;(of weather conditions) very cold.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, of Germanic origin.
meaning: a thin liquid food of oatmeal or other meal boiled in milk or water.

origins: late 17th century: from marquise, taken as plural and assimilated to -ee.
meaning: a large tent used for social or commercial functions.;a canopy projecting over the entrance to a theatre, hotel, or other building.

origins: early 17th century: from Anglo-Latin regnalis, from Latin regnum ‘kingdom’.
meaning: of a reign or monarch.

origins: Middle English: from be- (as an intensifier) + Old English sēcan (see seek).
meaning: ask (someone) urgently and fervently to do something; implore; entreat.

origins: from Sanskrit avatāra ‘descent’, from ava ‘down’ + tar- ‘to cross’.
meaning: a manifestation of a deity or released soul in bodily form on earth; an incarnate divine teacher.;an icon or figure representing a particular person in a video game, internet forum, etc.

origins: late 15th century: from French amalgame or medieval Latin amalgama, from Greek malagma ‘an emollient’.
meaning: a mixture or blend.

origins: late Middle English (as a verb): ultimately imitative; perhaps from Dutch bommen ‘to hum, buzz’.
meaning: a loud, deep, resonant sound.

origins: Old English līnen (as an adjective in the sense ‘made of flax’), of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch linnen, German Leinen, also to obsolete line ‘flax’.
meaning: cloth woven from flax.

origins: late 18th century: from French molécule, from modern Latin molecula, diminutive of Latin moles ‘mass’.

origins: late 17th century: of unknown origin. crumpet (sense 2 of the noun) dates from the 1930s.

origins: Middle English (as a noun): probably from Old Norse skáld ‘skald’.
meaning: remonstrate with or rebuke (someone) angrily.

origins: late Middle English: from Middle Low German and Middle Dutch bolwerk ; related to bole1 and work.
meaning: a defensive wall.;an extension of a ship's sides above the level of the deck.

origins: late 17th century (denoting the part of the brain at which a nerve originates): via Latin from Greek thalamos .
meaning: either of two masses of grey matter lying between the cerebral hemispheres on either side of the third ventricle, relaying sensory information and acting as a centre for pain perception.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: asserting one's will over another in an arrogant way

origins: via Latin from Greek.
meaning: the first letter of the Greek alphabet ( Α, α ), transliterated as ‘a’.;a code word representing the letter A, used in radio communication.

origins: late Middle English: the earlier form of human, restricted to the senses above in the 18th century.
meaning: having or showing compassion or benevolence.;(of a branch of learning) intended to have a civilizing effect on people.

origins: late 16th century: from French chicanerie, from chicaner ‘to quibble’ (see chicane).
meaning: the use of deception or subterfuge to achieve one's purpose.

origins: late Middle English: from bailie + wick2.
meaning: one's sphere of operations or area of interest.;the district or jurisdiction of a bailie or bailiff.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: capital of Honduras; population 967,200 (est. 2008).

origins: mid 17th century: from blather + skite, a Scots derogatory term adopted into American colloquial speech during the War of Independence from the Scottish song ‘Maggie Lauder’, by F. Semphill, which was popular with American troops.
meaning: a person who talks at great length without making much sense.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a first edition of a work;  also  a copy of this edition; the head of the state under the Roman Empire; any of various chief officials (as the headman of a tribe) among the ancient Teutons and Anglo-Saxons

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘lack of ease; inconvenience’): from Old French desaise ‘lack of ease’, from des- (expressing reversal) + aise ‘ease’.
meaning: a disorder of structure or function in a human, animal, or plant, especially one that produces specific symptoms or that affects a specific location and is not simply a direct result of physical injury.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a large aquatic plant-eating mammal of the order Sirenia, such as a manatee or dugong.;relating to or denoting sirenians.

origins: early 19th century (originally US): formed irregularly from Cambrai, the name of a town in northern France, where it was originally made. Compare with cambric.

origins: from the name of the area around the River Clyde in Scotland, where they were originally bred.
meaning: a horse of a heavy, powerful breed, used for pulling heavy loads.;a dog of a small breed of terrier.

origins: Old English brycg (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch brug and German Brücke .

origins: early 18th century: from French, from obsolete verbeier ‘to chatter’, from verbe ‘word’ (see verb).

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘ordinary or inferior’): origin uncertain; until the 17th century identical in spelling with course, and possibly derived from the latter in the sense ‘ordinary manner’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Unknown
meaning: a level or plateau (as of existence or achievement) especially in a progression

origins: late Middle English: from Old French necessite, from Latin necessitas, from necesse ‘be needful’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: 1970s: from collapse, on the pattern of words such as pulsar .

origins: Middle English: from Old French, based on Latin super- ‘above, in excess’ + facere ‘do’.

origins: mid 17th century: from extra- ‘outside’ + Latin vas ‘vessel’ + -ate3.

origins: early 17th century: from medieval Latin laboratorium, from Latin laborare ‘to labour’.

origins: late 19th century: from the name of Draco (see Draco2) + -ian.

origins: Unknown

origins: late Middle English: from Latin aestimat- ‘determined, appraised’, from the verb aestimare. The verb originally meant ‘to think well or badly of someone or something’ (late 15th century), later ‘regard as being, consider to be’ (compare with esteem);Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English: from Latin ministratio(n- ), from ministrare ‘wait upon’, from minister (see minister).

origins: mid 19th century: from isolate, partly on the pattern of French isolation .

origins: late 15th century: from Greek oligarkhia, from oligoi ‘few’ and arkhein ‘to rule’.
meaning: a small group of people having control of a country or organization.

origins: German, ‘house of architecture’, from Bau ‘building’ + Haus ‘house’
meaning: a school of design established by Walter Gropius in Weimar in 1919, best known for its designs of objects based on functionalism and simplicity.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘boy’, later ‘man, male servant’): of unknown origin.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: cheap and of poor quality.;of, like, or decorated with chintz

origins: 1950s: alteration of bizarre, perhaps from the name of a character in DC Comics' Superman comic books.
meaning: bizarre.

origins: late 16th century: shortened from coppice.
meaning: a small group of trees.

origins: 1950s: from interfere + -on.
meaning: a protein released by animal cells, usually in response to the entry of a virus, which has the property of inhibiting virus replication.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who supports the theories of the Greek philosopher Pythagoras;relating to or characteristic of the Greek philosopher Pythagoras or his ideas

origins: late Middle English: from Old French adjectif, -ive, from Latin adject- ‘added’, from the verb adicere, from ad- ‘towards’ + jacere ‘throw’. The term was originally used in the phrase noun adjective, translating Latin nomen adjectivum, a translation of Greek onoma epitheton ‘attributive name’.
meaning: a word naming an attribute of a noun, such as sweet, red, or technical.

origins: early 17th century: from French, feminine of beau, from Latin bella, feminine of bellus ‘beautiful’.
meaning: a beautiful girl or woman, especially the most beautiful at a particular event.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘use for, devote to’): from be- (as an intensifier) + Old English stōw ‘place’.

origins: mid 17th century: from French, plural of environ (see environ).
meaning: the surrounding area or district.

origins: Unknown
meaning: ástifled,ásmotheredáŚused especially of a damping or muting of the tone on a stringed instrument (such as the harp)

origins: mid 19th century: from French, formed irregularly from Latin avis ‘bird’.

origins: early 17th century: from French roquette, from Italian rocchetto, diminutive of rocca ‘distaff (for spinning)’, with reference to its cylindrical shape.
meaning: a cylindrical projectile that can be propelled to a great height or distance by the combustion of its contents, used typically as a firework or signal.;a severe reprimand.

origins: late 18th century: probably from cord ‘ribbed fabric’ + duroy, denoting a kind of lightweight worsted formerly made in the West of England, of unknown origin.

origins: Middle English (denoting a piece broken off (especially from a spear), also a cudgel): from Old French tronchon ‘stump’, based on Latin truncus ‘trunk’.

origins: Chinese (Cantonese dialect).

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Middle English (in assumption (sense 3)): from Old French asompsion or Latin assumptio(n- ), from the verb assumere (see assume).

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin sesquipedalis ‘a foot and a half long’, from sesqui- (see sesqui-) + pes, ped- ‘foot’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Etymology Unknown;1930s; earliest use found in The Biological Bulletin. From scientific Latin Acoela (W. N. Uljanin 1870) from ancient Greek ἄκοιλος not hollow from ἀ- + κοῖλος hollow; compare ancient Greek ἀκοίλιος without ducts, without stomach
meaning: A member of the group Acoela of simple flatworms that have no distinct gut.;Of or relating to the group Acoela.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French nonage, from non- ‘non-’ + age ‘age’.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French eschiver, ultimately of Germanic origin and related to German scheuen ‘shun’, also to shy1.

origins: early 18th century (in the sense ‘award judicially’): from Latin adjudicat- ‘awarded judicially’, from the verb adjudicare (see adjudge). The noun adjudication (as a Scots legal term) dates from the early 17th century.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Middle English (as a noun in the sense ‘worth, reputation’): from Old French estime (noun), estimer (verb), from Latin aestimare ‘to estimate’. The verb was originally in the Latin sense, also ‘appraise’ (compare with estimate), used figuratively to mean ‘assess the merit of’. Current senses date from the 16th century.

origins: late 15th century: from French amasser or medieval Latin amassare, based on Latin massa ‘lump’ (see mass).
meaning: gather together or accumulate (a large amount or number of material or things) over a period of time.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a class of compound words whose meanings follow the formula ô(one) having aáBáthat isáAöáwhereáAástands for the first constituent of the compound andáBáfor the secondááalsoá:áa compound word belonging to this class (such aságraybeard, blockhead, orábarefoot)

meaning: an official order or commission to do something;the authority to carry out a policy or course of action, regarded as given by the electorate to a candidate or party that is victorious in an election;give (someone) authority to act in a certain way;assign (territory) under a mandate of the League of Nations

origins: Old English sc(e)adu, of Germanic origin. Compare with shadow.

origins: late 19th century: from French, from medieval Latin graticula ‘a little grating’, from Latin craticula ‘gridiron’, diminutive of cratis ‘hurdle’.

origins: Italian, literally ‘bound’.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin ululat- ‘howled, shrieked’, from the verb ululare, of imitative origin.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin thema, from Greek, literally ‘proposition’; related to tithenai ‘to set or place’.

origins: early 17th century: from French, from Provençal acolada, literally ‘embrace around the neck (when bestowing knighthood)’, from Latin ad- ‘at, to’ + collum ‘neck’.

origins: late 15th century: from Latin corporatus, past participle of corporare ‘form into a body’, from corpus, corpor- ‘body’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late 18th century: of unknown origin.

origins: Middle English (denoting the divine nature of God): from Old French deite, from ecclesiastical Latin deitas (translating Greek theotēs ), from deus ‘god’.

origins: Japanese, from yaki ‘grilling, frying’ + tori ‘bird’.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘serving to differentiate’): from late Latin distinctivus, from Latin distinct- ‘distinguished’ (see distinct).

origins: late Middle English: from bone + fire. The term originally denoted a large open-air fire on which bones were burnt (sometimes as part of a celebration), also one for burning heretics or proscribed literature. Dr Johnson accepted the mistaken idea that the word came from French bon ‘good’.

origins: early 20th century: from Japanese urushi ‘Japanese lacquer’ + -ol.

Some kinds have become cosmopolitan and are sometimes responsible for transmitting diseases.;a despicable person, especially a man who has been deceitful or disloyal.;a person who is associated with or frequents a specified place.;a pad used to give shape and fullness to a woman's hair.

origins: Middle English: from Old French feau(l)te, fealte, from Latin fidelitas (see fidelity).

origins: early 17th century: from Latin chrysal(l)is, chrysal(l)id-, from Greek khrusallis, from khrusos ‘gold’ (because of the gold colour or metallic sheen of some pupae).

origins: Middle English: from Old French toaille, of Germanic origin. Sense 2 of the verb dates from the early 18th century; sense 1 from the mid 19th century.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, contraction of gratiis ‘as a kindness’, from gratia ‘grace, kindness’.

origins: late 16th century: from late Latin spinalis, from Latin spina (see spine).

origins: late 17th century: symbolic of writhing movement; probably associated with worm.

origins: late Middle English: via Latin from Greek sunekdokhē, from sun- ‘together’ + ekdekhesthai ‘take up’.
