meaning: to remodel (an ancient building) without proper knowledge or care to retain its original quality and character

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: causing allergic sensitization

origins: Italian, literally ‘recooked, cooked twice’.
meaning: a soft white unsalted Italian cheese.

origins: mid 18th century (also in the sense ‘feebly sentimental’): from lackaday or its obsolete extended form lackadaisy .
meaning: lacking enthusiasm and determination; carelessly lazy.

origins: French.
meaning: a type of pork sausage, served typically as an hors d'oeuvre.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin sedulus ‘zealous’ + -ous.
meaning: (of a person or action) showing dedication and diligence.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: apparently or purportedly, but perhaps not actually

origins: late Middle English (as an adjective): from French palliatif, -ive or medieval Latin palliativus, from the verb palliare ‘to cloak’ (see palliate).
meaning: (of a medicine or medical care) relieving pain without dealing with the cause of the condition.

origins: late 16th century: modern Latin, from Italian sorgo, perhaps based on a variant of Latin syricum ‘Syrian’.
meaning: a cereal which is native to warm regions of the Old World and is a major source of grain and stockfeed.

origins: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French sudein, from an alteration of Latin subitaneus, from subitus ‘sudden’.
meaning: occurring or done quickly and unexpectedly or without warning.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin codicillus, diminutive of codex, codic- (see codex).
meaning: an addition or supplement that explains, modifies, or revokes a will or part of one.

origins: mid 19th century: perhaps from Spanish jaquima, earlier xaquima ‘halter’.
meaning: a bridle without a bit, operating by exerting pressure on the horse's nose.

origins: via Latin from Greek hudra ‘water snake’ (see Hydra), named by Linnaeus because, if cut into pieces, each section can grow into a whole animal.
meaning: a minute freshwater coelenterate with a tubular body and a ring of tentacles around the mouth.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: made holy; consecrated

origins: Italian dialect, probably a special use of calzone ‘trouser leg’, with reference to the shape of the pizza.
meaning: a type of pizza that is folded in half before cooking to contain a filling.

origins: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin seraphicus, from late Latin seraphim (see seraph).
meaning: characteristic of or resembling a seraph or seraphim; angelic.

origins: Japanese.
meaning: (in a Japanese house) a recess or alcove, typically a few inches above floor level, for displaying flowers, pictures, and ornaments.

origins: late 16th century (as a noun): from obsolete French favorit, from Italian favorito, past participle of favorire ‘to favour’, from Latin favor (see favour).
meaning: preferred to all others of the same kind.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: showing or characterized by complete sincerity and commitment

origins: late 17th century: from French synthétique or modern Latin syntheticus, from Greek sunthetikos, based on suntithenai ‘place together’.
meaning: (of a substance) made by chemical synthesis, especially to imitate a natural product.;(of a proposition) having truth or falsity determinable by recourse to experience.;(of a language) characterized by the use of inflections rather than word order to express grammatical structure.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the study of the rights and duties of citizenship.

origins: late Middle English (denoting an ancient Roman magistrate): from Latin, related to consulere ‘take counsel’.
meaning: an official appointed by a state to live in a foreign city and protect the state's citizens and interests there.;(in ancient Rome) each of the two annually elected chief magistrates who jointly ruled the republic.

origins: late 15th century: perhaps ultimately related to Latin mappa ‘napkin’.
meaning: an implement consisting of a bundle of thick loose strings or a sponge attached to a handle, used for wiping floors or other surfaces.;a thick mass of disordered hair.

origins: mid 19th century: from the name of Louis Braille (see Braille, Louis).
meaning: a form of written language for blind people, in which characters are represented by patterns of raised dots that are felt with the fingertips.

origins: late Middle English (denoting the department of a household concerned with kitchen utensils): from Old French escuelerie, from escuele ‘dish’, from Latin scutella ‘salver’, diminutive of scutra ‘wooden platter’.
meaning: a small kitchen or room at the back of a house used for washing dishes and other dirty household work.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a flash of lightning with a simultaneous crash of thunder.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to the thorax

origins: mid 19th century: French entente (cordiale) ‘(friendly) understanding’.
meaning: a friendly understanding or informal alliance between states or factions.

origins: late Middle English: from French, from Latin dentifricium, from dens, dent- ‘tooth’ + fricare ‘to rub’.
meaning: a paste or powder for cleaning the teeth.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: you think that they are extremely silly, showing a lack of intelligence or thought.

origins: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vol and German voll .
meaning: containing or holding as much or as many as possible; having no empty space.;not lacking or omitting anything; complete.;(of a person's figure or part of the body) plump or rounded.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or characteristic of Namibia;a native or inhabitant of Namibia

origins: Italian, from canna ‘reed’.
meaning: a dessert consisting of small deep-fried pastry tubes with a creamy filling, typically of sweetened ricotta cheese.

origins: late 16th century: of unknown origin, but first recorded in a work by Thomas Nashe, as a term of abuse for a crank or pedant, later coming to denote a whim or fancy, also a pun. Current senses date from the late 17th century.
meaning: a confusing and difficult problem or question.

origins: Provençal; compare with pesto.
meaning: sauce or paste made from crushed basil, garlic, and cheese, used especially in Provençal dishes.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a state of total disorder;a butcher's slaughterhouse (archaic except in place names)

origins: Middle English: from Old French porpos, from the verb porposer, variant of proposer (see propose).
meaning: the reason for which something is done or created or for which something exists.;a person's sense of resolve or determination.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin corollarium ‘money paid for a garland or chaplet; gratuity’ (in late Latin ‘deduction’), from corolla, diminutive of corona ‘wreath, crown, chaplet’.
meaning: a proposition that follows from (and is often appended to) one already proved.

origins: French, past participle of consommer ‘consume or consummate’, from Latin consummare ‘make complete’ (see consummate).
meaning: a clear soup made with concentrated stock.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: involving hard or tedious work

origins: Middle English fylberd, from Anglo-Norman French philbert, dialect French noix de filbert (so named because it is ripe about 20 August, the feast day of St Philibert).
meaning: a cultivated hazel tree that bears edible oval nuts.;a brush with bristles forming a flattened oval head, used in oil painting.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘very painful or distressing’): from Latin pungent- ‘pricking’, from the verb pungere .
meaning: having a sharply strong taste or smell.

origins: mid 17th century (in the Latin sense): from Latin, literally ‘little thing, trifle’, once thought to mean ‘that which sticks to a bean’, hence the current sense (mid 18th century).
meaning: the scar on a seed marking the point of attachment to its seed vessel.

origins: Italian, literally ‘robbed’.
meaning: the temporary disregarding of strict tempo to allow an expressive quickening or slackening, usually without altering the overall pace.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin emollient- ‘making soft’, from the verb emollire, from e- (variant of ex- ‘out’) + mollis ‘soft’.
meaning: having the quality of softening or soothing the skin.;attempting to avoid confrontation or anger; calming or conciliatory.

origins: mid 18th century: from French clarinette, diminutive of clarine, denoting a kind of bell; related to clarion.
meaning: a woodwind instrument with a single-reed mouthpiece, a cylindrical tube with a flared end, and holes stopped by keys.

origins: late 16th century (in sultana (sense 2)): from Italian, feminine of sultano (see sultan). sultana (sense 1) dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: a small, light brown, seedless raisin used in foods such as puddings and cakes.;a wife or concubine of a sultan.

origins: early 16th century: from Latin malevolent- ‘wishing evil’, from male ‘ill’ + volent- ‘wishing’ (from the verb velle ).
meaning: having or showing a wish to do evil to others.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin theatrum, from Greek theatron, from theasthai ‘behold’.
meaning: a building or outdoor area in which plays and other dramatic performances are given.;a room or hall for lectures with seats in tiers.;the area in which something happens.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘encircled’): from Latin succinctus ‘tucked up’, past participle of succingere, from sub- ‘from below’ + cingere ‘gird’.
meaning: (especially of something written or spoken) briefly and clearly expressed.

origins: Middle English (also in the sense ‘sweet music’): from Old French melodie, via late Latin from Greek melōidia, from melos ‘song’.
meaning: a sequence of single notes that is musically satisfying; a tune.

origins: mid 19th century: named after Rugby School (see Rugby), where the game was first played.
meaning: a team game played with an oval ball that may be kicked, carried, and passed from hand to hand. Points are scored by grounding the ball behind the opponents' goal line (thereby scoring a try) or by kicking it between the two posts and over the crossbar of the opponents' goal.

origins: Middle English (in fountain (sense 2 of the noun)): from Old French fontaine, from late Latin fontana, feminine of Latin fontanus, adjective from fons, font- ‘a spring’.
meaning: an ornamental structure in a pool or lake from which one or more jets of water are pumped into the air.;a natural spring of water.;a roundel barry wavy argent and azure (i.e. a circle with wavy horizontal stripes of white and blue).

origins: late 18th century: from medieval Latin oriolus (in Old French oriol ), from Latin aureolus, diminutive of aureus ‘golden’, from aurum ‘gold’.
meaning: a tree-dwelling Old World bird of which the male typically has bright yellow and black plumage.;a New World bird of the American blackbird family, with black and orange or yellow plumage.

origins: early 18th century: from French pédestre or Latin pedester ‘going on foot’, also ‘written in prose’ + -ian. Early use in English was in the description of writing as ‘prosaic’.
meaning: a person walking rather than travelling in a vehicle.

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin apothecarius, from Latin apotheca, from Greek apothēkē ‘storehouse’.
meaning: a person who prepared and sold medicines and drugs.

origins: Middle English (also denoting a whale): from Old French baleine, from Latin balaena ‘whale’.
meaning: whalebone.

origins: early 19th century (as a noun): from modern Latin invertebrata (plural) ‘the invertebrates’ (former taxonomic group), from French invertébrés, from in- ‘without’ + Latin vertebra (see vertebra).
meaning: an animal lacking a backbone, such as an arthropod, mollusc, annelid, coelenterate, etc. The invertebrates constitute an artificial division of the animal kingdom, comprising 95 per cent of animal species and about thirty different phyla.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: speaking in a specified way

origins: late 16th century (denoting a thrust or bout in fencing; also in the Law sense): from Old French, literally ‘a coming’, feminine past participle of venir ‘come’ from Latin venire .
meaning: the place where something happens, especially an organized event such as a concert, conference, or sports competition.

origins: late 16th century (in the senses ‘fortify’ and ‘shelter within or behind a fortification’; formerly also as insconce ): from en-1, in-2 ‘in’ + sconce2.
meaning: establish or settle (someone) in a comfortable, safe place.

origins: Middle English: from Middle Dutch, Middle Low German schōre ; perhaps related to the verb shear.
meaning: the land along the edge of a sea, lake, or other large body of water.

origins: late Middle English: via late Latin from Greek sunkopē, from sun- ‘together’ + koptein ‘strike, cut off’.
meaning: temporary loss of consciousness caused by a fall in blood pressure.;the omission of sounds or letters from within a word, for example when library is pronounced /ˈlʌɪbri/.

origins: Unknown
meaning: prepared or garnished with usually white seedless grapes

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: only just; almost not

origins: mid 18th century: origin uncertain; recorded in the late 17th century as a nickname; perhaps from Dutch Janke, diminutive of Jan ‘John’.
meaning: an American.;an inhabitant of New England or one of the northern states.;a bet on four or more horses to win (or be placed) in different races.;a large jib set forward of a staysail in light winds.;a code word representing the letter Y, used in radio communication.

origins: Portuguese.
meaning: a system of physical discipline and movement originating among Brazilian slaves, treated as a martial art and dance form.

origins: late 16th century: probably a variant of crest.
meaning: a line or ridge produced on paper or cloth by folding, pressing, or crushing.;any of a number of lines marked on the pitch at specified places.;an area around the goal in ice hockey or lacrosse which the players may not enter unless the puck or the ball has already done so.

origins: mid 16th century: via Latin from Greek arkhetupon ‘something moulded first as a model’, from arkhe- ‘primitive’ + tupos ‘a model’.
meaning: a very typical example of a certain person or thing.;(in Jungian theory) a primitive mental image inherited from the earliest human ancestors, and supposed to be present in the collective unconscious.;a recurrent symbol or motif in literature, art, or mythology.

origins: mid 19th century: perhaps from blow1.
meaning: talk at length, especially in an inflated or empty way.

origins: Unknown
meaning: abnormal form or structureá:ádevelopmental abnormality; love of the marvelous : worship of monsters

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: pointlessness or uselessness

origins: late 19th century: from tachy- ‘swift’ + Greek kardia ‘heart’.
meaning: an abnormally rapid heart rate.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the quality of being pompous; self-importance

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin crepusculum ‘twilight’ + -ar1.
meaning: resembling or relating to twilight.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French ospres, apparently based on Latin ossifraga (mentioned by Pliny and identified with the lammergeier), from os ‘bone’ + frangere ‘to break’, probably because of the lammergeier's habit of dropping bones from a height to break them and reach the marrow.
meaning: a large fish-eating bird of prey with long, narrow wings and a white underside and crown, found throughout the world.

origins: Old English fann (as a noun denoting a device for winnowing grain), fannian (verb), from Latin vannus ‘winnowing fan’. Compare with vane.
meaning: an apparatus with rotating blades that creates a current of air for cooling or ventilation.;a handheld device, typically folding and shaped like a segment of a circle when spread out, that is waved so as to cool the person holding it.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to an isotope or isotopes of an element

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘engaged in warfare’): from Old French, or from Latin militant- ‘serving as a soldier’, from the verb militare (see militate). The current sense dates from the early 20th century.
meaning: favouring confrontational or violent methods in support of a political or social cause.

origins: mid 17th century: from late Latin quadrilaterus (from Latin quadri- ‘four’ + latus, later- ‘side’) + -al.
meaning: a four-sided figure.

origins: mid 16th century: the noun from Italian corallina, diminutive of corallo ‘coral’, the adjective (mid 17th century) from French corallin or late Latin corallinus, both based on Latin corallum ‘coral’.
meaning: a branching reddish seaweed with a calcareous jointed stem.

origins: 1950s: from late Latin, neuter plural (used as a noun) of realis ‘relating to things’ (see real1).
meaning: objects and material from everyday life used as teaching aids.

origins: Middle English (in the senses ‘reckless, violent’ and ‘intractable, obstinate’): shortening of Old French esturdi ‘stunned, dazed’. The derivation remains obscure; thought by some to be based on Latin turdus ‘a thrush’ (compare with the French phrase soûl comme une grive ‘drunk as a thrush’).
meaning: (of a person or their body) strongly and solidly built.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: abnormality in a physiological rhythm, especially in the activity of the brain or heart

origins: French, from roc ‘rock’.
meaning: an 18th-century artistic or architectural style of decoration characterized by elaborate ornamentation with pebbles and shells, typical of grottos and fountains.;a tiny ornamental bead.

origins: late 16th century (originally as a heraldic term meaning ‘represent the head or limb of an animal with a jagged edge’): from Latin eras- ‘scraped away’, from the verb eradere, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out’ + radere ‘scrape’.
meaning: rub out or remove (writing or marks).

origins: early 20th century: from French, from Italian scar(i)ola, based on Latin esca ‘food’.
meaning: an endive of a variety with broad undivided leaves and a slightly bitter flavour, used in salads.

origins: mid 18th century: via Latin from Greek podion, diminutive of pous, pod- ‘foot’.
meaning: a small platform on which a person may stand to be seen by an audience, as when making a speech or conducting an orchestra.

origins: mid 18th century: probably of Celtic origin and related to Welsh bwci bo ‘bogey, the Devil’, bwci ‘hobgoblin’ and Cornish bucca .
meaning: an object of fear or alarm; a bogey.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin dissipat- ‘scattered’, from the verb dissipare, from dis- ‘apart, widely’ + supare ‘to throw’.
meaning: (with reference to a feeling or emotion) disappear or cause to disappear.;waste or fritter away (money, energy, or resources).

origins: from Italian.
meaning: a soft, mild Italian cream cheese.

origins: late 18th century: from cole; the origin of the second element is uncertain but it is said that cannonballs were used to mash such vegetables as spinach.
meaning: an Irish and Scottish dish of cabbage and potatoes boiled and mashed together.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: cause (someone) to have a wrong idea or impression about someone or something

origins: late 15th century: from Latin trepidatio(n- ), from trepidare ‘be agitated, tremble’, from trepidus ‘alarmed’.
meaning: a feeling of fear or anxiety about something that may happen.;trembling movements or motion.

origins: late 19th century: modern Latin, feminine (used as a noun) of floribundus ‘freely flowering’, from Latin flos, flor- ‘flower’, influenced by Latin abundus ‘copious’.
meaning: a plant, especially a rose, which bears dense clusters of flowers.

origins: from Latin planta genista ‘sprig of broom’, said to be worn as a crest by and given as a nickname to Geoffrey, count of Anjou, the father of Henry II.
meaning: relating to the English royal dynasty which held the throne from the accession of Henry II in 1154 until the death of Richard III in 1485.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: without suffering any injury, damage, or harm

origins: early 19th century: French, literally ‘head’.
meaning: a professional cook, typically the chief cook in a restaurant or hotel.

origins: Unknown
meaning: conferring or conveying honor

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the largest satellite of Pluto, discovered in 1978. Its diameter of 789 miles (1,270 km) is more than half that of Pluto.;an old man who ferried the souls of the dead across the Styx and Acheron Rivers to Hades.

origins: mid 19th century: from Adnyamathanha yuru;Etymology Unknown
meaning: the common wallaroo.;the single European currency, which replaced the national currencies of France, Germany, Spain, Italy, Greece, Portugal, Luxembourg, Austria, Finland, the Republic of Ireland, Belgium, and the Netherlands in 2002. Nineteen member states of the European Union now use the euro.;European, especially concerned with the European Union

origins: late 15th century: from Latin, literally ‘poor’. The word's use in English originated in the Latin legal phrase in forma pauperis, literally ‘in the form of a poor person’ (allowing non-payment of costs).
meaning: a very poor person.

origins: Italian, literally ‘sweet’.
meaning: (especially as a direction) sweetly and softly.

origins: early 17th century: from Carib balatá .
meaning: a tropical American tree which bears edible fruit and produces latex.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: feeling, expressing, or causing great pleasure and happiness

origins: late 16th century: from Latin abstrusus ‘put away, hidden’, from abstrudere ‘conceal’, from ab- ‘from’ + trudere ‘to push’.
meaning: difficult to understand; obscure.

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘alternation’): from French, or from Latin vicissitudo, from vicissim ‘by turns’, from vic- ‘turn, change’.
meaning: a change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant.;alternation between opposite or contrasting things.

origins: Unknown
meaning: possessing or exhibiting valor; brave; courageous

origins: late 17th century: from Greek diakritikos, from diakrinein ‘distinguish’, from dia- ‘through’ + krinein ‘to separate’.
meaning: a sign, such as an accent or cedilla, which when written above or below a letter indicates a difference in pronunciation from the same letter when unmarked or differently marked.

origins: early 19th century (originally of a person): probably the second element of mumbo jumbo. Originally denoting a large and clumsy person, the term was popularized as the name of an elephant at London Zoo, sold in 1882 to the Barnum and Bailey circus.
meaning: a very large person or thing.

origins: late Middle English: from medieval Latin gestura, from Latin gerere ‘bear, wield, perform’. The original sense was ‘bearing, deportment’, hence ‘the use of posture and bodily movements for effect in oratory’.
meaning: a movement of part of the body, especially a hand or the head, to express an idea or meaning.

origins: mid 16th century. From classical Latin nocīvus harmful from nocēre to hurt, injure + -īvus
meaning: Harmful, injurious.

origins: Old English calu  ‘bald’, of West Germanic origin, probably from Latin calvus ‘bald’. This was extended to mean ‘unfledged’, which led to the present sense ‘immature’.
meaning: (of a young person) inexperienced and immature.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person devoted to reading.;the larva of a wood-boring beetle that feeds on the paper and glue in books.

origins: Middle English: of Germanic origin, related to Dutch droom and German Traum, and probably also to Old English drēam ‘joy, music’.
meaning: a series of thoughts, images, and sensations occurring in a person's mind during sleep.;a cherished aspiration, ambition, or ideal.

origins: Italian, literally ‘400’ (shortened from milquattrocento ‘1400’), used with reference to the years 1400–99.
meaning: the 15th century as a period of Italian art or architecture.

origins: Old English gārlēac, from gār  ‘spear’ (because the shape of a clove resembles the head of a spear) + lēac ‘leek’.
meaning: a strong-smelling pungent-tasting bulb, used as a flavouring in cooking and in herbal medicine.;the central Asian plant, closely related to the onion, which produces garlic.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin vincibilis, from vincere ‘to overcome’.
meaning: (of an opponent or obstacle) able to be overcome or conquered.

origins: late Middle English, ‘laden, equipped’, past participle of obsolete fraught  ‘load with cargo’, from Middle Dutch vrachten, from vracht ‘ship's cargo’. Compare with freight.
meaning: (of a situation or course of action) filled with or likely to result in (something undesirable).;causing or affected by anxiety or stress.

origins: Unknown
meaning: excision of the liver or of a part of the liver

origins: late Middle English: from Latin frivolus ‘silly, trifling’ + -ous.
meaning: not having any serious purpose or value.

origins: from Arabic burġul (see burghul).
meaning: a stew or thick soup, typically one served at an outdoor meal.;a thick porridge.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin decennium ‘a decade’, from decennis ‘of ten years’ (from decem ‘ten’ + annus ‘year’), + -al.
meaning: recurring every ten years.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin sculptura, from sculpere ‘carve’.
meaning: the art of making two- or three-dimensional representative or abstract forms, especially by carving stone or wood or by casting metal or plaster.

origins: early 17th century: from Italian, Spanish, or Portuguese, originally in the sense ‘wild ass’, perhaps ultimately from Latin equiferus, from equus ‘horse’ + ferus ‘wild’.
meaning: an African wild horse with black-and-white stripes and an erect mane.;a large butterfly with pale stripes on a dark background.;a silvery-gold sea bream with vertical black stripes.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a county in northern England, traditionally divided into East, West, and North Ridings.

origins: early 19th century: from Latin praesentient- ‘perceiving beforehand’, from the verb praesentire, from prae ‘before’ + sentire ‘to feel’.
meaning: having a presentiment.

origins: mid 19th century: from French comédienne, feminine of comédien (see comedian).
meaning: a female comedian.

origins: Middle English: from Old French perillous, from Latin periculosus, from periculum ‘danger’ (see peril).
meaning: full of danger or risk.

origins: mid 19th century. From allo- + -onym, probably after French allonyme
meaning: The name of another person which has been assumed by the actual author of a work; (more generally) any name assumed by someone; a pseudonym, an alias. Also (occasionally): a book purporting to be by someone other than its actual author.

origins: Unknown
meaning: áa piece of highly cultivated land (as for an orchard) in Spain

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin quotidianus, earlier cotidianus, from cotidie ‘daily’.
meaning: of or occurring every day; daily.;denoting the malignant form of malaria.

origins: Middle English: from Middle Low German bōgsprēt, Middle Dutch boechspriet, from boech ‘bow’ + spriet ‘sprit’.
meaning: a spar running out from a ship's bow, to which the forestays are fastened.

origins: late 17th century: from Latin deciduus (from decidere ‘fall down or off’) + -ous.
meaning: (of a tree or shrub) shedding its leaves annually.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French assurer, based on Latin ad- ‘to’ (expressing change) + securus (see secure).
meaning: tell someone something positively to dispel any doubts.;make (something) certain to happen.;cover (a life) by assurance.

origins: Middle English: from Old French cisterne, from Latin cisterna, from cista ‘box’ (see cist).
meaning: a tank for storing water, especially one supplying taps or as part of a flushing toilet.

origins: mid 19th century: Latinized form of earlier osmose, from Greek ōsmos ‘a push’.
meaning: a process by which molecules of a solvent tend to pass through a semipermeable membrane from a less concentrated solution into a more concentrated one.;the process of gradual or unconscious assimilation of ideas, knowledge, etc.

origins: Spanish, literally ‘goatsucker’, from chupar ‘to suck’ + cabra ‘goat’.
meaning: an animal said to exist in parts of Latin America, where it supposedly attacks animals, especially goats.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin culinarius, from culina ‘kitchen’.
meaning: of or for cooking.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who practices necromancy; a wizard or magician.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘harshness, severity, cruel treatment’): via Old French from Latin duritia, from durus ‘hard’.
meaning: threats, violence, constraints, or other action used to coerce someone into doing something against their will or better judgement.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a bird, etc.) producing young by means of eggs that are hatched after they have been laid by the parent.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin leoninus, from leo, leon- ‘lion’.
meaning: of or resembling a lion or lions.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a large thin potato pancake served buttered and folded

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or resembling farce, especially because of absurd or ridiculous aspects

origins: Unknown
meaning: condition of áinflammation of the matrix of the nail leading to suppuration and loss of the nail or onychia

origins: Unknown
meaning: any of several succulent marine algae especially of the genusáGloiopeltisáthat furnish a tough glue

origins: early 16th century: from Old French, from late Latin combustibilis, from Latin combust- ‘burnt up’, from the verb comburere .
meaning: able to catch fire and burn easily.

origins: French, from haut ‘high’.
meaning: proud haughtiness of manner.

origins: mid 17th century (in emphysema (sense 2)): via late Latin from Greek emphusēma, from emphusan ‘puff up’.
meaning: a condition in which the air sacs of the lungs are damaged and enlarged, causing breathlessness.;a condition in which air is abnormally present within the body tissues.

origins: Unknown
meaning: aristocrats

origins: early 19th century: perhaps named after Ned Lud, a participant in the destruction of machinery, + -ite1.
meaning: a person opposed to new technology or ways of working.;a member of any of the bands of English workers who destroyed machinery, especially in cotton and woollen mills, that they believed was threatening their jobs (1811–16).

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a shell-less marine mollusk of the order Nudibranchia; a sea slug.

origins: Middle English: from Old French holocauste, via late Latin from Greek holokauston, from holos ‘whole’ + kaustos ‘burnt’ (from kaiein ‘burn’).
meaning: destruction or slaughter on a mass scale, especially caused by fire or nuclear war.;a Jewish sacrificial offering that was burned completely on an altar.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a straight slipover one-piece garment that is made by folding a rectangle of material end to end, sewing up the straight sides but leaving openings near the folded top for the arms, and cutting a slit or a square in the center of the fold to furnish an opening for the head, is often decorated with embroidery, and is worn as a blouse or dress by women chiefly in Mexico and Central America

origins: Unknown
meaning: of or relating to bird

origins: Latin (also denoting the periwinkle), from Greek klēmatis, from klēma ‘vine branch’.
meaning: a climbing plant of the buttercup family which bears white, pink, or purple flowers and feathery seeds. Several kinds are cultivated as ornamentals.

origins: late Middle English: from French, from Latin cartilago, cartilagin- .
meaning: firm, flexible connective tissue found in various forms in the larynx and respiratory tract, in structures such as the external ear, and in the articulating surfaces of joints. It is more widespread in the infant skeleton, being replaced by bone during growth.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a nerve cell) having two axons, one either side of the cell body.;(of a transistor or other device) using both positive and negative charge carriers.;(of psychiatric illness) characterized by both manic and depressive episodes, or manic ones only.;having or relating to two poles or extremities

origins: mid 16th century: from obsolete grate ‘pleasing, thankful’ (from Latin gratus ) + -ful.
meaning: feeling or showing an appreciation for something done or received.

origins: late Middle English: from medieval Latin cornea tela ‘horny tissue’, from Latin cornu ‘horn’.
meaning: the transparent layer forming the front of the eye.

origins: mid 17th century: alteration of dialect simper (in the same sense), perhaps imitative.
meaning: (of water or food that is being heated) stay just below boiling point while bubbling gently.

origins: late 16th century: from Dutch cassier or French caissier, from caisse ‘cash’.
meaning: a person handling payments and receipts in a shop, bank, or business.

origins: late 19th century: named after A.-H. Becquerel (see Becquerel, Antoine-Henri).
meaning: the SI unit of radioactivity, corresponding to one disintegration per second.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin aestivalis, from aestivus, from aestus ‘heat’.
meaning: belonging to or appearing in summer.

origins: early 19th century: from French, from Latin bolis, bolid-, from Greek bolis ‘missile’.
meaning: a large meteor which explodes in the atmosphere.

origins: early 18th century: from French mignonnette, diminutive of mignon ‘small and sweet’.
meaning: a herbaceous plant with spikes of small fragrant greenish flowers.

origins: Old English weder, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch weer and German Wetter, probably also to the noun wind1.
meaning: the state of the atmosphere at a particular place and time as regards heat, cloudiness, dryness, sunshine, wind, rain, etc.

origins: 1970s: blend of endogenous and morphine.
meaning: any of a group of hormones secreted within the brain and nervous system and having a number of physiological functions. They are peptides which activate the body's opiate receptors, causing an analgesic effect.

origins: 1940s (in degauss (sense 3)): from de- + gauss.
meaning: remove unwanted magnetism from (a television or monitor) in order to correct colour disturbance.;destroy the data on (a data storage device) by removing its magnetism.;neutralize the magnetic field of (a ship) by encircling it with a conductor carrying electric currents.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a practitioner of osteopathy

origins: mid 17th century: probably an alteration of squeal, influenced by bawl.
meaning: a sudden violent gust of wind or localized storm, especially one bringing rain, snow, or sleet.;a loud cry.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the activity or practice of posting short videos to or maintaining a vlog

origins: late Middle English: from Old French heroique or Latin heroicus, from Greek hērōikos ‘relating to heroes’, from hērōs ‘hero’.
meaning: having the characteristics of a hero or heroine; admirably brave or determined.;(of language or a work of art) grand or grandiose in scale or intention.

origins: mid 19th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: a matter, operation, or set of circumstances.;a rough hut or shelter.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French tronc, from Latin truncus .
meaning: the main woody stem of a tree as distinct from its branches and roots.;a person's or animal's body apart from the limbs and head.;the elongated, prehensile nose of an elephant.;a large box with a hinged lid for storing or transporting clothes and other articles.

origins: early 17th century: from French doublon or its source, Spanish doblón, from doble ‘double’ (so named because the coin was worth double the value of a pistole).
meaning: a Spanish gold coin.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a Basque song or dance in ?/? time and dotted rhythm

origins: early 20th century: variant of dialect scrunge  ‘steal’.
meaning: seek to obtain (something, typically food or money) at the expense or through the generosity of others or by stealth.

origins: late 15th century: from late Latin mellifluus (from mel ‘honey’ + fluere ‘to flow’) + -ous.
meaning: (of a sound) pleasingly smooth and musical to hear.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a person's expression or behavior) indicating mild or amused puzzlement

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the process by which fertile land becomes desert, typically as a result of drought, deforestation, or inappropriate agriculture

origins: 1930s: alteration of music.
meaning: recorded light background music played through speakers in public places.

origins: from German Schnitzel, literally ‘slice’.
meaning: a thin slice of veal or other light meat, coated in breadcrumbs and fried.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a salad plate consisting of chopped or sliced meats, anchovies, hard-cooked eggs, pickled vegetables, olives, radishes, endive, and watercress that are arranged in rows for color and flavor contrast and dressed with a salad dressing; a heterogeneous mixture : medley, potpourri

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘despising law and order’): from medieval Latin contemptuosus, from Latin contemptus ‘contempt’, from contemnere (see contemn).
meaning: showing contempt; scornful.

origins: Middle English: from the rare verb slug  ‘be lazy or slow’ + -ard.
meaning: a lazy, sluggish person.

origins: Unknown
meaning: áwelcomeáŚformerly common in English but now usually a conscious borrowing from the French; obsolete : an entry fee demanded from a new worker by fellow workers

origins: Latin.
meaning: mother.

origins: Old English wæter (noun), wæterian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch water, German Wasser, from an Indo-European root shared by Russian voda (compare with vodka), also by Latin unda ‘wave’ and Greek hudōr ‘water’.
meaning: a colourless, transparent, odourless liquid that forms the seas, lakes, rivers, and rain and is the basis of the fluids of living organisms.;a stretch or area of water, such as a river, sea, or lake.;urine.;the amniotic fluid surrounding a fetus in the womb, especially as discharged in a flow shortly before birth.;the quality of transparency and brilliance shown by a diamond or other gem.;capital stock that represents a book value greater than the true assets of a company.

origins: Unknown
meaning: capitalizedá:áthe type genus of Janthinidae comprising pelagic snails of warm seas that have a thin spiral purple shell, a large head, and protrusible gills

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘disturbance of one's quietness or rest’): from Old French, or from late Latin inquietudo, from Latin inquietus, from in- ‘not’ + quietus ‘quiet’.
meaning: physical or mental restlessness or disturbance.

origins: late 17th century: from French, from Old French glacier ‘to slip’, from glace ‘ice’, based on Latin glacies .
meaning: a bank sloping down from a fort which exposes attackers to the defenders' missiles.;a sloping piece of armour plate protecting part of a vehicle.

origins: mid 17th century: from French polyglotte, from Greek poluglōttos, from polu- ‘many’ + glōtta ‘tongue’.
meaning: knowing or using several languages.

origins: late 16th century: from Old French apportionner or medieval Latin apportionare, from ad- ‘to’ + portionare ‘divide into portions’.
meaning: divide up and share out.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a river in northern India and Bangladesh that rises in the Himalayas and flows southwest for about 1,678 miles (2,700 km) to the Bay of Bengal, where it forms the world's largest delta. The river is regarded by Hindus as sacred.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin homicidium, from homo, homin- ‘man’.
meaning: the killing of one person by another.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from medieval Latin acuta (febris) ‘acute (fever)’.
meaning: malaria or another illness involving fever and shivering.

origins: Middle English: from Old French soutilte, from Latin subtilitas, from subtilis ‘fine, delicate’ (see subtle).
meaning: the quality or state of being subtle.

origins: late Middle English: from Old English twi-  ‘two’ (used in an obscure sense in this compound) + light1.
meaning: the soft glowing light from the sky when the sun is below the horizon, caused by the reflection of the sun's rays from the atmosphere.;a period or state of obscurity, ambiguity, or gradual decline.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a red light at the rear of a motor vehicle, train, or bicycle.

origins: late 15th century: plural of Anglo-Norman French estover, noun use of a verb meaning ‘be necessary’, based on Latin est opus ‘it is necessary’.
meaning: the right to take wood from land one does not own, especially land of which one is the tenant or lessee.

origins: late 16th century: from French procédure, from procéder (see proceed).
meaning: an established or official way of doing something.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin tempestuosus, from Latin tempestas (see tempest).
meaning: characterized by strong and turbulent or conflicting emotion.;very stormy.

origins: from Italian (Ligurian dialect) ciuppin or cuipin, ultimately from Spanish chupar ‘to suck, sip’.
meaning: an Italian American stew of seafood cooked with tomatoes and wine.

origins: mid 17th century (first recorded in the Greek sense): from Greek, literally ‘depth’. The current sense was introduced by Alexander Pope in the early 18th century.
meaning: (especially in a literary work) an effect of anticlimax created by an unintentional lapse in mood from the sublime to the trivial or ridiculous.

origins: early 16th century: from dialect whimp  ‘to whimper’, of imitative origin.
meaning: make a series of low, feeble sounds expressive of fear, pain, or unhappiness.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin arteria, from Greek artēria, probably from airein ‘raise’.
meaning: any of the muscular-walled tubes forming part of the circulation system by which blood (mainly that which has been oxygenated) is conveyed from the heart to all parts of the body.;an important route in a system of roads, rivers, or railway lines.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a careful and prudent manner, especially in order to keep something confidential or to avoid embarrassment

origins: late Middle English: from French, from Latin murmuratio(n- ), from murmurare ‘to murmur’. The usage as a collective noun dates from the late 15th century.
meaning: a flock of starlings.;the action of murmuring.

origins: Unknown
meaning: áa Swiss breed of black and white cattle used for dairy, meat, and draft

origins: Old English ( ge)recenian ‘recount, relate’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch rekenen and German rechnen ‘to count (up)’. Early senses included ‘give an account of items received’ and ‘mention things in order’, which gave rise to the notion of ‘calculation’ and hence of ‘being of an opinion’.
meaning: establish by calculation.;consider or regard in a specified way.;be of the opinion.

origins: early 19th century (originally a North American usage): from French, ‘fall’ (of water or rocks), from Old French cheoite, feminine past participle of cheoir ‘to fall’, from Latin cadere ; influenced by shoot.
meaning: a sloping channel or slide for conveying things to a lower level.;a narrow metal enclosure for holding or restraining livestock, in which an animal may be vaccinated, branded, etc.

origins: late 19th century (in the general sense ‘motorist’): from French, literally ‘stoker’ (by association with steam engines), from chauffer ‘to heat’.
meaning: a person employed to drive a private or hired car.

origins: mid 18th century: from Portuguese, from Tupi-Guarani jakara'nda .
meaning: a tropical American tree that has blue trumpet-shaped flowers, fernlike leaves, and fragrant timber.

origins: Middle English (in the senses ‘statuary, carved images collectively’): from Old French imagerie, from imager ‘make an image’, from image (see image).
meaning: visually descriptive or figurative language, especially in a literary work.;visual images collectively.

origins: Middle English: from Old French calendier, from Latin kalendarium ‘account book’, from kalendae (see calends).
meaning: a chart or series of pages showing the days, weeks, and months of a particular year, or giving particular seasonal information.

origins: early 17th century (in the dialect sense ‘carry about’): back-formation from the noun cadger, which dates from the late 15th century, denoting (in northern English and Scots) an itinerant dealer, whence the verb sense ‘hawk, peddle’, giving rise to the current verb senses from the early 19th century.
meaning: ask for or obtain (something to which one is not strictly entitled).

origins: mid 18th century: from French prédilection, from Latin praedilect- ‘preferred’, from the verb praediligere, from prae ‘in advance’ + diligere ‘to select’.
meaning: a preference or special liking for something; a bias in favour of something.

origins: Middle English: shortening of Old French espace, from Latin spatium . Current verb senses date from the late 17th century.
meaning: a continuous area or expanse which is free, available, or unoccupied.;the dimensions of height, depth, and width within which all things exist and move.;an interval of time (often used to suggest that the time is short considering what has happened or been achieved in it).;the portion of a text or document available or needed to write about a subject.;the freedom to live, think, and develop in a way that suits one.;one of two possible states of a signal in certain systems.

origins: Old English rib, ribb (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch rib(be ) and German Rippe . Sense 1 of the verb dates from the mid 16th century; the sense ‘tease’ was originally a US slang usage meaning ‘to fool, dupe’ (1930s).
meaning: each of a series of slender curved bones articulated in pairs to the spine (twelve pairs in humans), protecting the thoracic cavity and its organs.;a long raised piece of strengthening or supporting material.;a vein of a leaf or an insect's wing.;a combination of alternate plain and purl stitches producing a ridged, slightly elastic fabric.

origins: Middle English: from Old French boissel, perhaps of Gaulish origin.
meaning: a measure of capacity equal to 8 gallons (equivalent to 36.4 litres), used for corn, fruit, liquids, etc.;a measure of capacity equal to 64 US pints (equivalent to 35.2 litres), used for dry goods.

origins: Italian, from fritto, past participle of friggere ‘to fry’. Compare with fritter2.
meaning: an Italian dish made with fried beaten eggs, resembling a Spanish omelette.

origins: Unknown
meaning: one of a late class of Vedic treatises dealing with broad philosophic problems (as the nature of ultimate reality, humankind, and the universe)

origins: late 19th century: from Egyptian, literally ‘life, soul’.
meaning: an object or design resembling a cross but having a loop instead of the top arm, used in ancient Egypt as a symbol of life.

origins: Unknown
meaning: the science of veterinary medicine

origins: mid 19th century; earliest use found in The New Monthly Magazine. From Italian ballabile, noun from ballare to dance + -abile
meaning: A dance performed by the company in a ballet, or by the chorus in an opera; a piece of music accompanying this.

origins: mid 16th century: from late Latin despicabilis, from despicari ‘look down on’.
meaning: deserving hatred and contempt.

origins: early 18th century (in the sense ‘almost imperceptible’): from Latin evanescent- ‘disappearing’, from the verb evanescere (see evanesce).
meaning: soon passing out of sight, memory, or existence; quickly fading or disappearing.;denoting a field or wave which extends into a region where it cannot propagate and whose amplitude therefore decreases with distance.

origins: Middle English: from Old English dragan or Old Norse draga ‘to draw’; the noun partly from Middle Low German dragge ‘grapnel’.
meaning: pull (someone or something) along forcefully, roughly, or with difficulty.;(of time) pass slowly and tediously.;move (an image or highlighted text) across a computer screen using a tool such as a mouse.

origins: late 16th century: from Spanish bravada, from bravo ‘bold’ (see brave, -ado).
meaning: a bold manner or a show of boldness intended to impress or intimidate.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘obtained by suppression of the truth’): from Latin surreptitius (from the verb surripere, from sub- ‘secretly’ + rapere ‘seize’) + -ous.
meaning: kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of.

origins: Italian, dialect alteration of schiavo ‘(I am your) slave’, from medieval Latin sclavus ‘slave’.
meaning: used as a greeting at meeting or parting.

origins: Unknown
meaning: viscid; slimy

origins: early 20th century: from modern Latin, plural of trivium ‘place where three roads meet’, influenced in sense by trivial.
meaning: details, considerations, or pieces of information of little importance or value.

origins: early 18th century (denoting a medicine used to increase the proportion of water in the blood): from Latin diluent- ‘dissolving’, from the verb diluere .
meaning: a substance used to dilute something.

origins: modern Latin, named after J. C. Scheffler, 18th-century German botanist.
meaning: an evergreen tropical or subtropical shrub or small tree which is widely grown as a pot plant for its decorative foliage.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of food or drink) pleasant to taste

origins: late Middle English: from Latin clementia, from clemens, clement- ‘clement’.
meaning: mercy; lenience.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin obloquium ‘contradiction’, from Latin obloqui, from ob- ‘against’ + loqui ‘speak’.
meaning: strong public condemnation.

origins: mid 16th century (in the medical sense): via late Latin from Greek plēthōrē, from plēthein ‘be full’.
meaning: a large or excessive amount of something.;an excess of a bodily fluid, particularly blood.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘no longer alight’): from Latin exstinct- ‘extinguished’, from the verb exstinguere (see extinguish).
meaning: (of a species, family, or other group of animals or plants) having no living members; no longer in existence.;(of a volcano) not having erupted in recorded history.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: marked with spots or rounded patches

origins: 1950s: from Swedish, from ( trampcykel med) mo(tor och) ped(aler ) ‘pedal cycle with motor and pedals’.
meaning: a light motor cycle, especially one with an engine capacity of not more than 50 cc.

origins: Japanese.
meaning: an edible brown seaweed used, typically in dried form, in Chinese and Japanese cooking.

origins: early 20th century: from Turkish, ablative of yar ‘steep bank’.
meaning: a sharp irregular ridge of sand lying in the direction of the prevailing wind in exposed desert regions, formed by the wind erosion of adjacent material which is less resistant.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who has a particular regard for someone or something

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: involving or by means of a vehicle or vehicles

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: showing excessive confidence or pride

origins: mid 19th century: from German Löss, from Swiss German lösch ‘loose’.
meaning: a loosely compacted yellowish-grey deposit of wind-blown sediment of which extensive deposits occur e.g. in eastern China and the American Midwest.

origins: named after the Marquis d'Uxelles, a 17th-century French nobleman.
meaning: a preparation of mushrooms sautéed with onions, shallots, garlic, and parsley and used to make stuffing or sauce.

origins: mid 18th century; earliest use found in Thomas Percy (1729–1811), writer and Church of Ireland bishop of Dromore. From the name of Samuel Pepys, English diarist + -ian
meaning: Of, belonging to, or characteristic of Samuel Pepys, his library, or the age in which he lived; (of a written record or account) resembling the diaries of Pepys, especially in being frank and full of personal detail.

origins: 1960s: blend of stagnation (see stagnate) and inflation.
meaning: persistent high inflation combined with high unemployment and stagnant demand in a country's economy.

origins: mid 19th century: from the liquid aldehyde acrolein (from Latin acer, acri- ‘pungent’ + ol(eum ) ‘oil’ + -in1) + -yl + -ic.
meaning: an acrylic textile fibre.;an acrylic paint.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin, ‘a binding together’, from nex- ‘bound’, from the verb nectere .
meaning: a connection or series of connections linking two or more things.;a central or focal point.

origins: Unknown
meaning: Nosebleed, especially one in which bleeding is profuse

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or derived from alluvium

origins: early 19th century: from modern Latin medium aevum ‘middle age’ + -al.
meaning: relating to the Middle Ages.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: inflammation of the meninges caused by viral or bacterial infection and marked by intense headache and fever, sensitivity to light, and muscular rigidity, leading (in severe cases) to convulsions, delirium, and death.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: give (something) legal or formal status.

origins: mid 19th century: from Greek tauros ‘bull’ (because it was originally obtained from ox bile) + -ine4.
meaning: an amino acid containing sulphur and important in the metabolism of fats.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin patientia, from patient- ‘suffering’, from the verb pati .
meaning: the capacity to accept or tolerate delay, problems, or suffering without becoming annoyed or anxious.;any of various forms of card game for one player, the object of which is to use up all one's cards by forming particular arrangements and sequences.

origins: mid 19th century: modern Latin, from citron + the diminutive suffix -ella .
meaning: a fragrant natural oil used as an insect repellent and in perfume and soap manufacture.;the South Asian grass from which citronella oil is obtained.

origins: late 18th century: from Latin, from demens, dement- ‘out of one's mind’.
meaning: a chronic or persistent disorder of the mental processes caused by brain disease or injury and marked by memory disorders, personality changes, and impaired reasoning.

origins: early 20th century: modern Latin, from Greek ana- ‘again’ + phulaxis ‘guarding’.
meaning: an acute allergic reaction to an antigen (e.g. a bee sting) to which the body has become hypersensitive.

origins: mid 18th century: from French, from Old French mal ‘bad’ (from Latin malus ) + aise ‘ease’.
meaning: a general feeling of discomfort, illness, or unease whose exact cause is difficult to identify.

origins: early 16th century: from French, or from Latin indulgent- ‘giving free rein to’, from the verb indulgere .
meaning: having or indicating a readiness or over-readiness to be generous to or lenient with someone.

origins: late 18th century: from dys- ‘bad’ + utopia.
meaning: an imagined state or society in which there is great suffering or injustice, typically one that is totalitarian or post-apocalyptic.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the arrangement or classification of something into different groups

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: of or resembling a torus.

origins: late 19th century: from Yiddish goylem, from Hebrew gōlem ‘shapeless mass’.
meaning: (in Jewish legend) a clay figure brought to life by magic.

origins: early 20th century: from lysis + a shortened form of enzyme.
meaning: an enzyme which catalyses the destruction of the cell walls of certain bacteria, and occurs notably in tears and egg white.

origins: mid 17th century: from French calebasse, from Spanish calabaza, perhaps from Persian ḵarbuz ‘melon’.
meaning: an evergreen tropical American tree which bears fruit in the form of large woody gourds.

origins: from Glasgow, on the pattern of words such as Norwegian .
meaning: relating to Glasgow.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an instrument for measuring time, especially one designed to keep accurate time in spite of motion or variations in temperature, humidity, and air pressure. Chronometers were first developed for marine navigation, being used in conjunction with astronomical observation to determine longitude.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a country in southwestern North America, with extensive coastlines on the Gulf of Mexico and the Pacific Ocean, bordered by the US on the north; population 127,000,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Mexico City; language, Spanish (official).

origins: early 18th century: from French, from Latin solitarius (see solitary).
meaning: any of various card games played by one person, the object of which is to use up all one's cards by forming particular arrangements and sequences.;a game for one player played by removing pegs one at a time from a board by jumping others over them from adjacent holes, the object being to be left with only one peg.;a diamond or other gem set in a piece of jewellery by itself.;either of two large extinct flightless birds related to the dodo, found on two of the Mascarene Islands until they were exterminated in the 18th century.;a large American thrush with mainly grey plumage and a short bill.

origins: late 16th century: via late Latin from Greek sabbatikos ‘of the sabbath’ + -al.
meaning: a period of paid leave granted to a university teacher or other worker for study or travel, traditionally one year for every seven years worked.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, ‘shoulder’.
meaning: the bone of the upper arm or forelimb, forming joints at the shoulder and the elbow.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a green, blue, or white mineral which is one of the forms of jade. It is a silicate of sodium, aluminum, and iron and belongs to the pyroxene group.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, from Greek gupsos .
meaning: a soft white or grey mineral consisting of hydrated calcium sulphate. It occurs chiefly in sedimentary deposits and is used to make plaster of Paris and fertilizers, and in the building industry.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin loquax, loquac- (from loqui ‘talk’) + -ious.
meaning: tending to talk a great deal; talkative.

origins: mid 16th century (in an earlier sense). From classical Latin pudibundus easily ashamed, bashful, modest, shameful from pudēre to make or be ashamed + -bundus, suffix forming verbal adjectives
meaning: Modest, bashful; prudish.

origins: mid 18th century: from French philharmonique, from Italian filarmonico ‘loving harmony’ (see phil-, harmonic).
meaning: devoted to music (chiefly used in the names of orchestras).

origins: Unknown
meaning: of or relating to hierurgy; of or relating to an act or rite of worship

origins: Unknown
meaning: converse; to talk

origins: mid 19th century: Spanish.
meaning: used to address or refer to a friend, chiefly in Spanish-speaking areas.

origins: Old English me self, from me1 + self (used adjectivally); the change of me to my occurred in Middle English.
meaning: used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself as the object of a verb or preposition when he or she is the subject of the clause.;I or me personally (used to emphasize the speaker).;used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself; I.

origins: mid 19th century: named after J. Bowie (see Bowie, Jim).
meaning: a long knife with a blade that is double-edged at the point.

origins: early 17th century (denoting a covering or coating): from Latin integumentum, from the verb integere, from in- ‘in’ + tegere ‘to cover’.
meaning: a tough outer protective layer, especially that of an animal or plant.

origins: late 18th century: from Swedish, from tung ‘heavy’ + sten ‘stone’.
meaning: the chemical element of atomic number 74, a hard steel-grey metal of the transition series. It has a very high melting point (3410°C) and is used to make electric light filaments.

origins: early 18th century: from earlier stansel  ‘ornament with various colours’ (based on Latin scintilla ‘spark’).
meaning: a thin sheet of card, plastic, or metal with a pattern or letters cut out of it, used to produce the cut design on the surface below by the application of ink or paint through the holes.

origins: Middle English: from Old French tane, from tan ‘tanbark’; related to tan1.
meaning: of an orange-brown or yellowish-brown colour.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a resplendent quality or state; splendor

origins: late Middle English: from Latin ventriculus, diminutive of venter ‘belly’.
meaning: a hollow part or cavity in an organ.

origins: Middle English: from Old French fourrage (noun), fourrager (verb), from fuerre ‘straw’, of Germanic origin and related to fodder.
meaning: (of a person or animal) search widely for food or provisions.

origins: early 19th century; earliest use found in The Sporting Magazine. From classical Latin subrīdent-, subrīdēns, present participle of subrīdēre to smile
meaning: Characterized by or accompanied by a smile or smiles; wearing a smile; smiling.

origins: from Malayalam, from Sanskrit kathā ‘story’ + Malayalam kaḷi ‘play’.
meaning: a form of dramatic dance of southern India, based on Hindu literature and characterized by masks, stylized costume and make-up, and frequent use of mime.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French sourplus, from medieval Latin superplus, from super- ‘in addition’ + plus ‘more’.
meaning: an amount of something left over when requirements have been met; an excess of production or supply.

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin oppositus, past participle of opponere ‘set against’.
meaning: situated on the other or further side when seen from a specified or implicit viewpoint; facing.;completely different; of a contrary kind.

origins: late Middle English: from un-1 ‘not’ + kempt ‘combed’ (past participle of archaic kemb, related to comb).
meaning: (especially of a person) having an untidy or dishevelled appearance.

origins: late Middle English (originally as an adjective meaning ‘reviling, abusive’): from Old French invectif, -ive, from late Latin invectivus ‘attacking’, from invehere (see inveigh). The noun is from late Latin invectiva (oratio) ‘abusive or censorious (language)’.
meaning: insulting, abusive, or highly critical language.

origins: modern Latin, from Latin velox, veloc- ‘swift’ + raptor.
meaning: a small dromaeosaurid dinosaur of the late Cretaceous period.

origins: 1960s: from German Fussball ‘football’.
meaning: a tabletop version of soccer in which players turn rods fixed on top of a playing box and attached to miniature figures of players, in order to flick the ball and strike it toward the goal.

origins: early 19th century: from Latin nihil ‘nothing’ + -ism.
meaning: the rejection of all religious and moral principles, in the belief that life is meaningless.

origins: Old English heofonlic  (see heaven, -ly1).
meaning: of heaven; divine.;of the heavens or sky.;very pleasing; wonderful.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin, ‘assault, force’, from impetere ‘assail’, from in- ‘towards’ + petere ‘seek’.
meaning: the force or energy with which a body moves.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: deep insight; great depth of knowledge or thought

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an elevated railroad or section of railroad, especially that in Chicago.

origins: early 17th century (originally as tangara ): from Tupi tangará, later refashioned on the pattern of the modern Latin genus name Tanagra .
meaning: a small American songbird of the bunting family, the male of which typically has brightly coloured plumage.

origins: Unknown
meaning: lamb

origins: Etymology Unknown;late Middle English: from Old French marchandise, from marchand ‘merchant’
meaning: promote the sale of (goods), especially by their presentation in retail outlets;goods to be bought and sold

origins: mid 19th century: modern Latin, from French diphthérie (earlier diphthérite ), from Greek diphthera ‘skin, hide’.
meaning: an acute and highly contagious bacterial disease causing inflammation of the mucous membranes, formation of a false membrane in the throat which hinders breathing and swallowing, and potentially fatal heart and nerve damage by a bacterial toxin in the blood. It is now rare in developed countries owing to immunization.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a small piece or brief extract

origins: Middle English: from Old French unce, from Latin uncia ‘twelfth part (of a pound or foot)’; compare with inch1.
meaning: a unit of weight of one sixteenth of a pound avoirdupois (approximately 28 grams).;a very small amount of something.

origins: late 19th century: from Airedale, a district in Yorkshire, where the dog was bred.
meaning: a large terrier of a rough-coated black-and-tan breed.

origins: late Middle English (as a verb): imitative; compare with Flemish rijsselen and Dutch ritselen . The noun dates from the mid 18th century.
meaning: make a soft, muffled crackling sound like that caused by the movement of dry leaves or paper.;round up and steal (cattle, horses, or sheep).;move or act quickly or energetically; hustle.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: deceitful

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘lasting seven days’): from late Latin hebdomadalis, from Greek hebdomas, hebdomad- ‘the number seven, seven days’, from hepta ‘seven’.
meaning: weekly (used especially of organizations that meet weekly).

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘pattern, model’): from Latin, from specere ‘to look’.
meaning: an individual animal, plant, piece of a mineral, etc. used as an example of its species or type for scientific study or display.;used to refer humorously to a person or animal.

origins: mid 17th century: diminutive of lap1.
meaning: the part on each side of a coat or jacket immediately below the collar which is folded back on either side of the front opening.

origins: late 19th century: from Latin resonat- ‘resounded’, from the verb resonare (see resound).
meaning: produce or be filled with a deep, full, reverberating sound.;produce electrical or mechanical resonance.

origins: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘small drinking cup’): of unknown origin.
meaning: a person's head.;a small quantity of alcoholic drink, typically a quarter of a pint.

origins: late 16th century: from French billard, denoting both the game and the cue, diminutive of bille (see billet2).
meaning: a game for two people, played on a billiard table, in which three balls are struck with cues into pockets round the edge of the tabl, with points scored by cannons, pocketing an object ball, or cannoning the cue ball into a pocket. In North America the game is known as English billiards.

origins: from Greek iōta . iota (sense 2) arose because iota is the smallest letter of the Greek alphabet: compare with jot.
meaning: the ninth letter of the Greek alphabet ( Ι, ι ), transliterated as ‘i’.;an extremely small amount.

origins: early 19th century: named after Mackinaw City, Michigan, formerly an important trading post.
meaning: a short coat or jacket made of a thick woollen cloth, typically with a plaid design.

origins: mid 16th century: from Spanish flamengo, earlier form of flamenco (see flamenco); associated, because of its colour, with Latin flamma ‘a flame’.
meaning: a tall wading bird with mainly pink or scarlet plumage and long legs and neck. It has a heavy bent bill that is held upside down in the water in order to filter-feed on small organisms.

origins: mid 19th century: from sewer1, by substitution of the suffix -age.
meaning: waste water and excrement conveyed in sewers.

origins: late 17th century: figurative use of Mogul.
meaning: an important or powerful person, especially in the film or media industry.;a steam locomotive of 2-6-0 wheel arrangement.

origins: mid 18th century: probably via Portuguese from Hindi.
meaning: a large coloured handkerchief, typically with white spots, worn tied around the head or neck.

origins: mid 19th century: from French, from preste ‘nimble’ + Latin digitus ‘finger’ + -ation.
meaning: conjuring tricks performed as entertainment.

origins: Middle English: from Old French baniere, ultimately of Germanic origin and related to band2.
meaning: a long strip of cloth bearing a slogan or design, carried in a demonstration or procession or hung in a public place.;a heading or advertisement appearing on a web page in the form of a bar, column, or box.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin gubia, gulbia, perhaps of Celtic origin; compare with Old Irish gulba ‘beak’ and Welsh gylf ‘beak, pointed instrument’.

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘urge on’): from Latin instigat- ‘urged, incited’, from the verb instigare, from in- ‘towards’ + stigare ‘prick, incite’.
meaning: bring about or initiate (an action or event).

origins: early 17th century: from Latin nitidus, from nitere ‘to shine’.
meaning: shining or glossy.

origins: from the name of the hero of Shakespeare's romantic tragedy Romeo and Juliet .
meaning: an attractive, passionate male seducer or lover.;a code word representing the letter R, used in radio communication.

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, based on Latin separare (see sever).
meaning: the action of ending a connection or relationship.;division by cutting or slicing.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin rugosus, from ruga ‘wrinkle’.
meaning: wrinkled; corrugated.

origins: late 18th century: from Scotsingle + nook.
meaning: a space on either side of a large fireplace.

origins: early 20th century: from Greek, literally ‘hot’.
meaning: a vacuum flask.

origins: mid 19th century: from French, humorous alteration of rocaille.
meaning: denoting furniture or architecture characterized by an elaborately ornamental late baroque style of decoration prevalent in 18th-century continental Europe, with asymmetrical patterns involving motifs and scrollwork.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin perspicax, perspicac- ‘seeing clearly’ + -acious.
meaning: having a ready insight into and understanding of things.

origins: Unknown
meaning: an Italian customhouse

origins: late 18th century (in the sense ‘detrition’): from French détritus, from Latin detritus, from deterere ‘wear away’.
meaning: waste or debris of any kind.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin violaceus (from viola ‘violet’) + -ous.
meaning: of a violet colour.;relating to or denoting plants of the violet family ( Violaceae ).

origins: late 19th century; earliest use found in William Flower (1831–1899), zoologist and museum curator. From mega- + -cephalic
meaning: macrocephalic.

origins: early 17th century: from French véracité or medieval Latin veracitas, from verax ‘speaking truly’ (see veracious).
meaning: conformity to facts; accuracy.

origins: Old English dōn, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch doen and German tun, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek tithēmi ‘I place’ and Latin facere ‘make, do’.
meaning: perform (an action, the precise nature of which is often unspecified).;achieve or complete.;act or behave in a specified way.;be suitable or acceptable.;beat up or kill.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin tamariscus, variant of Latin tamarix, of unknown origin.
meaning: an Old World shrub or small tree with tiny scale-like leaves borne on slender branches, giving it a feathery appearance.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French replet(e ) or Latin repletus ‘filled up’, past participle of replere, from re- ‘back, again’ + plere ‘fill’.
meaning: filled or well-supplied with something.

origins: Middle English: from Old French quitance, from quiter ‘to release’ (see quit1).
meaning: a release or discharge from a debt or obligation.

origins: Middle English: probably from Welsh gwlanen ‘woollen article’, from gwlân ‘wool’.
meaning: a kind of soft woven fabric, typically made of wool or cotton and slightly milled and raised.;a small piece of towelling used for washing oneself.;bland fluent talk indulged in to avoid addressing a difficult subject or situation directly.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or denoting a mammal

origins: Old English oferyrnan(see over-, run);Etymology Unknown
meaning: continue beyond or above an expected or allowed time or cost;the movement or extension of something beyond an allotted or particular position or space;the movement of a vehicle at a speed greater than is imparted by the engine;an instance of something exceeding an expected or allowed time or cost;spread over or occupy (a place) in large numbers

origins: Middle English: from Old French ceptre, via Latin from Greek skēptron, from skēptein (alteration of skēptesthai ) ‘lean on’.
meaning: an ornamented staff carried by rulers on ceremonial occasions as a symbol of sovereignty.

origins: late 16th century (as a heraldic term denoting the tail of an animal): from French, based on Latin cauda ‘tail’. Compare with cue2. queue (sense 1 of the noun) dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: a line or sequence of people or vehicles awaiting their turn to be attended to or to proceed.;a list of data items, commands, etc., stored so as to be retrievable in a definite order, usually the order of insertion.;a plait of hair worn at the back.

origins: mid 16th century: from dis- (expressing absence) + proportionate, on the pattern of French disproportionné .
meaning: too large or too small in comparison with something else.

origins: Dutch;Etymology Unknown
meaning: a mountain or hill.

origins: mid 16th century: via French from Latin demolitio(n- ), from the verb demoliri (see demolish).
meaning: the action or process of demolishing or being demolished.

origins: late 16th century: from Spanish and Old Portuguese (now curral ), perhaps based on Latin currere ‘to run’. Compare with kraal.
meaning: gather together and confine (a group of people or things).;put or keep (livestock) in a corral.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a method of teaching people to read by correlating sounds with letters or groups of letters in an alphabetic writing system.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a disease caused by trichinae, typically from infected meat, especially pork, characterized by digestive disturbance, fever, and muscular rigidity.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a tall North American plant of the daisy family, with very large golden-rayed flowers. Sunflowers are cultivated for their edible seeds, which are an important source of oil for cooking and margarine.

origins: mid 17th century: from French, from Italian arabesco ‘in the Arabic style’, from arabo ‘Arab’.

origins: Old English dæg, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dag and German Tag .

origins: early 17th century: from Old Norse and Swedish troll, Danish trold . The first English use is from Shetland; the term was adopted more widely into English in the mid 19th century.

origins: late 19th century: from Rubicon.
meaning: (in piquet) an act of winning a game against an opponent whose total score is less than 100, in which case the loser's score is added to rather than subtracted from the winner's.

origins: late 16th century (in sympathy (sense 3)): via Latin from Greek sumpatheia, from sumpathēs, from sun- ‘with’ + pathos ‘feeling’.
meaning: feelings of pity and sorrow for someone else's misfortune.;understanding between people; common feeling.;the state or fact of responding in a way similar or corresponding to an action elsewhere.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or situated on the edge or periphery of something;a peripheral device

origins: modern Latin, named after Charles Plumier (1646–1704), French botanist.
meaning: a fragrant flowering tropical tree of a genus which includes frangipani.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who tends to dwell unduly on difficulty or troubles.

origins: 1960s: from tachy- ‘swift’ + -on.
meaning: a hypothetical particle that travels faster than light.

origins: Unknown
meaning: used for a system of aided body movements intended to increase body awareness and ease tension

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin alatus, from ala ‘wing’.
meaning: (chiefly of insects or seeds) having wings or winglike appendages.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a white sauce made of chicken or veal stock and cream and thickened with butter and flour

origins: Unknown
meaning: meat and fish (as pork and salmon) wrapped in leaves (as taro or ti) and baked or steamed

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: having or denoting a jagged edge; sawlike

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an immature erythrocyte, containing a nucleus.

origins: Unknown

origins: late 18th century: modern Latin, from Latin urtica ‘nettle’, from urere ‘to burn’.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action of talking; speech or discussion;engaging in speech.

origins: mid 16th century; earliest use found in William Turner (d. 1568), naturalist and religious controversialist. From post-classical Latin sumpsimus, use as noun of classical Latin sūmpsimus, 1st person plural perfect indicative of sūmere to take from sus- + emere to take
meaning: A correct expression, notion, or custom which replaces one that is incorrect but popular or traditional. Contrasted with mumpsimus.

origins: from German, from Gast ‘guest’ + Haus ‘house’.
meaning: a small inn or hotel in a German-speaking country or region.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin adscit- ‘admitted, adopted’, from adsciscere, + -itious1, on the pattern of adventitious .

origins: mid 16th century: from French, or from Latin vagus ‘wandering, uncertain’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (in surfing and other board sports) with the right leg in front of the left on the board.;foolish or harmlessly eccentric.

origins: Unknown

origins: 1920s: from French calligramme, from calli- (in calligraphie ‘calligraphy’) + -gramme (in idéogramme ‘ideogram’).

origins: Unknown

origins: Unknown
meaning: a soup or sauce made of chicken stock, egg yolks, and lemon juice

origins: early 19th century: coined by Coleridge.
meaning: become or make more intense.;increase the opacity of (a negative) using a chemical.

origins: late Middle English: a later variant of slick (adjective and verb).
meaning: (of hair, fur, or skin) smooth and glossy.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin praesentia ‘being at hand’, from the verb praeesse (see present1).

origins: 1920s (originally US): of unknown origin.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Middle English (denoting bail or a guarantee; now chiefly Scots and US): from Latin cautio(n- ), from cavere ‘take heed’.

origins: late Middle English: via Latin from Greek akakia .
meaning: a tree or shrub of warm climates which bears spikes or clusters of yellow or white flowers and is typically thorny.

origins: 1930s: from graph2 + -eme.

origins: French, from maquiller ‘to make up’, from Old French masquiller ‘to stain’.
meaning: make-up; cosmetics.

origins: mid 19th century: probably from the nouns shin and dig, influenced later by shindy.

origins: early 17th century: from Italian, from Latin porticus ‘porch’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Middle English: from Old French maquerel, of unknown origin.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge;

origins: Unknown

origins: early 17th century: from obsolete French astut or Latin astutus, from astus ‘craft’.
