origins: late 16th century: from Gargantua, the name of a voracious giant in Rabelais' book of the same name (1534), + -an.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin concha ‘shellfish, shell’, from Greek konkhē ‘mussel, cockle, or shell-like cavity’.
meaning: a tropical marine mollusc with a robust spiral shell which may bear long projections and have a flared lip.;the roof of a semicircular apse, shaped like half a dome.;another term for concha.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin verisimilitudo, from verisimilis ‘probable’, from veri (genitive of verus ‘true’) + similis ‘like’.
meaning: the appearance of being true or real.

origins: late 15th century: from French invoquer, from Latin invocare, from in- ‘upon’ + vocare ‘to call’.
meaning: call on (a deity or spirit) in prayer, as a witness, or for inspiration.;cite or appeal to (someone or something) as an authority for an action or in support of an argument.;cause (a procedure) to be carried out.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: one that can be manipulated

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: any of the bones of the foot (metatarsus).

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin sopor ‘sleep’ + -fic.
meaning: tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a follower of Martin Luther.;of or characterized by the theology of Martin Luther.

origins: Middle English: from Old French enterrer, based on Latin in- ‘into’ + terra ‘earth’.

origins: Louisiana French, from Provençal jambalaia .

origins: Old English, from Old French cedre or Latin cedrus, from Greek kedros .

origins: late Middle English: from Old French colique, from late Latin colicus, from colon (see colon2).

origins: Unknown
meaning: ápoisonááspecificallyá:áto inject a toxic substance into

origins: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French and Old Northern French caroine, caroigne, Old French charoigne, based on Latin caro ‘flesh’.
meaning: the decaying flesh of dead animals.

origins: Old English mōnath, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch maand and German Monat, also to moon.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin praecursor, from praecurs- ‘preceded’, from praecurrere, from prae ‘beforehand’ + currere ‘to run’.
meaning: a person or thing that comes before another of the same kind; a forerunner.

origins: 1930s: from Moxie, the proprietary name of a soft drink.
meaning: force of character, determination, or nerve.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin eminent- ‘jutting, projecting’, from the verb eminere .
meaning: (of a person) famous and respected within a particular sphere.;(of a positive quality) present to a notable degree.

origins: Middle English (denoting a grant of legal immunity): from Old French, based on franc, franche ‘free’ (see frank1). franchise (sense 2 of the noun) dates from the late 18th century and franchise (sense 1 of the noun) from the 20th century.

origins: mid 19th century: abbreviation.
meaning: an advertisement.

origins: late Middle English (as a noun denoting the throwing of goods overboard to lighten a ship in distress): from Old French getaison, from Latin jactatio(n- ), from jactare ‘to throw’ (see jet1). The verb dates from the mid 19th century.

origins: early 18th century (originally as an adjective designating soup made of chopped vegetables, especially carrots): French, from the male given names Jules or Julien, of obscure development.
meaning: a portion of food cut into short, thin strips.

origins: mid 18th century (originally relating to feudal service in the sense ‘compulsory’, hence ‘common to all’): from French, from ban ‘a proclamation or call to arms’; ultimately of Germanic origin and related to ban1.

origins: late 19th century: from Latin, from reducere ‘bring back’.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin praevius ‘going before’ (from prae ‘before’ + via ‘way’) + -ous.
meaning: existing or occurring before in time or order.;overhasty in acting.

origins: mid 16th century: via Latin from Greek rhombos .

origins: late 16th century: from Latin, from simulare (see simulate).
meaning: an image or representation of someone or something.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: without wearing anything on the feet;wearing nothing on the feet

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘fragrant’): from Old French, or from Latin redolent- ‘giving out a strong smell’, from re(d)- ‘back, again’ + olere ‘to smell’.
meaning: strongly reminiscent or suggestive of.;fragrant or sweet-smelling.

origins: early 20th century: from French, from the verb transhumer, based on Latin trans- ‘across’ + humus ‘ground’.
meaning: the action or practice of moving livestock from one grazing ground to another in a seasonal cycle, typically to lowlands in winter and highlands in summer.

origins: early 20th century (originally dialect): of unknown origin.
meaning: a person who is old-fashioned and fussy.

origins: early 16th century (in dome (sense 3)): from Latin domus ; other senses are via French dôme, from Italian duomo ‘cathedral, dome’.
meaning: a rounded vault forming the roof of a building or structure, typically with a circular base.;a thing shaped like a dome.;a stately building.

origins: late 18th century: from pan- ‘all’ + Greek horama ‘view’ (from horan ‘see’).
meaning: an unbroken view of the whole region surrounding an observer.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the formal and technical language of legal documents that is often hard to understand

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (in racing results) favorite;fine.;farad.;Fahrenheit;forint.;feminine.;foot.;focal length;the sixth letter of the alphabet.;France.;false.;the chemical element fluorine.;franc.;(in units of measurement) femto- (10¹⁵).;(in textual references) folio.;force;from.;form.;(in auto racing) formula;Fellow.;French.;fathom.;denoting electrons and orbitals possessing three units of angular momentum;fighter (in designations of US aircraft types);farthing.;the fourth note of the diatonic scale of C major.;a function of a specified variable;frequency.;farad(s).;feet.;franc(s);failure.;father.;forte.;(in racing results) furlong(s).;filly.;female.;February.;faraday(s).

origins: early 19th century: from French, literally ‘squinting’.
meaning: disreputable or sordid in a rakish or appealing way.

origins: early 17th century: via French from Italian gazzetta, originally Venetian gazeta de la novità ‘a halfpennyworth of news’ (because the news-sheet sold for a gazeta, a Venetian coin of small value).
meaning: a journal or newspaper.

origins: Middle English: from Old French autorite, from Latin auctoritas, from auctor ‘originator, promoter’ (see author).
meaning: the power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience.;a person or organization having political or administrative power and control.;the power to influence others, especially because of one's commanding manner or one's recognized knowledge about something.

origins: late 16th century (as a noun denoting a place where alms were distributed): from medieval Latin eleemosynarius, from late Latin eleemosyna ‘alms’, from Greek eleēmosunē ‘compassion’ (see alms).
meaning: relating to or dependent on charity; charitable.

origins: early 19th century (in corsage (sense 2)): French, from Old French cors ‘body’, from Latin corpus .
meaning: a spray of flowers worn pinned to a woman's clothes.;the upper part of a woman's dress.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: extreme or strict naturalism in art or literature

origins: mid 19th century: from Latin, from pinus ‘pine’.
meaning: a plantation of pine trees or other conifers planted for scientific or ornamental purposes.

origins: early 16th century (in the sense ‘momentary sick feeling’): perhaps related to Old English cw(e)alm ‘pain’, of Germanic origin.
meaning: an uneasy feeling of doubt, worry, or fear, especially about one's own conduct; a misgiving.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin iteratio(n- ), from the verb iterare (see iterate).
meaning: the repetition of a process or utterance.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: of or pertaining to a hexagon

origins: late 19th century: from French décor, from the verb décorer, from Latin decorare ‘embellish’ (see decorate).
meaning: the furnishing and decoration of a room.

origins: late 18th century: from Greek epideiktikos (based on deiknunai ‘to show’).
meaning: characterized by or designed to display rhetorical or oratorical skill.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin fraudulentus, from fraus, fraud- ‘deceit, injury’.

origins: early 18th century: from the imaginary country of Lilliput in Swift's Gulliver's Travels, inhabited by people 6 inches (15 cm) high, + -ian.

origins: Middle English: via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek Pharaō, from Hebrew par‘ōh, from Egyptian pr-‘o ‘great house’.

origins: mid 16th century: from French corsaire, from medieval Latin cursarius, from cursus ‘a raid, plunder’, special use of Latin cursus ‘course’, from currere ‘to run’.

origins: mid 16th century: from French binôme or modern Latin binomium (from bi- ‘having two’ + Greek nomos ‘part, portion’) + -al.
meaning: an algebraic expression of the sum or the difference of two terms.;a two-part name, especially the Latin name of a species of living organism (consisting of the genus followed by the specific epithet).;a noun phrase with two heads joined by a conjunction, in which the order is relatively fixed (as in knife and fork ).

origins: Middle English partrich, from Old French pertriz, perdriz, from Latin perdix .
meaning: a short-tailed game bird with mainly brown plumage, found chiefly in Europe and Asia.

origins: late Middle English: from medieval Latin gradualis, from Latin gradus ‘step’. The original sense of the adjective was ‘arranged in degrees’; the noun refers to the altar steps in a church, from which the antiphons were sung.
meaning: taking place or progressing slowly or by degrees.;(of a slope) not steep or abrupt.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a gourmet of cheese

origins: late 16th century: from French, or from late Latin tangibilis, from tangere ‘to touch’.
meaning: perceptible by touch.

origins: early 17th century: via Latin from Greek proskēnion, from pro ‘before’ + skēnē ‘stage’.
meaning: the part of a theatre stage in front of the curtain.

origins: early 19th century (originally US, denoting a violent blow): of unknown origin.
meaning: a severe snowstorm with high winds.

origins: Old English (as a verb), of imitative origin.
meaning: a continuous rattling sound as of hard objects falling or striking each other.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin tripartitus, from tri- ‘three’ + partitus ‘divided’ (past participle of partiri ).
meaning: shared by or involving three parties.;consisting of three parts.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: characterized by reverberation

origins: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French trifoil, from Latin trifolium, from tri- ‘three’ + folium ‘leaf’.
meaning: a small European plant of the pea family, with yellow flowers and three-lobed clover-like leaves.

origins: Latin, literally ‘we send’, first used as the opening word of the writ which transferred records from one court to another (late Middle English to the early 18th century).
meaning: a warrant committing a person to prison.

origins: French, from chanter ‘sing’.
meaning: a female singer of popular songs.

origins: late Middle English (as a noun denoting a person with a diseased spleen): from late Latin spleneticus, from Greek splēn (see spleen).
meaning: bad-tempered; spiteful.;archaic term for splenic.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French visconte, from medieval Latin vicecomes, vicecomit- (see vice-, count2).
meaning: a British nobleman ranking above a baron and below an earl.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in every part of a place or object;in every part of (a place or object)

origins: late Middle English: variant of migraine.
meaning: depression; low spirits.;a whim or fancy.;old-fashioned term for migraine.

origins: Middle English (as a verb in the sense ‘tuck up around the body’): of Scandinavian origin; compare with Danish kilte (op) ‘tuck (up)’ and Old Norse kilting ‘a skirt’. The noun dates from the mid 18th century.
meaning: a garment resembling a knee-length skirt of pleated tartan cloth, traditionally worn by men as part of Scottish Highland dress and now also worn by women and girls.

origins: early 20th century: perhaps from slang posh, denoting either a dandy or a coin of small value. There is no evidence to support the folk etymology that posh is formed from the initials of port out starboard home (referring to the more comfortable accommodation, out of the heat of the sun, on ships between England and India).
meaning: elegant or stylishly luxurious.

origins: mid 19th century: first appears as the real Mackay, in which real may be a corruption of the name of the Reay branch of the Scottish Mackay family
meaning: If you describe someone or something as the real McCoy, you mean that they really are what they claim to be and are not an imitation.

origins: mid 17th century: from Italian quarantina ‘forty days’, from quaranta ‘forty’.
meaning: a state, period, or place of isolation in which people or animals that have arrived from elsewhere or been exposed to infectious or contagious disease are placed.

origins: modern Latin, from diplo- ‘double’ + Greek dokos ‘wooden beam’.
meaning: a huge herbivorous dinosaur of the late Jurassic period, with a long slender neck and tail.

origins: mid 19th century: from German, from Latin cithara (see cittern).
meaning: a musical instrument consisting of a flat wooden soundbox with numerous strings stretched across it, placed horizontally and played with the fingers and a plectrum. It is used especially in central European folk music.

origins: mid 16th century (denoting any atmospheric phenomenon): from modern Latin meteorum, from Greek meteōron, neuter (used as a noun) of meteōros ‘lofty’.
meaning: a small body of matter from outer space that enters the earth's atmosphere, becoming incandescent as a result of friction and appearing as a streak of light.

origins: Middle English (also in the sense ‘set a price on, attach value to’): from Old French preisier ‘to prize, praise’, from late Latin pretiare, from Latin pretium ‘price’. Compare with prize1.
meaning: express warm approval or admiration of.;express one's respect and gratitude towards (a deity), especially in song.

origins: early 19th century (originally US): formed irregularly from hydro- ‘relating to water’ + -ant.
meaning: a fitting in a street or other public place with a nozzle by which a hose may be attached to a water main.

origins: mid 17th century: from French médaillon, from Italian medaglione, augmentative of medaglia (see medal).
meaning: a piece of jewellery in the shape of a medal, worn as a pendant.

origins: mid 17th century: related to dialect daddle, doddle  ‘dally’.
meaning: waste time; be slow.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a liquid) not transparent or clear;(of the sky or weather) covered with or characterized by clouds; overcast

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a violin made by a member of the Guarneri family of Cremona, Italy, during the 17th and 18th centuries.

origins: early 17th century: from medieval Latin bifurcat- ‘divided into two forks’, from the verb bifurcare, from Latin bifurcus ‘two-forked’, from bi- ‘having two’ + furca ‘a fork’;Etymology Unknown
meaning: forked; branched;divide into two branches or forks

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘exchange, barter’): via Old French from Latin permutatio(n- ), from the verb permutare ‘change completely’ (see permute).
meaning: each of several possible ways in which a set or number of things can be ordered or arranged.

origins: mid 19th century: from French artésien ‘from Artois’ (see Artois), where such wells were first made.
meaning: relating to or denoting a well bored perpendicularly into water-bearing strata lying at an angle, so that natural pressure produces a constant supply of water with little or no pumping.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: You use elaborate to describe something that is very complex because it has a lot of different parts.

origins: Middle English: from Old French defaut, from defaillir ‘to fail’, based on Latin fallere ‘disappoint, deceive’;Etymology Unknown
meaning: a preselected option adopted by a computer program or other mechanism when no alternative is specified by the user or programmer;fail to fulfill an obligation, especially to repay a loan or to appear in a court of law;failure to fulfill an obligation, especially to repay a loan or appear in a court of law;(of a device or computer program) revert automatically to (a preselected option)

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin fomentatio(n- ), from the verb fomentare (see foment).
meaning: the action of instigating or stirring up undesirable sentiment or actions.;a poultice.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an ornamental covering or band for the head, especially one worn on ceremonial occasions

origins: Unknown
meaning: having a projecting lower jaw

origins: late 18th century: from French préhensile, from Latin prehens- ‘grasped’, from the verb prehendere, from prae ‘before’ + hendere ‘to grasp’.
meaning: (chiefly of an animal's limb or tail) capable of grasping.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: without any reduction in intensity or strength

origins: late Middle English: from French, from non- ‘not’ + pareil ‘equal’ (from popular Latin pariculus, diminutive of Latin par ‘equal’).
meaning: having no match or equal; unrivalled.

origins: Spanish, literally ‘sauce’, extended in American Spanish to denote the dance.
meaning: a type of Latin American dance music incorporating elements of jazz and rock.;(especially in Latin American cooking) a spicy tomato sauce.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, ultimately of Germanic origin and related to wisent.
meaning: a humpbacked shaggy-haired wild ox native to North America and Europe.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘close attention, caution’): via Old French from Latin diligentia, from diligent- ‘assiduous’ (see diligent).
meaning: careful and persistent work or effort.

origins: Old English, from Old French cercle, from Latin circulus ‘small ring’, diminutive of circus ‘ring’.
meaning: a round plane figure whose boundary (the circumference) consists of points equidistant from a fixed point (the centre).;a group of people with a shared profession, interests, or acquaintances.

origins: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin complacentia, from Latin complacere ‘to please’.
meaning: a feeling of smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements.

origins: late Middle English: from French miraculeux or medieval Latin miraculosus, from Latin miraculum (see miracle).
meaning: of the nature of a miracle or having the power to work miracles.

origins: 1930s: from Yiddish klots ‘wooden block’.
meaning: a clumsy, awkward, or foolish person.

origins: late 15th century (in caravan (sense 2)): from French caravane, from Persian kārwān . The sense ‘covered horse-drawn wagon’ dates from the early 19th century.
meaning: a vehicle equipped for living in, typically towed by a car and used for holidays.;a group of people, especially traders or pilgrims, travelling together across a desert in Asia or North Africa.

origins: 1980s: blend of shop and alcoholic.
meaning: a compulsive shopper.

origins: early 20th century: from French, literally ‘butterfly’, from Latin papilio(n- ).
meaning: a dog of a toy breed with ears suggesting the form of a butterfly.

origins: mid 16th century (denoting a list of words with definitions or translations): from medieval Latin vocabularius, from Latin vocabulum (see vocable).
meaning: the body of words used in a particular language.;a range of artistic or stylistic forms, techniques, or movements.

origins: mid 17th century: from French sardonique, earlier sardonien, via Latin from Greek sardonios ‘of Sardinia’, alteration of sardanios, used by Homer to describe bitter or scornful laughter.
meaning: grimly mocking or cynical.

origins: 1920s; earliest use found in Dictionary Occupational Terms. From classical Latin mīlle thousand + grain
meaning: A gem setting of beaded or crenellated metal.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin piscis ‘fish’ + -vorous.
meaning: (of an animal) feeding on fish.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the quality or fact of being greater in number, quantity, or importance

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘diversify (something) by introducing other things at intervals’): from Latin interspers- ‘scattered between’, from interspergere, from inter- ‘between’ + spargere ‘scatter’.
meaning: scatter among or between other things; place here and there.

origins: early 18th century: French, literally ‘still, again’.
meaning: a repeated or additional performance of an item at the end of a concert, as called for by an audience.

origins: Spanish tapa, literally ‘cover, lid’ (because the dishes were given free with the drink, served on a dish balanced on, therefore ‘covering’, the glass).
meaning: small Spanish savoury dishes, typically served with drinks at a bar.

origins: mid 19th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: a boldly patterned Asian cuckoo-shrike (songbird), the male of which is typically red and black, and the female yellow and grey.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: foolish or silly behavior

origins: mid 17th century: from back + gammon2.
meaning: a board game in which two players move their pieces around twenty-four triangular points according to the throw of dice, the winner being the first to remove all their pieces from the board.

origins: early 19th century: from Latin sartor ‘tailor’ (from sarcire ‘to patch’) + -ial.
meaning: relating to tailoring, clothes, or style of dress.

origins: late 16th century (denoting a Chinese official): from Portuguese mandarim, via Malay from Hindi mantrī ‘counsellor’.
meaning: the standard literary and official form of Chinese, spoken by over 730 million people.;an official in any of the nine top grades of the former imperial Chinese civil service.;a powerful official or senior bureaucrat, especially one perceived as reactionary and secretive.

origins: mid 19th century: back-formation from drapery, influenced by French draper ‘to drape’. The noun senses date from the early 20th century.

origins: Italian, from the phrase tira mi su ‘pick me up’.

origins: Old English ūtlendisc  ‘not native’, from ūtland  ‘foreign country’.

origins: mid 17th century: modern Latin, from Latin mergus ‘diver’ (from mergere ‘to dive’) + anser ‘goose’.
meaning: a fish-eating diving duck with a long, thin serrated and hooked bill.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an electronic document in which data is arranged in the rows and columns of a grid and can be manipulated and used in calculations

origins: early 17th century: from Latin sagax, sagac- ‘wise’ + -ious.
meaning: having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgement; wise or shrewd.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: capable of being persuaded; open to or yielding to persuasion

origins: Unknown
meaning: a 3-line unrhymed Japanese poem structurally similar to haiku but treating human nature usually in an ironic or satiric vein

origins: mid 16th century: from French, from Latin adagium ‘saying’, based on an early form of aio ‘I say’.

origins: early 19th century: probably from French organsin (see organzine).
meaning: a thin, stiff, transparent dress fabric made of silk or a synthetic yarn.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a cautious and surreptitious manner, so as not to be seen or heard

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘holy in character’): from Latin sanctimonia ‘sanctity’ (from sanctus ‘holy’) + -ous.

origins: Middle English: from Old French force (noun), forcer (verb), based on Latin fortis ‘strong’.
meaning: strength or energy as an attribute of physical action or movement.;coercion or compulsion, especially with the use or threat of violence.;mental or moral strength or power.;an organized body of military personnel or police.;(in the Star Wars films) a mystical universal energy field which certain individuals, such as the Jedi, can harness to gain special powers or abilities.

origins: late 18th century (in the sense ‘acute homesickness’): modern Latin (translating German Heimweh ‘homesickness’), from Greek nostos ‘return home’ + algos ‘pain’.
meaning: a sentimental longing or wistful affection for a period in the past.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin squalidus, from squalere ‘be rough or dirty’.
meaning: (of a place) extremely dirty and unpleasant, especially as a result of poverty or neglect.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: covered with spangles or other small sparkling objects or lights

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an expert in the preparation and analysis of statistics.

origins: late 16th century: from hap1 + hazard.
meaning: lacking any obvious principle of organization.

origins: early 17th century: from French, from Italian carnaggio, from medieval Latin carnaticum, from Latin caro, carn- ‘flesh’.
meaning: the killing of a large number of people.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who makes or sells archers' bows.

origins: early 16th century: perhaps from badge, with reference to its distinctive head markings. The verb sense (late 18th century) originates from the sport of badger baiting.
meaning: a heavily built omnivorous nocturnal mammal of the weasel family, typically having a grey and black coat.;a native of Wisconsin.

origins: modern Latin, from spirula ‘small spiral (shell)’.

origins: mid 19th century: from Yucatán Spanish, from Maya tzonot .
meaning: a natural underground reservoir of water such as occurs in the limestone of Yucatán, Mexico.

origins: early 19th century: from Italian, from Latin studium (see study).
meaning: a room where an artist, photographer, sculptor, etc. works.;a film or television production company.;a studio flat.

origins: early 19th century (originally as a noun denoting an ancient Norse warrior who fought with wild or uncontrolled ferocity): from Old Norse berserkr (noun), probably from birn-, bjorn (see bear2) + serkr ‘coat’, but also possibly from berr ‘bare’ (i.e. without armour).

origins: late Middle English: from the imperative of fare + the adverb well1.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin vindicta ‘vengeance’ + -ive.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: make a microfiche of (a newspaper, catalog, or other document);a flat piece of film containing microphotographs of the pages of a newspaper, catalog, or other document

origins: late Middle English: from Old French climat or late Latin clima, climat-, from Greek klima ‘slope, zone’, from klinein ‘to slope’. The term originally denoted a zone of the earth between two lines of latitude, then any region of the earth, and later, a region considered with reference to its atmospheric conditions. Compare with clime.
meaning: the weather conditions prevailing in an area in general or over a long period.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a carbonated nonalcoholic drink

origins: Unknown
meaning: template

origins: late 16th century: from French, from Italian torrente, from Latin torrent- ‘boiling, roaring’, from torrere ‘parch, scorch’.
meaning: a strong and fast-moving stream of water or other liquid.

origins: late 19th century: from American Spanish.
meaning: an earthquake.

origins: Middle English: past participle of the obsolete verb affray, from Anglo-Norman French afrayer (see affray).
meaning: feeling fear or anxiety; frightened.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French auborne, alborne, from Latin alburnus ‘whitish’, from albus ‘white’. The original sense was ‘yellowish white’, but the word became associated with brown because in the 16th and 17th centuries it was often written abrune or abroun .
meaning: (of hair) of a reddish-brown colour.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin permissio(n- ), from the verb permittere ‘allow’ (see permit1).

origins: Middle English: apparently from goose + summer1, perhaps from the time of year around St Martin's summer, i.e. early November, when geese were eaten (gossamer being common then).
meaning: a fine, filmy substance consisting of cobwebs spun by small spiders, seen especially in autumn.

origins: Unknown
meaning: an East Indian ship propelled by sails and oars and often armed and used by pirates

origins: late Middle English: from Old French superlatif, -ive, from late Latin superlativus, from Latin superlatus ‘carried beyond’, past participle of superferre .
meaning: of the highest quality or degree.;(of an adjective or adverb) expressing the highest or a very high degree of a quality (e.g. bravest, most fiercely ).

origins: French, literally ‘liquid in which something has boiled’, from bouillir ‘to boil’.
meaning: thin soup or stock made by stewing meat, fish, or vegetables in water.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: of toponyms

origins: Middle English: from Old French disner (infinitive used as a noun: see dine).
meaning: the main meal of the day, taken either around midday or in the evening.

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘proximity’): from Latin vicinitas, from vicinus ‘neighbour’.
meaning: the area near or surrounding a particular place.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late 19th century: French, past participle of masser ‘make a massé stroke’.
meaning: a stroke made with an inclined cue, imparting swerve to the ball.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a writer of any of the Hagiographa.;a writer of the lives of the saints.

origins: early 17th century: from French marionnette, from Marion, diminutive of the given name Marie .

origins: late 19th century: from Maori, from tua ‘on the back’ + tara ‘spine’.

origins: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘make intensely hot’): from Latin ignire ‘set on fire’, from ignis ‘fire’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late 17th century (denoting a regular course or procedure): from French, from route ‘road’ (see route).

origins: late 17th century: from Akan haramata .

origins: mid 19th century: apparently from dialect nug  ‘lump’, of unknown origin.

origins: Old English midhrif, from mid1 + hrif ‘belly’.

origins: early 16th century: from Latin pecuniarius, from pecunia ‘money’, from pecu ‘cattle, money’.

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French tretis, from Old French traitier (see treat).

origins: late 19th century: from French, originally in the sense ‘person who frequents boulevards’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English: from French capacité, from Latin capacitas, from capax, capac- ‘that can contain’, from capere ‘take or hold’.
meaning: the maximum amount that something can contain.;the amount that something can produce.;a specified role or position.

origins: early 21st century: from self + -ie.
meaning: a photograph that one has taken of oneself, typically one taken with a smartphone or webcam and shared via social media.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or denoting a violent natural event

origins: Unknown

origins: late 18th century: from Swedish dialect rotabagge .
meaning: a large, round, yellow-fleshed root that is eaten as a vegetable; a swede.;the European plant of the cabbage family that produces this root.

meaning: a personality trait characterized by instability, anxiety, aggression, etc

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘repair’ but originally not implying clumsiness): of unknown origin.

origins: Etymology Unknown;late 17th century; earliest use found in Gideon Harvey (c1636–?1702), physician. From post-classical Latin raninus from classical Latin rāna frog + -īnus. On the reason for the name in sense A. 1 see quot. 1615
meaning: Resembling a frog; of the nature of a frog; of, relating to, or characteristic of frogs, specifically (Zoology) those of the subfamily Raninae.;A frog of the subfamily Raninae.;Designating the deep lingual artery and vein, which run on each side of the undersurface of the tongue from the back to the tip. In early use also: †designating a sublingual salivary gland (obsolete).

origins: late 19th century: German Gegenschein, from gegen ‘opposite’ + Schein ‘glow, shine’.
meaning: a patch of very faint nebulous light sometimes seen in the night sky opposite the position of the sun. It is thought to be the image of the sun reflected from gas and dust outside the atmosphere.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a lock of hair that grows in a direction different from the rest and that resists being combed flat

origins: Italian, literally ‘resurrection’
meaning: a movement for the unification and independence of Italy, which was achieved in 1870.

origins: early 20th century: from Japanese.
meaning: an ornamental East Asian tree which has leaves that resemble those of the Judas tree and light, fine-grained timber.;a type of Japanese wig worn mainly by women.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: early 19th century (denoting a long-haired breed): from the place name Angora.
meaning: a cat, goat, or rabbit of a long-haired breed.

origins: 1970s: from Greek mimēma ‘that which is imitated’, on the pattern of gene .
meaning: an element of a culture or system of behaviour passed from one individual to another by imitation or other non-genetic means.;an image, video, piece of text, etc., typically humorous in nature, that is copied and spread rapidly by internet users, often with slight variations.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: being unsure or tentative

origins: late 16th century: via late Latin from Greek eikosaedron, neuter (used as a noun) of eikosaedros ‘twenty-faced’.
meaning: a solid figure with twenty plane faces, especially equilateral triangular ones.

origins: late Middle English (originally Scots in the sense ‘whirlpool’): perhaps of Low German or Dutch origin; compare with Dutch zwirrelen ‘to whirl’.

origins: Old English byrgels  ‘place of burial, grave’ (interpreted as plural in Middle English, hence the loss of the final -s ), of Germanic origin; related to bury.
meaning: the action or practice of burying a dead body.

origins: Unknown
meaning: one of the very large land tortoises of the Galßpagos islands

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: If you say that a person, problem, or device is tractable, you mean that they can be easily controlled or dealt with.

origins: Unknown
meaning: capable of growth

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘translation’): from French, or from medieval Latin versio(n- ), from Latin vertere ‘to turn’.
meaning: a particular form of something differing in certain respects from an earlier form or other forms of the same type of thing.;an account of a matter from a particular person's point of view.;the manual turning of a fetus in the uterus to make delivery easier.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin alacritas, from alacer ‘brisk’.
meaning: brisk and cheerful readiness.

origins: Unknown
meaning: minutely scabrous; harsh

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: another name for gimbals;to support on gimbals

origins: Old English starian, of Germanic origin, from a base meaning ‘be rigid’.
meaning: look fixedly or vacantly at someone or something with one's eyes wide open.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin, ‘sharpness, point’, from acuere ‘sharpen’ (see acute).
meaning: the ability to make good judgements and take quick decisions.

origins: late 16th century: from French, from barrique ‘cask’, from Spanish barrica ; related to barrel (barrels often being used to build barricades).
meaning: an improvised barrier erected across a street or other thoroughfare to prevent or delay the movement of opposing forces.

origins: Unknown
meaning: áwater wally

origins: late 16th century (denoting tall stature): from French, from grand ‘great, grand’ (see grand).

origins: Middle English: from Old French beneiçun, from Latin benedictio (see benediction).

origins: late 15th century: probably related to run.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin vespertinus, from vesper ‘evening’.
meaning: relating to, occurring, or active in the evening.

origins: late 16th century (in the legal sense): from Old French abeance ‘aspiration to a title’, from abeer ‘aspire after’, from a- ‘towards’ + beer ‘to gape’.
meaning: a state of temporary disuse or suspension.

origins: French, from danser ‘to dance’.
meaning: a male ballet dancer.

origins: early 17th century: from be- + smirch.

origins: early 17th century (in the sense ‘sportive, intended as a jest’): from Latin ludicrus (probably from ludicrum ‘stage play’) + -ous.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: early 17th century: from French panégyrique, via Latin from Greek panēgurikos ‘of public assembly’, from pan ‘all’ + aguris ‘agora, assembly’.

origins: mid 17th century: French, literally ‘rough speech’, perhaps from Old French patoier ‘treat roughly’, from patte ‘paw’.
