origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the complex emotional or psychological interaction between two people;the branch of science that deals with the identification of the substances of which matter is composed; the investigation of their properties and the ways in which they interact, combine, and change; and the use of these processes to form new substances.

origins: 1871: coined by Lewis Carroll in Through the Looking Glass ; probably a blend of chuckle and snort.
meaning: laugh in a noisy, gleeful way.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin meditatio(n- ), from meditari (see meditate).
meaning: the action or practice of meditating.

origins: Italian.
meaning: thin, crisp Italian breadsticks.

origins: early 19th century; earliest use found in John Mason Good (1764–1827), physician and surgeon. From scientific Latin ageusia from a- + ancient Greek γεῦσις sense of taste + scientific Latin -ia
meaning: Loss of the sense of taste; = ageustia.

origins: early 20th century: from Swiss German, literally ‘thrust, blow’.
meaning: a violent attempt to overthrow a government; a coup.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a helicopter.

origins: late 17th century (denoting the system of drill invented by Martinet): named after Jean Martinet, 17th-century French drill master.
meaning: a person who demands complete obedience; a strict disciplinarian.

origins: late 16th century: from modern Latin cutaneus (from Latin cutis ‘skin’) + -ous.
meaning: relating to or affecting the skin.

origins: Old English leger  ‘resting place, bed’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch leger ‘bed, camp’ and German Lager ‘storehouse’, also to lie1. Compare with laager, lager.
meaning: a place where a wild animal, especially a fierce or dangerous one, lives.;a burial plot in a graveyard.

origins: early 18th century: from Anglo-Latin, of unknown origin.
meaning: a gallery or arcade above the arches of the nave, choir, and transepts of a church.

origins: early 18th century; earliest use found in John Scheuchzer (1702–1729), physician and naturalist. From Japanese chanoyu hot water boiled for the purpose of making tea, especially ceremonially, method of making tea, gathering for tea drinking
meaning: In Japanese culture: the ceremonial preparation and drinking of the powdered green tea matcha; a gathering devoted to this.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: colored or shining like gold;(of a period) very happy and prosperous;denoting the fiftieth year of something;(of a singing voice) rich and smooth;made or consisting of gold

origins: mid 19th century: back-formation from complicity.
meaning: involved with others in an activity that is unlawful or morally wrong.

origins: modern Latin, from Latin, literally ‘little frog’, diminutive of rana .
meaning: a temperate plant of a genus that includes the buttercups and water crowfoots, typically having yellow or white bowl-shaped flowers and lobed or toothed leaves.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin obliterat- ‘struck out, erased’, from the verb obliterare, based on littera ‘letter, something written’.
meaning: destroy utterly; wipe out.

origins: mid 16th century: from French, from Italian bastione, from bastire ‘build’.
meaning: a projecting part of a fortification built at an angle to the line of a wall, so as to allow defensive fire in several directions.;an institution, place, or person strongly maintaining particular principles, attitudes, or activities.

origins: late Middle English: from French, from Latin contusio(n- ), from the verb contundere (see contuse).
meaning: a region of injured tissue or skin in which blood capillaries have been ruptured; a bruise.

origins: late 16th century: probably via Dutch from obsolete French truffle, perhaps based on Latin tubera, plural of tuber ‘hump, swelling’. truffle (sense 2) dates from the 1920s.
meaning: a strong-smelling underground fungus that resembles an irregular, rough-skinned potato, growing chiefly in broadleaved woodland on calcareous soils. It is considered a culinary delicacy and found, especially in France, with the aid of trained dogs or pigs.;a soft sweet made of a chocolate mixture, typically flavoured with rum and covered with cocoa.

origins: Old English bēan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch boon and German Bohne .
meaning: an edible seed, typically kidney-shaped, growing in long pods on certain leguminous plants.;a leguminous plant that bears beans in pods.;a very small amount or nothing at all of something (used emphatically).;a person's head, especially when regarded as a source of common sense.

origins: Italian.
meaning: a variety of round-grained rice produced in Italy and used in making risotto.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin cadaverosus, from cadaver ‘corpse’.
meaning: very pale, thin, or bony.

origins: Unknown
meaning: the practice of conniving

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘overcome, defeat in argument’): from Latin convincere, from con- ‘with’ + vincere ‘conquer’. Compare with convict.
meaning: cause (someone) to believe firmly in the truth of something.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin consecrat- ‘dedicated, devoted as sacred’, from the verb consecrare, from con- (expressing intensive force) + sacrare ‘dedicate’, from sacer ‘sacred’.
meaning: make or declare (something, typically a church) sacred; dedicate formally to a religious purpose.

origins: late 16th century: from French incarnadin(e ), from Italian incarnadino, variant of incarnatino ‘flesh colour’, based on Latin incarnare (see incarnate).
meaning: a bright crimson or pinkish-red colour.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘rhythm or metrical beat’): via Old French from Italian cadenza, based on Latin cadere ‘to fall’.
meaning: a modulation or inflection of the voice.;a sequence of notes or chords comprising the close of a musical phrase.

origins: probably a back-formation from dishevelled.
meaning: make (a person's hair or clothes) untidy.

origins: Middle English: from Middle Dutch, Middle Low German snūt ; related to snot.
meaning: the projecting nose and mouth of an animal, especially a mammal.;a cigarette.;a police informer.;a European moth with long palps that extend in front of the head like a snout.

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, variant of Old French ligeance, from lige, liege (see liege), perhaps by association with Anglo-Latin alligantia ‘alliance’.
meaning: loyalty or commitment to a superior or to a group or cause.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the machinery or working parts of something;the branch of applied mathematics dealing with motion and forces producing motion

origins: early 17th century: from obsolete Portuguese macau, of unknown origin.
meaning: a large long-tailed parrot with brightly coloured plumage, native to Central and South America.

origins: early 16th century: from Scottish Gaelic sluagh-ghairm, from sluagh ‘army’ + gairm ‘shout’.
meaning: a short and striking or memorable phrase used in advertising.;a Scottish Highland war cry.

origins: mid 18th century: from French, from Italian caricatura, from caricare ‘load, exaggerate’, from Latin carricare (see charge).
meaning: a picture, description, or imitation of a person in which certain striking characteristics are exaggerated in order to create a comic or grotesque effect.

origins: mid 19th century: from Wiradhuri bilabang ‘channel that is dry except after rain’.
meaning: a branch of a river forming a backwater or stagnant pool, made by water flowing from the main stream during a flood.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French reflecter or Latin reflectere, from re- ‘back’ + flectere ‘to bend’.
meaning: (of a surface or body) throw back (heat, light, or sound) without absorbing it.;think deeply or carefully about.;(of an action or situation) bring credit or discredit to the relevant parties.

origins: Latin
meaning: a large peninsula in northwestern Europe, occupied by Norway and Sweden. It is bounded by the Arctic Ocean on the north, the Atlantic Ocean on the west, and the Baltic Sea on the south and the east.

origins: mid 19th century: from modern Latin Cruciferae (plural), from Latin crux, cruc- ‘cross’ + -fer ‘bearing’ (because the flowers have four equal petals arranged crosswise), + -ous.
meaning: relating to or denoting plants of the cabbage family ( Cruciferae ).

origins: late Middle English (originally an adjective in the sense ‘divorced’): from Latin repudiatus ‘divorced, cast off’, from repudium ‘divorce’.
meaning: refuse to accept; reject.;deny the truth or validity of.

origins: late 17th century: imitative; compare with sputter.
meaning: make a series of short explosive spitting or choking sounds.

origins: early 16th century (denoting a form of argument involving a choice between equally unfavourable alternatives): via Latin from Greek dilēmma, from di- ‘twice’ + lēmma ‘premise’.
meaning: a situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two or more alternatives, especially ones that are equally undesirable.

origins: mid 18th century: from French réciprocité, from réciproque, from Latin reciprocus ‘moving backwards and forwards’ (see reciprocate).
meaning: the practice of exchanging things with others for mutual benefit, especially privileges granted by one country or organization to another.

origins: early 19th century (as a medical term in the sense ‘following as a secondary condition’): from sequence, on the pattern of consequential .
meaning: forming or following in a logical order or sequence.

origins: late Middle English (as a term in logic): from late Latin contradictorius, from Latin contradict- ‘spoken against’, from the verb contradicere (see contradict).
meaning: mutually opposed or inconsistent.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin quotiens ‘how many times’ (from quot ‘how many’), by confusion with participial forms ending in -ens, -ent- .
meaning: a result obtained by dividing one quantity by another.;a degree or amount of a specified quality or characteristic.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who physically attacks another

origins: Unknown
meaning: to add strong newly fermenting wort to (beer) to produce natural carbonation

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a smooth surface) reflecting light, typically because very clean or polished

origins: mid 16th century: from French, or from Latin fiscalis, from fiscus ‘purse, treasury’ (see fisc).
meaning: relating to government revenue, especially taxes.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘intercessory prayers’, also ‘assistance’): from Latin suffragium, reinforced by French suffrage . The modern sense of ‘right to vote’ was originally US (dating from the late 18th century).
meaning: the right to vote in political elections.;(in the Book of Common Prayer) the intercessory petitions pronounced by a priest in the Litany.

origins: late 15th century (in the sense ‘bring low, overwhelm’): from Old French succomber or Latin succumbere, from sub- ‘under’ + a verb related to cubare ‘to lie’.
meaning: fail to resist pressure, temptation, or some other negative force.

origins: early 17th century (also used as an adjective meaning ‘nectar-like’): from nectar + -ine4.
meaning: a peach of a variety with smooth red and yellow skin and rich, firm flesh.

origins: late 17th century: modern Latin, from Greek pharunx, pharung- .
meaning: the membrane-lined cavity behind the nose and mouth, connecting them to the oesophagus.

origins: Middle English: via Old French lige, liege from medieval Latin laeticus, probably of Germanic origin.
meaning: concerned with or relating to the relationship between a feudal superior and a vassal.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a person) old or aging

origins: late 16th century: from Latin, from semi- ‘half’ + caput ‘head’.
meaning: the front of the skull from the forehead to the crown.

origins: Middle English: from Old French ancestre, from Latin antecessor, from antecedere, from ante ‘before’ + cedere ‘go’.
meaning: a person, typically one more remote than a grandparent, from whom one is descended.

origins: late 17th century: from French frisquette, from Provençal frisqueto, from Spanish frasqueta .
meaning: a thin metal frame keeping the paper in position during printing on a hand press.

origins: Italian, literally ‘narrow’.
meaning: a passage, especially at the end of an aria or movement, to be performed in quicker time.

origins: mid 18th century (in prosthetic (sense 2 of the adjective)): via late Latin prostheticus from Greek prosthesis : see prosthesis, -ic.
meaning: denoting an artificial body part, such as a limb, a heart, or a breast implant.;denoting a letter or syllable added at the beginning of a word, as in Spanish escuela derived from Latin scola.

origins: mid 18th century (denoting a type of iguana): alteration of iguana.
meaning: a monitor lizard.

origins: Spanish, ultimately from Arabic sikbāj ‘marinated dish’, perhaps via Catalan.
meaning: a dish of fish that is fried then marinated in vinegar and spices.

origins: early 20th century: from German Phaenotypus (see pheno-, type).
meaning: the set of observable characteristics of an individual resulting from the interaction of its genotype with the environment.

origins: mid 16th century: via Latin from Greek anōdunos ‘painless’, from an- ‘without’ + odunē ‘pain’.
meaning: not likely to cause offence or disagreement and somewhat dull.

origins: late 16th century: from Italian, ‘word’.
meaning: a short sentence or phrase chosen as encapsulating the beliefs or ideals of an individual, family, or institution.;a phrase which recurs throughout a musical work and has some symbolical significance.

origins: mid 19th century: from German Zeitgeist, from Zeit ‘time’ + Geist ‘spirit’.
meaning: the defining spirit or mood of a particular period of history as shown by the ideas and beliefs of the time.

origins: 1930s: from Greek allēl- ‘one another’ + -pathy.
meaning: the chemical inhibition of one plant (or other organism) by another, due to the release into the environment of substances acting as germination or growth inhibitors.

origins: mid 17th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: hard reddish-brown timber from a tropical tree, used for quality furniture.;the tropical tree which produces mahogany.

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin affabilis, from the verb affari, from ad- ‘to’ + fari ‘speak’.
meaning: friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘notion’, also ‘quaintly decorative article’): from conceive, on the pattern of pairs such as deceive, deceit .
meaning: excessive pride in oneself.;an ingenious or fanciful comparison or metaphor.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a hybrid between the American buffalo and domestic cattle that is hardier than the latter

origins: late 15th century (in the sense ‘use up, wear out’): perhaps from per- ‘thoroughly’ + use, but compare with Anglo-Norman French peruser ‘examine’.
meaning: read (something), typically in a thorough or careful way.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin ferox, feroc- ‘fierce’ + -ious.
meaning: savagely fierce, cruel, or violent.

origins: late Middle English: from earlier dismal (noun), denoting the two days in each month which in medieval times were believed to be unlucky, from Anglo-Norman French dis mal, from medieval Latin dies mali ‘evil days’.
meaning: causing a mood of gloom or depression.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: extreme patriotism, especially in the form of aggressive or warlike foreign policy

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘deceive, deprive of by fraud’): from be- ‘thoroughly’ + obsolete guile ‘to deceive’ (see guile).
meaning: charm or enchant (someone), often in a deceptive way.;help (time) pass pleasantly.

origins: from Japanese shōji .
meaning: (in Japan) a sliding outer or inner door made of a latticed screen covered with white paper.

origins: Middle English (referring to the ascent of Christ): via Old French from Latin ascensio(n- ), from the verb ascendere (see ascend).
meaning: the action of rising to an important position or a higher level.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: treat (a person, group, or concept) as insignificant or peripheral

origins: mid 17th century: from Greek akoustikos, from akouein ‘hear’.
meaning: relating to sound or the sense of hearing.;(of popular music or musical instruments) not having electrical amplification.

origins: natural exclamation: first recorded in American English in the 1920s.
meaning: expressing wild excitement or delight.

origins: Middle English (also denoting something morally corrupting): from Old French, from Latin pestilentia, based on pestis ‘a plague’.
meaning: a fatal epidemic disease, especially bubonic plague.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who is very fashionable or up to date;very fashionable or up to date

origins: late 19th century: from French, probably imitative.
meaning: a noisy and overexcited reaction or response to something.

origins: Old English bītan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch bijten and German beissen .
meaning: (of a person or animal) use the teeth to cut into or through something.;(of a fish) take the bait or lure on the end of a fishing line into the mouth.;make firm contact with a surface.;(of a policy or situation) take effect, with unpleasant consequences.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a way that displays fondness or tenderness

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘workmanship’): from Old French, from Latin artificium, based on ars, art- ‘art’ + facere ‘make’.
meaning: clever or cunning devices or expedients, especially as used to trick or deceive others.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: parts into which a poem is divided.

origins: late Middle English (denoting an ecclesiastical pastor, also (still a Scots legal term) the guardian of a minor): from Old French curateur or, in later use, directly from Latin curator, from curare (see cure). The current sense dates from the mid 17th century.
meaning: a keeper or custodian of a museum or other collection.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: speak slightingly or abusively of; vilify.;regard as worthless or of little value; despise.

origins: late 16th century (as a term in lacemaking): French, literally ‘net, web’.
meaning: a network or grid.

origins: early 19th century: welter of unknown origin.
meaning: a weight in boxing and other sports intermediate between lightweight and middleweight. In the amateur boxing scale it ranges from 63.5–67 kg.

origins: early 16th century (in the sense ‘move indolently’): perhaps symbolic of slow movement. Sense 1 of the noun dates from the late 19th century.
meaning: lie, sit, or stand in a relaxed or lazy way.

origins: mid 19th century: from Spanish, via Latin from Greek apothēkē ‘storehouse’. Compare with boutique.
meaning: (in a Spanish-speaking country) a wine shop or wine cellar.;(in the US) a small grocery shop, especially in a Spanish-speaking neighbourhood.;a storehouse or storeroom.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a flat, rectangular container, typically made of leather, for carrying books and papers.

origins: early 17th century (in an earlier sense). From ancient Greek ὠτ-, οὖς ear + ἀκουστικός acoustic
meaning: That assists the sense of hearing.

origins: Greek, from Phoenician daleth .
meaning: the fourth letter of the Greek alphabet ( Δ, δ ), transliterated as ‘d’.;a code word representing the letter D, used in radio communication.;a difference between two things or values.

origins: Middle English: from Old French betoine, based on Latin betonica, perhaps from the name of an Iberian tribe.
meaning: a Eurasian plant of the mint family, which bears spikes of showy purple flowers.

origins: Old English pīpere .
meaning: a bagpipe player.;a person who plays a pipe, especially an itinerant musician.

origins: mid 17th century: from late Latin septennis (from Latin septem ‘seven’ + annus ‘year’) + -al.
meaning: recurring every seven years.

origins: late Middle English (also denoting the function or office of a deputy, especially a papal legate): from Old French legacie, from medieval Latin legatia ‘legateship’, from legatus ‘person delegated’ (see legate).
meaning: an amount of money or property left to someone in a will.;an applicant to a particular college or university who is regarded preferentially because a parent or other relative attended the same institution.

origins: 1980s: blend of camera1 and recorder.
meaning: a portable combined video camera and video recorder.

origins: early 17th century: from French cénotaphe, from late Latin cenotaphium, from Greek kenos ‘empty’ + taphos ‘tomb’.
meaning: a monument to someone buried elsewhere, especially one commemorating people who died in a war.

origins: mid 17th century: related to crib; the game is said to have been invented by the English poet Sir John Suckling; it seems to have been developed from an older game called Noddy.
meaning: a card game, usually for two players, in which the objective is to play so that the pip value of one's cards played reaches exactly 15 or 31.

origins: Old English wafian (verb), from the Germanic base of waver; the noun by alteration (influenced by the verb) of Middle English wawe ‘(sea) wave’.
meaning: move one's hand to and fro in greeting or as a signal.;move to and fro with a swaying motion while remaining fixed to one point.;style (hair) so that it curls slightly.

origins: mid 19th century: modern Latin, from Greek ouraios, representing the Egyptian word for ‘cobra’.
meaning: a representation of a sacred serpent as an emblem of supreme power, worn on the headdresses of ancient Egyptian deities and sovereigns.

origins: Middle English: from Old French livree ‘delivered’, feminine past participle of livrer, from Latin liberare ‘liberate’ (in medieval Latin ‘hand over’). The original sense was ‘the dispensing of food, provisions, or clothing to servants’; hence livery1 (sense 4), also ‘allowance of provender for horses’, surviving in the phrase at livery and in livery stable. livery1 (sense 1) arose because medieval nobles provided matching clothes to distinguish their servants from others'.
meaning: a special uniform worn by a servant, an official, or a member of a City Company.;short for livery stable.;(in the UK) the members of a City livery company collectively.;a provision of food or clothing for servants.;the ceremonial procedure at common law of conveying freehold land to a grantee.

origins: mid 19th century: a place name of southern New England, of Algonquian origin.
meaning: a hypothetical small town regarded as typically dull or insignificant.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person suffering from anemia;(of a person) suffering from anemia

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: in a way that deliberately avoids harm or errors; cautiously

origins: late 16th century; from French sécante, based on Latin secare ‘to cut’.
meaning: the ratio of the hypotenuse to the shorter side adjacent to an acute angle (in a right-angled triangle); the reciprocal of a cosine.;a straight line that cuts a curve in two or more parts.

origins: from French jésuite or modern Latin Jesuita, from Christian Latin Iesus (see Jesus).
meaning: a member of the Society of Jesus, a Roman Catholic order of priests founded by St Ignatius Loyola, St Francis Xavier, and others in 1534, to do missionary work. The order was zealous in opposing the Reformation. Despite periodic persecution it has retained an important influence in Catholic thought and education.

origins: Middle English: from Old French thym, via Latin from Greek thumon, from thuein ‘burn, sacrifice’.
meaning: a low-growing aromatic plant of the mint family. The small leaves are used as a culinary herb and the plant yields a medicinal oil.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: able to be used for a practical purpose or in several ways

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin vivax, vivac- ‘lively, vigorous’ (from vivere ‘to live’) + -ious.
meaning: attractively lively and animated (typically used of a woman).

origins: late Middle English: via French from Latin impenetrabilis, from in- ‘not’ + penetrabilis ‘able to be pierced’, from the verb penetrare (see penetrate).
meaning: impossible to pass through or enter.;impossible to understand.

origins: Old English wīsdōm  (see wise1, -dom).
meaning: the quality of having experience, knowledge, and good judgement; the quality of being wise.

origins: Old English lȳtel, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch luttel, German dialect lützel .
meaning: small in size, amount, or degree (often used to convey an appealing diminutiveness or express an affectionate or condescending attitude).

origins: late Middle English (denoting the administration of drugs): from Old French farmacie, via medieval Latin from Greek pharmakeia ‘practice of the druggist’, based on pharmakon ‘drug’.
meaning: a shop or hospital dispensary where medicinal drugs are prepared or sold.

origins: Middle English: from Old French dromedaire or late Latin dromedarius (camelus ) ‘swift camel’, based on Greek dromas, dromad- ‘runner’.
meaning: an Arabian camel, especially one of a light and swift breed trained for riding or racing.

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘final point in space or time’): from Latin, ‘end, limit, boundary’.
meaning: the end of a railway or other transport route, or a station at such a point; a terminal.;a final point in space or time; an end or extremity.;a figure of a human bust or an animal ending in a square pillar from which it appears to spring, originally used as a boundary marker in ancient Rome.

origins: mid 16th century: probably based on Old English drēosan  ‘to fall’, of Germanic origin; probably related to dreary.
meaning: light rain falling in very fine drops.;(in cooking) a thin stream of a liquid ingredient trickled over food.

origins: late 16th century: perhaps a blend of founder3 and blunder, or perhaps symbolic, fl- frequently beginning words connected with swift or sudden movement.
meaning: struggle or stagger clumsily in mud or water.

origins: Middle English: from Old French seizir ‘give seisin’, from medieval Latin sacire, in the phrase ad proprium sacire ‘claim as one's own’, from a Germanic base meaning ‘procedure’.
meaning: take hold of suddenly and forcibly.;take (an opportunity) eagerly and decisively.;(of a feeling or pain) affect (someone) suddenly or acutely.;strongly appeal to or attract (the imagination or attention).;(of a machine with moving parts) become jammed.;fasten or attach (someone or something) to something by binding with turns of rope.

origins: Old English twengan  ‘pinch, wring’, of Germanic origin. The noun dates from the mid 16th century.
meaning: a sudden, sharp localized pain.

origins: late 16th century: perhaps from obsolete Italian cozzonare ‘to cheat’, from cozzone ‘middleman, broker’, from Latin cocio ‘dealer’.
meaning: trick or deceive.

origins: 1960s: from peace + -nik.
meaning: a member of a pacifist movement.

origins: mid 18th century: Italian, from sopra ‘above’, from Latin supra .
meaning: the highest singing voice.;an instrument of a high or the highest pitch in its family.

origins: early 17th century: from obsolete sheen  ‘beautiful, resplendent’; apparently related to the verb shine.
meaning: a soft lustre on a surface.

origins: early 19th century: apparently from dialect tiffing  ‘sipping’, of unknown origin.
meaning: a snack or light meal.;a cake or dessert made with crushed biscuits, golden syrup, and chocolate, and chilled in a fridge.

origins: early 18th century: from French, from Old French dialect ruissole, from a feminine form of late Latin russeolus ‘reddish’, from Latin russus ‘red’.
meaning: a compressed mixture of meat and spices, coated in breadcrumbs and fried.

origins: Middle English: Old French, from medieval Latin hominaticum, from Latin homo, homin- ‘man’ (the original use of the word denoted the ceremony by which a vassal declared himself to be his lord's ‘man’).
meaning: special honour or respect shown publicly.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: of, pertaining to, noting, or of the nature of a parenthesis several unnecessary parenthetic remarks

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a thing that persuades or influences someone to do something

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: make into or become an emulsion

origins: late 17th century: from Latin tubulus ‘small tube’ + -ar1.
meaning: long, round, and hollow like a tube.;of or involving tubules or other tube-shaped structures.

origins: late 15th century: of unknown origin. The original meaning was ‘push, shove’ (noun and verb), a sense retained now in Scots as a noun, and in US dialect as a verb. Sense 1 of the noun derives probably from a US sense of the verb ‘nudge someone in order to draw attention to something’.
meaning: raise (one's shoulders) and bend the top of one's body forward.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French flacon, based on late Latin flasco, flascon-, of unknown origin. Compare with flask.
meaning: a large container in which drink is served, typically with a handle and spout.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a high level of activity in an economy or stock market;an optimistic and cheerful disposition;the ability or tendency to float in water or air or some other fluid.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the product of an integer and all the integers below it; e.g. factorial four (4!) is equal to 24.;relating to a factor or factorial

origins: mid 19th century: named after Anders Celsius (see Celsius, Anders).
meaning: of or denoting a scale of temperature on which water freezes at 0° and boils at 100° under standard conditions.

origins: early 18th century: from Latin sessilis, from sess- ‘seated’, from the verb sedere .
meaning: (of an organism, e.g. a barnacle) fixed in one place; immobile.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a person born before a certain time or event especially with reference to the existence of political rights (as a person born in an American colony before the Declaration of Independence)áŚusually used in plural

origins: mid 16th century: from Italian banca rotta ‘broken bench’, from banca (see bank2) and rompere ‘to break’. The change in the ending was due to association with Latin rupt- ‘broken’.
meaning: (of a person or organization) declared in law as unable to pay their debts.;completely lacking in a particular good quality.

origins: early 19th century: from French, from gastronomie (see gastronomy).
meaning: a gourmet.

origins: early 17th century: variant of german, with which it was synonymous from Middle English. The current sense has arisen from a usage in Shakespeare's Hamlet .
meaning: relevant to a subject under consideration.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: denoting the standard layout on English-language typewriters and keyboards, having q, w, e, r, t, and y as the first keys from the left on the top row of letters

origins: late Middle English: from the phrase all be it  ‘although it be (that’).
meaning: though.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or promoting anabolism.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin sacerdotalis, from sacerdos, sacerdot- ‘priest’.
meaning: relating to priests or the priesthood; priestly.

origins: early 20th century: from French, feminine of romain ‘Roman’.
meaning: a lettuce of a variety with crisp narrow leaves that form a tall head.

origins: late Middle English (in the senses ‘absorb or cause to absorb moisture’ and ‘take into solution’): from Latin imbibere, from in- ‘in’ + bibere ‘to drink’.
meaning: drink (alcohol).

origins: mid 16th century (earlier (late Middle English) as immolation ): from Latin immolat- ‘sprinkled with sacrificial meal’, from the verb immolare, from in- ‘upon’ + mola ‘meal’.
meaning: kill or offer as a sacrifice, especially by burning.

origins: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin lumbaris, from Latin lumbus ‘loin’.
meaning: relating to the lower part of the back.

origins: Old English sweorfan  ‘depart, leave, turn aside’, of Germanic origin; related to Middle Dutch swerven ‘to stray’.
meaning: change or cause to change direction abruptly.

origins: Middle English. From Anglo-Norman aferer, affeerer, afferer, affurer, afurer, Anglo-Norman and Middle French affeurer, Middle French afeurer (also Anglo-Norman affoerer, Anglo-Norman and Middle French afforer, Old French, Middle French aforer; French †affeurer, †afforer) to determine the value of (goods, or a weight or measure), to tax (someone), to fix the amount of (an amercement) from post-classical Latin afforare to assess, to appraise, fix the price of from classical Latin af-, variant of ad- + forum market, in post-classical Latin also market price
meaning: To determine, decide, assess; (Law) to fix or settle the amount of (a fine or amercement), typically by adjusting a generally prescribed penalty according to the particular circumstances of an offender and his or her offence; to settle the amount to be paid by (a person); to perform this task for (a certain community or region).

origins: early 17th century: from Latin consternatio(n- ), from the verb consternare ‘lay prostrate, terrify’ (see consternate).
meaning: a feeling of anxiety or dismay, typically at something unexpected.

origins: late 17th century (in the sense ‘resembling a pouch’): from modern Latin marsupialis, via Latin from Greek marsupion ‘pouch’ (see marsupium).
meaning: a mammal of an order whose members are born incompletely developed and are typically carried and suckled in a pouch on the mother's belly. Marsupials are found chiefly in Australia and New Guinea, and also in America.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin, neuter of continuus (see continuous).
meaning: a continuous sequence in which adjacent elements are not perceptibly different from each other, but the extremes are quite distinct.

origins: Middle English: from Old French letanie, via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek litaneia ‘prayer’, from litē ‘supplication’.
meaning: a series of petitions for use in church services or processions, usually recited by the clergy and responded to in a recurring formula by the people.;a tedious recital or repetitive series.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘duality, a pair’): from late Latin binarius, from bini ‘two together’.
meaning: relating to, composed of, or involving two things.;relating to, using, or denoting a system of numerical notation that has 2 rather than 10 as a base.

origins: Old English wæcce  ‘watchfulness’, wæccende  ‘remaining awake’; related to wake1. The sense ‘small timepiece’ probably developed by way of a sense ‘alarm device attached to a clock’.
meaning: look at or observe attentively over a period of time.;exercise care, caution, or restraint about.;remain awake for the purpose of religious observance.

origins: Unknown
meaning: an official announcementáátypicallyá:áa brief formal summation report

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: gaudy articles or decoration, especially clothing or jewelry.;tasteless or extravagant display of gaudy articles or decoration.

origins: late 16th century (also in the general sense ‘fact of seeing wrongly’): from French parallaxe, from Greek parallaxis ‘a change’, from parallassein ‘to alternate’, based on allassein ‘to exchange’ (from allos ‘other’).
meaning: the effect whereby the position or direction of an object appears to differ when viewed from different positions, e.g. through the viewfinder and the lens of a camera.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a cowboy or herdsman in Spanish America

origins: mid 16th century: via Latin from Greek panakeia, from panakēs ‘all-healing’, from pan ‘all’ + akos ‘remedy’.
meaning: a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin lateralis, from latus, later- ‘side’.
meaning: of, at, towards, or from the side or sides.;involving lateral thinking.;(of a consonant, especially the English clear l ) pronounced with partial closure of the air passage by the tongue, which is so placed as to allow the breath to flow on one or both sides of the point of contact.

origins: late 19th century: from Greek phloos ‘bark’ + the passive suffix -ēma .
meaning: the vascular tissue in plants which conducts sugars and other metabolic products downwards from the leaves.

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French merilun, from Old French esmerillon, augmentative of esmeril, of Germanic origin; related to German Schmerl .
meaning: a small dark falcon that hunts small birds, found throughout most of Eurasia and North America.

origins: mid 18th century: from French nobiliaire, based on Latin nobilis (see noble).
meaning: relating to the nobility.

origins: mid 19th century: blend of altitude and azimuth.
meaning: a telescope mounting that moves in azimuth (about a vertical axis) and in altitude (about a horizontal axis).;a surveying instrument for measuring vertical and horizontal angles, resembling a theodolite but larger and more precise.

origins: Unknown
meaning: ness

origins: late Middle English: the adjective from Latin supinus ‘bent backwards’ (related to super ‘above’); the noun from late Latin supinum, neuter of supinus .
meaning: (of a person) lying face upwards.;failing to act or protest as a result of moral weakness or indolence.

origins: late 18th century: from Greek axiōmatikos, from axiōma ‘what is thought fitting’ (see axiom).
meaning: self-evident or unquestionable.

origins: early 18th century: from Tupi-Guarani tipioca, from tipi ‘dregs’ + og, ok ‘squeeze out’.
meaning: a starchy substance in the form of hard white grains, obtained from cassava and used in cooking for puddings and other dishes.

origins: late Middle English; earliest use found in Morte Arthure. From Anglo-Norman alette, specific use of alette little wing from ale wing + -ete
meaning: Each of a pair of pieces of leather or other material worn over the shoulders as part of the accoutrements of an armoured knight or man-at-arms.

origins: Middle English (also in the sense ‘robust, well-built’): from Old French vailant, based on Latin valere ‘be strong’.
meaning: possessing or showing courage or determination.

origins: late Middle English damascene, from Latin damascenum (prunum ) ‘(plum) of Damascus’. Compare with Damascene and damask.
meaning: a small purple-black fruit similar to the plum.;the small deciduous tree which bears damsons, probably derived from the bullace.

origins: early 20th century: Portuguese, past participle of turbinar ‘to spin’ (with reference to the use of turbines to spin the sugar during its production).
meaning: a type of partially refined light brown cane sugar similar to demerara but with larger crystals.

origins: early 19th century; earliest use found in Aberdeen Journal. Probably from grand + drill, in which case some forms probably show alteration by association with words in -elle;Etymology Unknown
meaning: Of a yarn, twist, or item of clothing: made of grandrelle.;A mottled yarn which is plied with two different colours of thread; (also) an (especially cotton) cloth made from a warp of such yarn and a plain-coloured weft, used especially for making shirts or trousers.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, ‘attendant spirit present from one's birth, innate ability or inclination’, from the root of gignere ‘beget’. The original sense ‘spirit attendant on a person’ gave rise to a sense ‘a person's characteristic disposition’ (late 16th century), which led to a sense ‘a person's natural ability’, and finally ‘exceptional natural ability’ (mid 17th century).
meaning: exceptional intellectual or creative power or other natural ability.;an exceptionally intelligent person or one with exceptional skill in a particular area of activity.;a person regarded as exerting a powerful influence over another for good or evil.;the prevailing character or spirit of something.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: situated or applied under the skin

origins: late 19th century: from samar(skite), a mineral in which its spectrum was first observed (named after Samarsky, a 19th-century Russian official) + -ium.
meaning: the chemical element of atomic number 62, a hard silvery-white metal of the lanthanide series.

origins: early 19th century: from topaz + -lite.
meaning: a variety of andradite (garnet) that is yellowish green.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin aestivalis, from aestivus, from aestus ‘heat’.
meaning: belonging to or appearing in summer.

origins: Middle English: from Old French comparesoun, from Latin comparatio(n- ), from comparare ‘to pair, match’ (see compare).
meaning: a consideration or estimate of the similarities or dissimilarities between two things or people.;the formation of the comparative and superlative forms of adjectives and adverbs.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin, literally ‘load or burden’.
meaning: something that is one's duty or responsibility.

origins: from French Aztèque or Spanish Azteca, from Nahuatl aztecatl ‘person of Aztlan’, their legendary place of origin.
meaning: a member of the indigenous people dominant in Mexico before the Spanish conquest of the 16th century.;the extinct language of the Aztecs, a Uto-Aztecan language from which modern Nahuatl is descended.

origins: 1950s: from Greek spēlaion ‘cave’ + thema ‘deposit’.
meaning: a structure formed in a cave by the deposition of minerals from water, e.g. a stalactite or stalagmite.

origins: early 16th century (in the sense ‘be moved or thrown with a sudden jerk’): probably imitative of the sound of feet coming into contact with the ground.
meaning: push oneself off a surface and into the air by using the muscles in one's legs and feet.;(of a person) move suddenly and quickly in a specified way.;attack (someone) suddenly and unexpectedly.;(of a place) be full of lively activity.;have sex with (someone).;start (a vehicle) using jump leads.

origins: 1920s (originally US): of unknown origin but possibly an approximate anagram of magic, the original sense being ‘a piece of magicians' apparatus’.
meaning: a trick or device intended to attract attention, publicity, or trade.;a night out with friends.

origins: early 20th century: from poly- ‘many’ + Greek sēma ‘sign’.
meaning: the coexistence of many possible meanings for a word or phrase.

origins: late 19th century: from petro- ‘rock’ + Greek glyphē ‘carving’.
meaning: a rock carving, especially a prehistoric one.

origins: from Chinese rénmínbì, from rénmín ‘people’ + bì ‘currency’.
meaning: the system of currency of the People's Republic of China, introduced in 1948.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: grand and impressive in appearance

origins: late Middle English: via Latin from Greek Amazōn, explained by the Greeks as ‘without a breast’ (as if from a- ‘without’ + mazos ‘breast’), referring to the fable that the Amazons cut off the right breast so as not to interfere with the use of a bow, but probably a folk etymology of an unknown foreign word.
meaning: a member of a legendary race of female warriors believed by the ancient Greeks to exist in Scythia (near the Black Sea in modern Russia) or elsewhere on the edge of the known world.;a parrot, typically green, found in Central and South America.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: any of the carpal bones.;relating to the bones forming the human carpus (wrist), or to their equivalent in an animal's forelimb.

origins: early 19th century. From post-classical Latin and scientific Latin disciformis from disci-, combining form of classical Latin discus + -formis
meaning: Of a composite flower: composed of fertile disc florets with reduced or filiform marginal florets, superficially similar to a discoid flower.;Having the form of a disc; disc-shaped, discoidal; (Medicine) characterized by lesions of this form.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French garden, of Germanic origin; compare with ward and warden. The ending was altered by association with -ian.
meaning: a person who protects or defends something.;the superior of a Franciscan convent.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the quality or state of being irritable

origins: late 19th century: from Marathōn in Greece, the scene of a victory over the Persians in 490 BC; the modern race is based on the tradition that a messenger ran from Marathon to Athens (22 miles) with the news. The original account by Herodotus told of the messenger Pheidippides running 150 miles from Athens to Sparta before the battle, seeking help.
meaning: a long-distance running race, strictly one of 26 miles 385 yards (42.195 km).

origins: Middle English: from Old French baillif, inflected form of bailli (see bailie), based on Latin bajulus ‘carrier, manager’.
meaning: a sheriff's officer who executes writs and processes and carries out distraints and arrests.;an official in a court of law who keeps order, looks after prisoners, etc.;the sovereign's representative in a district, especially the chief officer of a hundred.

origins: mid 19th century: from French rôtisserie, from rôtir ‘to roast’.
meaning: a restaurant specializing in roasted or barbecued meat.;a cooking appliance with a rotating spit for roasting and barbecuing meat.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin fluentia, from fluere ‘to flow’.
meaning: the quality or condition of being fluent.

origins: mid 19th century: formed irregularly from vegetable + -arian.
meaning: a person who does not eat meat or fish, and sometimes other animal products, especially for moral, religious, or health reasons.

origins: early 19th century (denoting a water butt on the deck of a ship, providing drinking water): from scuttled butt . Sailors would traditionally exchange gossip when they gathered at the scuttlebutt for a drink of water.
meaning: rumour; gossip.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French moite, from Latin medietas ‘middle’, from medius ‘mid, middle’.
meaning: each of two parts into which a thing is or can be divided.

origins: late Middle English: via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek neophutos, literally ‘newly planted’ but first used in the sense ‘new convert’ by St Paul (1 Tim. 3:6), from neos ‘new’ + phuton ‘plant’.
meaning: a person who is new to a subject or activity.;a new convert to a religion.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: theft or misappropriation of funds placed in one's trust or belonging to one's employer

origins: Unknown
meaning: bearing or containing yttrium or related elements

origins: Unknown
meaning: unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something

origins: early 18th century: perhaps a fanciful variant of settle2.
meaning: a long upholstered seat for more than one person, typically with a back and arms.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French espousaille, from Latin sponsalia ‘betrothal’, neuter plural of sponsalis (adjective), from sponsare ‘espouse, betroth’ (see espouse).
meaning: an act of adopting or supporting a cause, belief, or way of life.;a marriage or engagement.

origins: Middle English cayser, from Old Norse keisari, based on Latin Caesar (see Caesar1), and later reinforced by Middle Dutch keiser . The modern English form (early 19th century) derives from German Kaiser .
meaning: the German Emperor, the Emperor of Austria, or the head of the Holy Roman Empire.;a round, soft bread roll with a crisp crust, made by folding the corners of a square of dough into the centre, resulting in a pinwheel shape when baked.

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, variant of Old French aiguiere, based on Latin aquarius ‘of water’, from aqua ‘water’.
meaning: a large jug with a wide mouth, formerly used for carrying water.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin pugnax, pugnac- (from pugnare ‘to fight’, from pugnus ‘fist’) + -ious.
meaning: eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight.

origins: modern Latin, named after Gaillard de Marentonneau, 18th-century French amateur botanist.
meaning: an American plant of the daisy family, which is cultivated for its bright red and yellow flowers.

origins: late 19th century: from French croquignole ‘flip, flick’
meaning: a board game played mainly in Canada, in which players take turns flicking small disks across a circular playing surface with the aim of displacing opponents' pieces and landing in the higher-scoring central sections

origins: mid 19th century: from Glengarry, the name of a valley in the Highlands of Scotland.
meaning: a brimless boat-shaped hat with a cleft down the centre, typically having two ribbons hanging at the back, worn as part of Highland dress.

origins: Old English cild, of Germanic origin. The Middle English plural childer or childre became childeren or children by association with plurals ending in -en, such as brethren .
meaning: a young human being below the age of puberty or below the legal age of majority.

origins: mid 18th century: from Italian, diminutive of casa ‘house’, from Latin casa ‘cottage’.
meaning: a public room or building where gambling games are played.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a reactionary person;(of a person or a set of views) opposing political or social liberalization or reform

origins: late 16th century: from medieval Latin miscibilis, from Latin miscere ‘to mix’.
meaning: (of liquids) forming a homogeneous mixture when added together.

origins: mid 19th century: from volume + metric1.
meaning: relating to the measurement of volume.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: lack of skill or ability

origins: mid 16th century (originally denoting a physical gap): from Latin, literally ‘gaping’, from hiare ‘gape’.
meaning: a pause or break in continuity in a sequence or activity.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin amuletum, of unknown origin.
meaning: an ornament or small piece of jewellery thought to give protection against evil, danger, or disease.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action of matriculating at a college or university;the registration of arms in an official register.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: not particularly attractive or appealing to the eye

origins: late 15th century (denoting the district under the charge of a constable): from medieval Latin constabularia (dignitas) ‘(rank) of constable’, from constabulus, based on Latin comes stabuli (see constable).
meaning: a police force covering a particular area or city.

origins: late 15th century: from French, present participle of mordre ‘to bite’, from Latin mordere .
meaning: (especially of humour) having or showing a sharp or critical quality; biting.

origins: Old English swāt (noun), swǣtan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zweet and German Schweiss, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin sudor .
meaning: moisture exuded through the pores of the skin, typically in profuse quantities as a reaction to heat, physical exertion, fever, or fear.;another term for sweatsuit or sweatpants.

origins: late 15th century (in minority (sense 2)): from French minorité or medieval Latin minoritas, from Latin minor ‘smaller’ (see minor).
meaning: the smaller number or part, especially a number or part representing less than half of the whole.;the state or period of being under the age of full legal responsibility.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a horse of a thoroughbred breed.;(of a horse) of pure breed, especially of a breed originating from English mares and Arab stallions and widely used as racehorses

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an earnest and persistent quality; insistence;importance requiring swift action

origins: late 17th century: from Latin, diminutive of malleus ‘hammer’.
meaning: a bony projection with a shape likened to a hammer head, especially each of those on either side of the ankle.

origins: French, from Italian canaglia ‘pack of dogs’, from cane ‘dog’.
meaning: the common people; the masses.

origins: late Middle English (denoting yellow orpiment, arsenic sulfide): via Old French from Latin arsenicum, from Greek arsenikon ‘yellow orpiment’, identified with arsenikos ‘male’, but in fact from Arabic al-zarnīḵ ‘the orpiment’, based on Persian zar ‘gold’;Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to arsenic.;the chemical element of atomic number 33, a brittle steel-gray metalloid.

origins: early 19th century: named after the town of Paisley (see Paisley), the original place of manufacture.
meaning: a distinctive intricate pattern of curved feather-shaped figures based on an Indian pine-cone design.

origins: mid 16th century: from French sédiment or Latin sedimentum ‘settling’, from sedere ‘sit’.
meaning: matter that settles to the bottom of a liquid; dregs.

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin incantatio(n- ), from incantare ‘chant, bewitch’ (see incant).
meaning: a series of words said as a magic spell or charm.

origins: Spanish, from torear ‘fight bulls’, from toro ‘bull’.
meaning: a bullfighter, especially one on horseback.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French meridien, from Latin meridianum (neuter, used as a noun) ‘noon’, from medius ‘middle’ + dies ‘day’. The use in astronomy is due to the fact that the sun crosses a meridian at noon.
meaning: a circle of constant longitude passing through a given place on the earth's surface and the terrestrial poles.;(in acupuncture and Chinese medicine) each of a set of pathways in the body along which vital energy is said to flow.

origins: mid 16th century: from French iambique, via late Latin from Greek iambikos, from iambos (see iambus).
meaning: of or using iambuses.

origins: Unknown
meaning: an epidemic and fatal disease of silkworms believed to result from the combined action of a virus and a streptococcus

origins: late Middle English: perhaps from an Anglo-Norman French alteration of Old French robe ‘spoils’; compare with rubbish.
meaning: waste or rough fragments of stone, brick, concrete, etc., especially as the debris from the demolition of buildings.

origins: mid 16th century: from French, from accoutrer ‘clothe, equip’ (see accoutre).
meaning: an additional item of dress or equipment.

origins: mid 19th century; earliest use found in New York Journal Medicine. From French rongeur (noun) person who gnaws, rodent, (adjective) gnawing, corrosive from ronger to gnaw + -eur
meaning: Any of various types of surgical forceps having a biting action, typically used to remove small pieces of bone. Also "rongeur forceps".

origins: Old English thancas, plural of thanc  ‘(kindly) thought, gratitude’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dank and German Dank, also to think.
meaning: an expression of gratitude.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who enjoys spending time outside during warm weather, especially one who travels to a destination for its warmth and sun

origins: early 19th century: alteration of earlier platina, from Spanish, diminutive of plata ‘silver’.
meaning: a precious silvery-white metal, the chemical element of atomic number 78. It was first encountered by the Spanish in South America in the 16th century, and is used in jewellery, electrical contacts, laboratory equipment, and industrial catalysts.

origins: late Middle English: probably of Scandinavian origin; related to Swedish glimra and Danish glimre .
meaning: shine faintly with a wavering light.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘place of refuge’, especially for criminals): via Latin from Greek asulon ‘refuge’, from asulos ‘inviolable’, from a- ‘without’ + sulon ‘right of seizure’. Current senses date from the 18th century.
meaning: the protection granted by a state to someone who has left their home country as a political refugee.;an institution for the care of people who are mentally ill.

origins: Middle English (denoting knowledge): from Old French, from Latin scientia, from scire ‘know’.
meaning: the intellectual and practical activity encompassing the systematic study of the structure and behaviour of the physical and natural world through observation and experiment.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘booty, pilfered property’): from a variant of Old French pelfre ‘spoils’, of unknown origin. Compare with pilfer.
meaning: money, especially when gained in a dishonest or dishonourable way.

origins: Etymology Unknown;early 17th century: from Latin enervat- ‘weakened (by extraction of the sinews)’, from the verb enervare, from e- (variant of ex- ‘out of’ + nervus ‘sinew’
meaning: lacking in energy or vitality;cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, ‘shin bone’.
meaning: the inner and typically larger of the two bones between the knee and the ankle (or the equivalent joints in other terrestrial vertebrates), parallel with the fibula.

origins: late 16th century: from Turkish, from Persian ḵaftān, partly influenced by French cafetan .
meaning: a man's long belted tunic, worn in countries of the Near East.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: approaching; moving toward;the fact of being about to happen in the near future

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin minax, minac- ‘threatening’ (from minari ‘threaten’) + -ous.
meaning: menacing; threatening.

origins: late 18th century; earliest use found in Charles Plowden (1743–1821), Jesuit. From ancient Greek νεωτερισμός innovation, change from νεωτερίζειν to make innovations (from νεώτερος + -ίζειν) + -ισμός
meaning: Originally: modernity, novelty, innovation (especially in language). Later also: the use of new words or phrases, neologism; an instance of this.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, literally ‘something to be brought to mind’, gerundive of memorare . The original use was as an adjective, placed at the head of a note of a record made for future reference.
meaning: a written message in business or diplomacy.

origins: 1950s: probably from point in the sense ‘lace made entirely with a needle’ + the French diminutive suffix -elle .
meaning: a type of knitwear or woollen fabric with small eyelet holes that create a lacy effect.

origins: Old English thawian (verb), of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch dooien . The noun (first recorded in Middle English) developed its figurative use in the mid 19th century.
meaning: (of ice, snow, or another frozen substance, such as food) become liquid or soft as a result of warming up.

origins: early 17th century: from Tamil paṛaiyar, plural of paṛaiyan ‘(hereditary) drummer’, from paṛai ‘a drum’.
meaning: an outcast.;a member of an indigenous people of southern India originally functioning as ceremonial drummers but later having a low caste.

origins: early 18th century: from obsolete French, from conoistre ‘know’.
meaning: an expert judge in matters of taste.

origins: late 16th century: from French, or from Latin transcriptio(n- ), from the verb transcribere (see transcribe).
meaning: a written or printed version of something; a transcript.;an arrangement of a piece of music for a different instrument, voice, or group of these.;the process of transcribing RNA, with existing DNA serving as a template, or vice versa.

origins: Old English folgian, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch volgen and German folgen .
meaning: go or come after (a person or thing proceeding ahead); move or travel behind.;come after in time or order.;act according to (an instruction or precept).;pay close attention to.;practise (a trade or profession).

origins: Middle English (as a verb): probably a back-formation from sighte, past tense of siche, sike, from Old English sīcan .
meaning: emit a long, deep audible breath expressing sadness, relief, tiredness, or similar.

origins: late 18th century (originally US): from Latin campus ‘field’ (see camp1).
meaning: the grounds and buildings of a university or college.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a bacterium, virus, or other microorganism that can cause disease.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to a widely held but fixed and oversimplified image or idea of a particular type of person or thing

origins: Old English sting (noun), stingan (verb), of Germanic origin.
meaning: a small sharp-pointed organ at the end of the abdomen of bees, wasps, ants, and scorpions, capable of inflicting a painful or dangerous wound by injecting poison.;a carefully planned operation, typically one involving deception.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a woman's light, decorative headpiece consisting of feathers, flowers, beads, etc. attached to a comb or hair clip.;a fascinating person.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the display of strong feeling; passion

origins: mid 17th century: via late Latin from Greek homilētikos, from homilein ‘converse with, consort’, from homilia (see homily).
meaning: the art of preaching or writing sermons.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: making a loud and confused noise

origins: early 20th century: from German Zug ‘move’ + Zwang ‘compulsion’.
meaning: a situation in which the obligation to make a move in one's turn is a serious, often decisive, disadvantage.

origins: late 17th century (in bursary (sense 2)): from medieval Latin bursaria, from bursa ‘bag, purse’ (see bursa).
meaning: a grant, especially one awarded to someone to enable them to study at university or college.;the room of a bursar in a college or school.

origins: late Middle English (in papyrus (sense 2)): via Latin from Greek papuros . Sense 1 dates from the early 18th century.
meaning: a material prepared in ancient Egypt from the pithy stem of a water plant, used in sheets throughout the ancient Mediterranean world for writing or painting on and also for making articles such as rope.;the tall aquatic sedge from which papyrus is obtained, native to central Africa and the Nile valley.

origins: mid 19th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: uncontrollably exuberant; boisterous.

origins: mid 16th century (originally Scots): probably of Low German origin.
meaning: a curling tournament.

origins: late 16th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: a feeling of offence or deep resentment.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin lugubris (from lugere ‘mourn’) + -ous.
meaning: looking or sounding sad and dismal.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin aberratio(n- ), from aberrare ‘to stray’ (see aberrant).
meaning: a departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.

origins: Greek, ‘bare or simple E’, from psilos ‘bare’.
meaning: the fifth letter of the Greek alphabet ( Ε, ε ), transliterated as ‘e’.

origins: early 20th century: from cellulose + -phane, from diaphane, a kind of semi-transparent woven silk (from medieval Latin diaphanus ‘diaphanous’).
meaning: a thin transparent wrapping material made from viscose.

origins: early 17th century (originally denoting a Roman law for the division of conquered lands): from Latin agrarius, from ager, agr- ‘field’.
meaning: relating to cultivated land or the cultivation of land.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: one thousandth of a volt.

origins: late 17th century: from French, denoting a hood worn by priests in winter, probably based on Latin dominus ‘lord, master’.
meaning: any of 28 small oblong pieces marked with 0–6 pips in each half.;a loose cloak, worn with a mask for the upper part of the face at masquerades.

origins: mid 17th century: from French réveillez! ‘wake up!’, imperative plural of réveiller, based on Latin vigilare ‘keep watch’.

origins: late Middle English (denoting straightness): from Old French, from late Latin rectitudo, from Latin rectus ‘right, straight’.
meaning: morally correct behaviour or thinking; righteousness.

origins: Old English cēosan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kiezen .
meaning: pick out (someone or something) as being the best or most appropriate of two or more alternatives.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: Something that is desultory is done in an unplanned and disorganized way, and without enthusiasm.

origins: late 16th century: from Arabic muftī, active participle of 'aftā ‘decide a point of law’.

origins: Old English sife (noun), of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch zeef and German Sieb .

origins: early 16th century (denoting unity or reconciliation, especially between God and man): from at one + -ment, influenced by medieval Latin adunamentum ‘unity’, and earlier onement from an obsolete verb one ‘to unite’.

origins: late 16th century: via Latin from Greek paronomasia, from para- ‘beside’ (expressing alteration) + onomasia ‘naming’ (from onomazein ‘to name’, from onoma ‘a name’).
meaning: a play on words; a pun.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who composes the sequence of steps and moves for a performance of dance

origins: early 17th century (also in the sense ‘fairness, impartiality’): from Latin aequanimitas, from aequus ‘equal’ + animus ‘mind’.
meaning: calmness and composure, especially in a difficult situation.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: by means of virtual reality techniques.;nearly; almost

origins: late 16th century: from French, from Italian popolaccio ‘common people’, from popolo ‘people’ + the pejorative suffix -accio .
meaning: the people living in a particular country or area.

origins: French.
meaning: a native or inhabitant of the French city of Nice.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French serieux or late Latin seriosus, from Latin serius ‘earnest, serious’.
meaning: demanding or characterized by careful consideration or application.;acting or speaking sincerely and in earnest, rather than in a joking or half-hearted manner.;significant or worrying because of possible danger or risk; not slight or negligible.;substantial in terms of size, number, or quality.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: with sincere and intense conviction; seriously

origins: late 17th century: from French, literally ‘large chest’, from Italian cassone, the spelling having been altered in French by association with caisse ‘case’.
meaning: a large watertight chamber, open at the bottom, from which the water is kept out by air pressure and in which construction work may be carried out under water.;a chest or wagon for holding or conveying ammunition.

origins: mid 18th century: from Chinese siú ‘small’ + chúng ‘sort’.
meaning: a fine black variety of China tea.

origins: late Middle English: apparently via Old French from Provençal fonilh, from late Latin fundibulum, from Latin infundibulum, from infundere, from in- ‘into’ + fundere ‘pour’.
meaning: a tube or pipe that is wide at the top and narrow at the bottom, used for guiding liquid or powder into a small opening.;a metal chimney on a ship or steam engine.

origins: early 17th century (denoting a stew made of different kinds of meat): from French, literally ‘rotten pot’.
meaning: a mixture of dried petals and spices placed in a bowl to perfume a room.

origins: mid 19th century: named after Sylvester Graham (1794–1851), an American advocate of dietary reform.
meaning: denoting or made from wholewheat flour that has not been sifted.

origins: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘having two modes of existence or of doubtful nature’): from modern Latin amphibium ‘an amphibian’, from Greek amphibion (noun use of amphibios ‘living both in water and on land’, from amphi ‘both’ + bios ‘life’).
meaning: a cold-blooded vertebrate animal of a class that comprises the frogs, toads, newts, salamanders, and caecilians. They are distinguished by having an aquatic gill-breathing larval stage followed (typically) by a terrestrial lung-breathing adult stage.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a cancer) spread to other sites in the body by metastasis

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to gladiators

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to Egypt or its people.;the Afro-Asiatic language used in ancient Egypt, attested from c.3000 BC. It is represented in its oldest stages by hieroglyphic inscriptions and in its latest form by Coptic; it has been replaced in modern use by Arabic.;a native of ancient or modern Egypt, or a person of Egyptian descent.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: inflammation of the tonsils.

origins: from Urdu and Persian tandūri, from tandūr (see tandoor).
meaning: denoting or relating to a style of Indian cooking based on the use of a tandoor.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: aimlessly

origins: early 19th century: from Titian1, by association with the bright auburn hair portrayed in many of his works.
meaning: (of hair) bright golden auburn.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin, ‘seaweed’.
meaning: a simple, non-flowering, and typically aquatic plant of a large group that includes the seaweeds and many single-celled forms. Algae contain chlorophyll but lack true stems, roots, leaves, and vascular tissue.

origins: 1920s: blend of gene and chromosome.
meaning: the haploid set of chromosomes in a gamete or microorganism, or in each cell of a multicellular organism.

origins: Unknown
meaning: sad; dismal; dull

origins: Unknown
meaning: a rhymed folk verse usually of four lines traditional in form but often having political or topical content

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin pervas- ‘passed through’ (from the verb pervadere ) + -ive.
meaning: (especially of an unwelcome influence or physical effect) spreading widely throughout an area or a group of people.

origins: late Middle English: from French préparer or Latin praeparare, from prae ‘before’ + parare ‘make ready’.
meaning: make (something) ready for use or consideration.;make (someone) ready or able to do or deal with something.;(in conventional harmony) lead up to (a discord) by means of preparation.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: find or locate exactly;a tiny dot or point;absolutely precise; to the finest degree

origins: late 17th century (as a verb): from French, literally ‘small park (i.e. delineated area)’. The noun dates from the early 19th century.
meaning: flooring composed of wooden blocks arranged in a geometric pattern.;the ground floor of a theatre or auditorium, especially the orchestra pit.;(in France and French-speaking countries) the branch of the administration of the law that deals with the prosecution of crime.

origins: early 17th century: from French hypnotique, via late Latin from Greek hupnōtikos ‘causing sleep’, from hupnoun ‘put to sleep’, from hupnos ‘sleep’.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: 1930s; earliest use found in QST. From wobb- + -ulator

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the accumulation or increase of something over time, especially payments or benefits

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘causing sleepiness’): from Old French sompnolent or Latin somnolentus, from somnus ‘sleep’.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: money paid for work or a service

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin exasperat- ‘irritated to anger’, from the verb exasperare (based on asper ‘rough’).

origins: late 15th century (in the sense ‘morally weak’): from Latin fragilis, from frangere ‘to break’. The sense ‘liable to break’ dates from the mid 16th century.
meaning: (of an object) easily broken or damaged.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: having the effect of retarding or inhibiting the coagulation of the blood.;an anticoagulant substance.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: French.
meaning: a whipped filling of chocolate and cream, used in confectioneries such as cakes and truffles.

origins: Unknown
meaning: the outer colored layer of the mesocarp of a citrus fruit

origins: Middle English (as a verb, also in the sense ‘dance with contortions’): from Middle Low German tummelen ; compare with Old English tumbian ‘to dance’. The sense was probably influenced by Old French tomber ‘to fall’. The noun, first in the sense ‘tangled mass’, dates from the mid 17th century.
meaning: fall suddenly, clumsily, or headlong.;perform acrobatic feats, typically handsprings and somersaults in the air.;dry (washing) in a tumble dryer.;understand the meaning or hidden implication of (a situation).;have sex with.;clean (castings, gemstones, etc.) in a tumbling barrel.

origins: mid 19th century: modern Latin, from Greek hurax ‘shrew-mouse’.
meaning: a small herbivorous mammal with a compact body and a very short tail, found in arid country in Africa and Arabia. The nearest relatives to hyraxes are the elephants and other subungulates.

origins: late 19th century: American coinage of unknown origin.

origins: mid 17th century: from modern Latin phraseologia, from Greek phraseōn, genitive plural of phrasis ‘a phrase’ + -logia (see -logy).

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘domestic’): from Old French, from mesnee ‘household’.
meaning: (of work) not requiring much skill and lacking prestige.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin appellatio(n- ), from the verb appellare (see appeal).

origins: 1940s: from vegan + -ism.

origins: mid 18th century: perhaps from French chaudière ‘stew pot’, related to Old Northern French caudron (see cauldron).

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action or process of carrying out or accomplishing an action, task, or function;an act of staging or presenting a play, concert, or other form of entertainment

origins: early 17th century (denoting a decision or choice made after deliberation): from French, or from medieval Latin volitio(n- ), from volo ‘I wish’.

origins: early 20th century: from Franco- ‘French’ + Greek phōnē ‘voice’.

origins: Old English, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch vilt, also to filter.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin combinatio(n- ), from the verb combinare ‘join two by two’ (see combine1).

origins: early 17th century (denoting nodding of the head): from Latin nutatio(n- ), from nutare ‘to nod’.

origins: late 19th century (as a general term meaning ‘light, brightness’): from Latin luminant- ‘illuminating’ (from the verb luminare ) + -ance.

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: Middle English: from Old French torche, from Latin torqua, variant of torques ‘necklace, wreath’, from torquere ‘to twist’. The current verb sense was originally US slang and dates from the 1930s.

origins: Middle English (denoting a female ruler): via Old French from Latin domina ‘mistress’.

origins: late 18th century; earliest use found in Richard Chandler (d. 1810), classical scholar and traveller. From Hellenistic Greek παναγία (used from Origen onwards of the Virgin Mary), feminine of πανάγιος all-holy from ancient Greek παν- + ἅγιος holy
meaning: The All-holy (as a title of the Virgin Mary).

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late 16th century: from French intercéder or Latin intercedere ‘intervene’, from inter- ‘between’ + cedere ‘go’.

origins: early 18th century: from Italian, feminine past participle of toccare ‘to touch’.

origins: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘follower, obsequious underling’): from French satellite or Latin satelles, satellit- ‘attendant’.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin, ‘skin’.

origins: mid 17th century (as a noun): from German Patrolle, from French patrouille, from patrouiller ‘paddle in mud’, from patte ‘paw’ + dialect ( gad)rouille ‘dirty water’.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin fissio(n- ), from findere ‘to split’.

meaning: (in feudal Japan) a wandering samurai who had no lord or master.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: an area that is suitable for a ship to anchor in.;an anchorite's dwelling place.;a seaport in southern Alaska, on an inlet of the Pacific Ocean, the state's largest city; population 279,243 (est. 2008).

origins: late Middle English: from French sacristie, from medieval Latin sacristia, based on Latin sacer, sacr- ‘sacred’.

origins: late Middle English (as a verb in the general sense ‘tremble’): from dialect quave ‘quake, tremble’, probably from an Old English word related to quake. The noun is first recorded (mid 16th century) as a musical term.

origins: mid 18th century (denoting a person who undertakes a project): from French, from entreprendre ‘undertake’ (see enterprise).

origins: Old English gealla (denoting bile), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch gal, German Galle ‘gall’, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek kholē and Latin fel ‘bile’.

origins: late 18th century: modern Latin, from Uranus: compare with tellurium.

origins: Old English clēofan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch klieven and German klieben .

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: early 19th century: modern Latin, from Greek mastos ‘breast’ + odous, odont- ‘tooth’ (with reference to nipple-shaped tubercles on the crowns of its molar teeth).

origins: French, from obsolete char (earlier form of chair ) ‘flesh’ + cuite ‘cooked’.

origins: early 18th century: of unknown origin; compare with Dutch lapskous, Danish and Norwegian lapskaus, and German Lapskaus .

origins: mid 18th century: from modern Latin ammonites, from medieval Latin cornu Ammonis ‘horn of Ammon’, from the fossil's resemblance to the ram's horn associated with Jupiter Ammon (see ammoniacal).

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: mid 16th century (denoting an informer): from French sycophante, or via Latin from Greek sukophantēs ‘informer’, from sukon ‘fig’ + phainein ‘to show’, perhaps with reference to making the insulting gesture of the ‘fig’ (sticking the thumb between two fingers) to informers.

origins: Middle English: shortening of Old French ahuge, of unknown origin.

origins: Middle English: from Old French fornais(e ), from Latin fornax, fornac-, from fornus ‘oven’.

origins: Unknown

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: mid 18th century: from French, earlier vau de ville (or vire ), said to be a name given originally to songs composed by Olivier Basselin, a 15th-century fuller born in Vau de Vire in Normandy.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French exemplaire, from late Latin exemplarium, from Latin exemplum ‘sample, imitation’ (see example).

origins: late Middle English: via French from late Latin fortificatio(n- ), from fortificare (see fortify).

origins: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Thomas Keightley (1789–1872), historian and author. Partly from Danish nisse

origins: modern Latin, apparently an alteration of Swedish trilling ‘triplet’.

origins: late Middle English: from French, from Latin lassitudo, from lassus ‘tired’.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a grill opening (as a hatch or wicket)ááespeciallyá:áa ticket window

origins: from the Munchkins, depicted as a race of small childlike creatures, in L. Frank Baum's book The Wonderful Wizard of Oz (1900).

origins: late 18th century: from French, alteration of the Alpine dialect word lavanche (of unknown origin), influenced by avaler ‘descend’; compare with Italian valanga .
meaning: a mass of snow, ice, and rocks falling rapidly down a mountainside.;a sudden arrival or occurrence of something in overwhelming quantities.;a cumulative process in which a fast-moving ion or electron generates further ions and electrons by collision.

origins: Middle English: shortening of Old French estreit ‘tight, narrow’, from Latin strictus ‘drawn tight’ (see strict).
meaning: a narrow passage of water connecting two seas or two other large areas of water.;used in reference to a situation characterized by a specified degree of trouble or difficulty.

origins: mid 17th century: from French, ‘lively, fierce’, from Italian brusco ‘sour’.

origins: late 16th century: (earlier (late Middle English) as inundation ) from Latin inundat- ‘flooded’, from the verb inundare, from in- ‘into, upon’ + undare ‘to flow’ (from unda ‘a wave’).

origins: mid 19th century: modern Latin, from Greek kuanōsis ‘blueness’, from kuaneos ‘dark blue’.

origins: early 17th century: from medieval Latin divestit- ‘divested’ (from the verb divestire ) + -ure.

origins: from modern Greek, literally ‘hodgepodge’

origins: Etymology Unknown

origins: late 16th century: from French, from Italian mostaccio, from Greek mustax, mustak- .
