origins: late 16th century (as an adjective): via Latin from Greek epikos, from epos ‘word, song’, related to eipein ‘say’.
meaning: a long poem, typically one derived from ancient oral tradition, narrating the deeds and adventures of heroic or legendary figures or the past history of a nation.;an exceptionally long and arduous task or activity.

origins: mid 19th century: from pre- + nuptial
meaning: existing or occurring before marriage

origins: mid 16th century (in an earlier sense). Either from classical Latin nūbilōsus cloudy (2nd century a.d.; from nūbilus + -ōsus), or from classical Latin nūbilus cloudy, dim, confused (from nūbēs cloud (perhaps cognate with Baluchi nōd) + -ilus, suffix forming adjectives) + -ous
meaning: Clouded in appearance; foggy, misty.

origins: Unknown
meaning: an evening party or reception

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin, past participle of emereri ‘earn one's discharge by service’, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out of, from’ + mereri ‘earn’.
meaning: (of the former holder of an office, especially a university professor) having retired but allowed to retain their title as an honour.

origins: mid 16th century: weakened form of master1 in unstressed use before a name.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin praeeminent- ‘towering above, excelling’, from the verb praeeminere, from prae ‘before’ + eminere ‘stand out’.
meaning: surpassing all others; very distinguished in some way.

origins: Middle English: from Old French goles (plural of gole ‘throat’, from Latin gula ), used to denote pieces of red-dyed fur used as a neck ornament.
meaning: red, as a heraldic tincture.

origins: early 17th century; earliest use found in Anthony Copley (b. 1567), writer and conspirator. From classical Latin gentīlītius + -al
meaning: Of gentle birth; belonging to or characteristic of the gentry.;Of a noun, adjective, etc.: indicating the place, nation, tribe, etc., with which a person or thing is affiliated. Also of a suffix, etc.: forming words which indicate this. Compare "gentile".;Of or relating to a particular lineage or gens; familial.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: any adult present in order to maintain order or propriety at an activity of young people, as at a school dance;a round headdress of stuffed cloth with wide cloth streamers that fall from the crown or are draped around it, worn in the 15th century

origins: Unknown
meaning: a deer (Cervus cashmiriensis) of Kashmir closely related to the red deer of Europe

origins: early 17th century: from Greek kritērion ‘means of judging’, from kritēs (see critic).
meaning: a principle or standard by which something may be judged or decided.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin duplus (see duple). The verb is from Old French dobler, from late Latin duplare, from duplus .
meaning: consisting of two equal, identical, or similar parts or things.;lower in pitch by an octave.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action or fact of occupying a place

origins: Unknown
meaning: growing in gravelly soil

origins: mid 19th century (originally in knickerbocker (sense 2)): named after Diedrich Knickerbocker, pretended author of W. Irving's History of New York (1809). knickerbocker (sense 1) is said to have arisen from the resemblance of knickerbockers to the knee breeches worn by Dutch men in George Cruikshank's illustrations in Irving's book.
meaning: loose-fitting breeches gathered at the knee or calf.;a New Yorker.

origins: Unknown
meaning: region of Australia extending along the coast in eastern Victoria from near Melbourne to the border with New South Wales

origins: late 19th century: abbreviation of gelatin. See also jell.
meaning: a a thick, clear, slightly sticky substance, especially one used in cosmetic or medicinal products.;a semi-rigid slab or cylinder of an organic polymer used as a medium for the separation of macromolecules.

origins: mid 19th century: diminutive of the noun scrap1.
meaning: scraps of pork or other meat stewed with maize meal and shaped into large cakes.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the action of transferring something or the process of being transferred

origins: Middle English: from Old French joel, from jeu ‘game, play’, from Latin jocus ‘jest’.
meaning: a precious stone, typically a single crystal or piece of a hard lustrous or translucent mineral cut into shape with flat facets or smoothed and polished for use as an ornament.

origins: Old English hræfn, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch raaf and German Rabe .
meaning: a large heavily built crow with mainly black plumage, feeding chiefly on carrion.

origins: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, from the synonymous word su, from Latin sebum ‘tallow’.
meaning: the hard white fat on the kidneys and loins of cattle, sheep, and other animals, used to make foods such as puddings, pastry, and mincemeat.

origins: Italian, diminutive of pancio ‘belly’.
meaning: Italian cured belly of pork.

origins: early 19th century: from French oölithe, modern Latin oolites (see oo-, -lite).

origins: Old English wolde, past of wyllan (see will1).
meaning: past of will1, in various senses.;(expressing the conditional mood) indicating the consequence of an imagined event or situation.;expressing a desire or inclination.;expressing a polite request.;expressing a conjecture, opinion, or hope.;used to make a comment about behaviour that is typical.;expressing a wish or regret.

origins: late Middle English: probably from Old English getæl  ‘swift, prompt’. Early senses also included ‘fine, handsome’ and ‘bold, strong, good at fighting’.
meaning: of great or more than average height, especially (with reference to an object) relative to width.

origins: Middle English: from Old French chapitre, from Latin capitulum, diminutive of caput ‘head’.
meaning: a main division of a book, typically with a number or title.;a distinctive period in history or in a person's life.;the governing body of a religious community or knightly order.;a local branch of a society.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin mortalis, from mors, mort- ‘death’.
meaning: (of a living human being, often in contrast to a divine being) subject to death.;causing or liable to cause death; fatal.;denoting a grave sin that is regarded as depriving the soul of divine grace.;conceivable or imaginable.

origins: late Middle English: Latin plaga ‘stroke, wound’, probably from Greek (Doric dialect) plaga, from a base meaning ‘strike’.
meaning: a contagious bacterial disease characterized by fever and delirium, typically with the formation of buboes ( bubonic plague ) and sometimes infection of the lungs ( pneumonic plague ).;an unusually large number of insects or animals infesting a place and causing damage.;a thing causing trouble or irritation.

origins: Unknown
meaning: culture period; a river

origins: late 15th century (as a noun): via Latin from Greek iōta, the smallest letter of the Greek alphabet: see iota.
meaning: write (something) quickly.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a machine used for cutting grass

origins: late 16th century: from Latin, from Greek emporion, from emporos ‘merchant’, based on a stem meaning ‘to journey’.
meaning: a large retail store selling a wide variety of goods.

origins: early 17th century: from Latin subterraneus (from sub- ‘below’ + terra ‘earth’) + -an.
meaning: existing, occurring, or done under the earth's surface.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, from plume ‘feather’.
meaning: a bird's feathers collectively.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a loud reverberation

origins: Unknown
meaning: a difference in coloration in two anatomical structures or two parts of the same structure which are normally alike in color

origins: named after Wensleydale in Yorkshire.
meaning: a type of white cheese with a crumbly texture.;a sheep of a breed with long wool.

origins: 1960s: contraction of quasi-stellar .
meaning: a massive and extremely remote celestial object, emitting exceptionally large amounts of energy, and typically having a starlike image in a telescope. It has been suggested that quasars contain massive black holes and may represent a stage in the evolution of some galaxies.

origins: Middle English: from Old French record ‘remembrance’, from recorder ‘bring to remembrance’, from Latin recordari ‘remember’, based on cor, cord- ‘heart’. The noun was earliest used in law to denote the fact of being written down as evidence. The verb originally meant ‘narrate orally or in writing’, also ‘repeat so as to commit to memory’;Etymology Unknown
meaning: the sum of the past achievements or actions of a person or organization; a person or thing's previous conduct or performance;(especially in sports) the best performance or most remarkable event of its kind that has been officially measured and noted;set down in writing or some other permanent form for later reference, especially officially;convert (sound or a performance) into permanent form for later reproduction;a thin plastic disk carrying recorded sound, especially music, in grooves on each surface, for reproduction by a record player;a thing constituting a piece of evidence about the past, especially an account kept in writing or some other permanent form

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘sway unsteadily’): from Latin vacillat- ‘swayed’, from the verb vacillare .
meaning: waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin calix, calic- ‘cup’.
meaning: a large cup or goblet.

origins: late 19th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: a slender North American pikeperch with silver eyes, which is active at twilight and at night.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: hard dry bread or biscuit, especially as rations for sailors.

origins: mid 17th century (as an adjective): from Latin equester ‘belonging to a horseman’ (from eques ‘horseman, knight’, from equus ‘horse’) + -ian.
meaning: relating to horse riding.

origins: early 17th century: from Anglo-Norman French floteson, from floter ‘to float’.
meaning: the wreckage of a ship or its cargo found floating on or washed up by the sea.

origins: Japanese.
meaning: a round, yellowish citrus fruit with fragrant, acidic juice, used chiefly as a flavouring.;the citrus tree that bears the yuzu, originating in China and widely cultivated in Japan and Korea.

origins: Old English cycgel, of unknown origin.
meaning: a short, thick stick used as a weapon.

origins: late Middle English (in vermeil (sense 2)): from Old French (see vermilion).
meaning: gilded silver or bronze.;vermilion.

origins: late 18th century: from Spanish, from Aymara allpaca .
meaning: a long-haired domesticated South American mammal related to the llama, valued for its wool.

origins: early 17th century: from French, based on Arabic ṣuffa .
meaning: a long upholstered seat with a back and arms, for two or more people.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to illness caused by medical examination or treatment

origins: early 18th century (as thaumaturg ): via medieval Latin from Greek thaumatourgos, from thauma ‘marvel’ + -ergos ‘-working’.
meaning: a worker of wonders and performer of miracles; a magician.

origins: mid 17th century: from French mêlée, from an Old French variant of meslee (see medley).
meaning: a confused fight or scuffle.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French furieus, from Latin furiosus, from furia ‘fury’.
meaning: extremely angry.;full of anger or energy; violent or intense.

origins: late Middle English (in apprehensive (sense 2)): from French appréhensif or medieval Latin apprehensivus, from Latin apprehendere ‘seize, grasp’ (see apprehend).
meaning: anxious or fearful that something bad or unpleasant will happen.;relating to perception or understanding.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: of or relating to that part of geological time represented by rocks in which the evidence of life is slight and the life forms are primitive; pre-Phanerozoic

origins: mid 19th century: from French (earlier in the sense ‘one-eyed’), from late Latin monoculus ‘one-eyed’.
meaning: a single eyeglass, kept in position by the muscles around the eye.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: (especially of a person) looking attractive in photographs or on film;(of an organism or tissue) producing or emitting light.

origins: late 16th century (in Dalmatian (sense 2 of the noun)): the dog is believed to have originated in Dalmatia in the 18th century.
meaning: a dog of a large, white short-haired breed with dark spots.;a native or inhabitant of Dalmatia.

origins: Sanskrit.
meaning: breath, considered as a life-giving force.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a tassel on a Scotch bonnet

origins: late 19th century: from French, from Provençal espardi(l)hos, from espart ‘esparto’, from Latin spartum (see esparto).
meaning: a light canvas shoe with a plaited fibre sole.

origins: Old English hāligdæg  ‘holy day’.
meaning: an extended period of leisure and recreation, especially one spent away from home or in travelling.;a short period during which the payment of instalments, tax, etc. may be suspended.

origins: late Middle English: perhaps related to Old Norse gnastan ‘a gnashing’.
meaning: grind (one's teeth) together as a sign of anger (often used hyperbolically).

origins: mid 19th century: from modern Latin saccharum ‘sugar’ + -ide.
meaning: another term for sugar (sense 2 of the noun).

origins: late 16th century: from French, from medieval Latin scriptorium ‘writing room’ (see scriptorium).
meaning: a small writing desk with drawers and compartments.

origins: early 17th century: from medieval Latin omniscient- ‘all-knowing’, based on scire ‘to know’.
meaning: knowing everything.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the fact or condition of being bereaved

origins: late 17th century (in the sense ‘force equipped for war’): from Latin armamentum, from armare ‘to arm’ (see arm2).
meaning: military weapons and equipment.

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin putrescent- ‘beginning to go rotten’, inceptive of putrere ‘to rot’ (see putrid).
meaning: undergoing the process of decay; rotting.

origins: late 16th century (as a verb): of unknown origin.
meaning: cause (someone) to feel confused because they cannot understand something.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: concerned with tasting or the sense of taste

origins: Italian.
meaning: small rectangular biscuits containing nuts, made originally in Italy.

origins: mid 16th century (denoting soup thickened with barley): alteration of pottage. Sense 2 dates from the 1950s.
meaning: a dish consisting of oatmeal or another meal or cereal boiled in water or milk.;time spent in prison.

origins: 1920s: from Welsh, from cor ‘dwarf’ + ci ‘dog’.
meaning: a dog of a short-legged breed with a foxlike head.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin pronus ‘leaning forward’, from pro ‘forwards’.
meaning: likely or liable to suffer from, do, or experience something unpleasant or regrettable.;lying flat, especially face downwards.

origins: late 16th century (as an adjective): from late Latin subalternus, from Latin sub- ‘next below’ + alternus ‘every other’.
meaning: an officer in the British army below the rank of captain, especially a second lieutenant.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin nutrient- ‘nourishing’, from the verb nutrire .
meaning: a substance that provides nourishment essential for the maintenance of life and for growth.

origins: late 15th century (in the sense ‘pardon or be absolved from (an offence)’): from French effacer, from e- (from Latin ex- ‘away from’) + face ‘face’.
meaning: erase (a mark) from a surface.;make oneself appear insignificant or inconspicuous.

origins: Old English boren, past participle of beran  ‘to bear’ (see bear1).
meaning: existing as a result of birth.

origins: late Middle English: from late Latin auricularis, from auricula, diminutive of auris ‘ear’.
meaning: relating to the ear or hearing.;relating to or shaped like an auricle.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin emolumentum, originally probably ‘payment to a miller for grinding corn’, from emolere ‘grind up’, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out, thoroughly’ + molere ‘grind’.
meaning: a salary, fee, or profit from employment or office.

origins: early 19th century (denoting a whip or scourge): from Latin, diminutive of flagrum ‘scourge’.
meaning: a slender threadlike structure, especially a microscopic appendage that enables many protozoa, bacteria, spermatozoa, etc. to swim.

origins: 1950s: a local word.
meaning: a chimpanzee with a black face and black hair, found in the rainforests of the Democratic Republic of Congo (Zaire). It is believed to be the closest living relative of humans.

origins: Middle English: from Old French diademe, via Latin from Greek diadēma ‘the regal headband of the Persian kings’, from diadein ‘bind round’.
meaning: a jewelled crown or headband worn as a symbol of sovereignty.

origins: late Middle English (originally as an adjective meaning ‘destroyed, annulled’): from late Latin annihilatus ‘reduced to nothing’, from the verb annihilare, from ad- ‘to’ + nihil ‘nothing’. The sense ‘destroy utterly’ dates from the mid 16th century.
meaning: destroy utterly; obliterate.;convert (a subatomic particle) into radiant energy.

origins: late 19th century: modern Latin from Greek, phulon ‘race’.
meaning: a principal taxonomic category that ranks above class and below kingdom, equivalent to the division in botany.;a group of languages related to each other less closely than those forming a family, especially one in which the relationships are unclear.

origins: mid 19th century: from French vétiver, from Tamil veṭṭivēr, from vēr ‘root’.
meaning: a fragrant extract or essential oil obtained from the root of an Indian grass, used in perfumery and aromatherapy.

origins: early 19th century: of unknown origin.
meaning: an Asian wild dog with a sandy coat and a black bushy tail, living in packs.

origins: German, from Kaffee ‘coffee’ + Klatsch ‘gossip’.
meaning: another term for klatch.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a pressed whole-milk cheese of a pale yellow color and nutty flavor and usually with small holes

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a soft white cheese with a characteristic strong smell, originally made in Limburg, a former duchy of Lorraine.

origins: late Middle English (in the sense ‘pull up by the roots’): from Latin eradicat- ‘torn up by the roots’, from the verb eradicare, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out’ + radix, radic- ‘root’.
meaning: destroy completely; put an end to.

origins: Japanese, literally ‘beans on a branch’.
meaning: a Japanese dish of salted green soybeans boiled in their pods, typically served as a snack or appetizer.

origins: early 20th century; earliest use found in Waterloo (Iowa) Times-Tribune. From German Lachsschinken from Lachs salmon + Schinken ham, with reference to the bright pink colour of the ham, which resembles that of smoked salmon
meaning: A lean, mild-tasting ham originating in Bavaria, made from pork loin which has been salted, dry-cured, cold-smoked, and pressed into a casing.

origins: German, from Gesell(e ) ‘companion’ + -schaft (see -ship).
meaning: social relations based on impersonal ties, such as duty to a society or organization.

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin summa ‘main part, sum total’, feminine of summus ‘highest’.
meaning: a particular amount of money.;the total amount resulting from the addition of two or more numbers, amounts, or items.;an arithmetical problem, especially at an elementary level.

origins: 1930s: apparently from a term in Sherpa (a local language) that is related to Tibetan gya ‘rocky place’ + dred ‘yellow bear, hyena’.
meaning: a large hairy creature resembling a human or bear, said to live in the highest part of the Himalayas.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a 19th-century man's boot reaching above the knee in front and with a piece cut out behind, originally worn by cavalrymen.;a flaky rectangular pastry with a sweet filling.;the name of three rulers of France.;a gold twenty-franc French coin minted during the reign of Napoleon I.

origins: late18th century: alteration of the obsolete word cullability (in the same meaning), after gull2.
meaning: a tendency to be easily persuaded that something is real or true; credulity.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: characterized by or causing cohesion

origins: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Richard Saunders. From post-classical Latin peiorat-, past participial stem of peiorare to make worse (late 2nd or early 3rd century a.d.) from classical Latin pēior worse (functioning as the comparative of malus bad: see mal-) from the same Indo-European base as foot [interjection]; compare -ior
meaning: To make worse; to cause to deteriorate. In later use also: to endow (a word) with a less favourable meaning.

origins: Unknown
meaning: finished with a high luster; woven with a fancy warp rib

origins: 1940s: coined by W. H. Sheldon in Varieties of Human Physique .
meaning: a category to which people are assigned according to the extent to which their bodily physique conforms to a basic type (usually endomorphic, mesomorphic, or ectomorphic).

origins: late 16th century: from Tamil kaṟi .
meaning: a dish of meat, vegetables, etc., cooked in an Indian-style sauce of hot-tasting spices and typically served with rice.

origins: Old English scild (noun), scildan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schild and German Schild, from a base meaning ‘divide, separate’.
meaning: a broad piece of metal or another suitable material, held by straps or a handle attached on one side, used as a protection against blows or missiles.;a person or thing providing protection.;a large rigid area of the earth's crust, typically of Precambrian rock, which has been unaffected by later orogenic episodes, e.g. the Canadian Shield.

origins: Japanese.
meaning: (especially in Japan) a flowering cherry tree.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘born out of wedlock’): from Latin spurius ‘false’ + -ous.
meaning: not being what it purports to be; false or fake.

origins: late 15th century: from Old French, from medieval Latin comestibilis, from Latin comest- ‘eaten up’, from the verb comedere, from com- ‘altogether’ + edere ‘eat’.
meaning: an item of food.

origins: late 19th century: probably an invented word.
meaning: cheap or insubstantial stew.

origins: mid 19th century: from Greek, from aphatos ‘speechless’, from a- ‘not’ + phanai ‘speak’.
meaning: inability (or impaired ability) to understand or produce speech, as a result of brain damage.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin irreverent- ‘not revering’, from in- ‘not’ + reverent- ‘revering’ (see reverent).
meaning: showing a lack of respect for people or things that are generally taken seriously.

origins: Unknown
meaning: of, relating to, or being a method for determining the amount of nitrogen (as in an organic substance) by digesting a sample with boiling concentrated sulfuric acid and other reagents, adding an excess of alkali, distilling, collecting the ammonia expelled, and determining the ammonia by titration

origins: late Middle English: via Latin from Greek historikos (see historic).
meaning: of or concerning history or past events.

origins: late Middle English (denoting a private room): via French from Latin conclave ‘lockable room’, from con- ‘with’ + clavis ‘key’.
meaning: a private meeting.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the practice of opinionating on subjects of which one has only superficial knowledge

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin consequent- ‘overtaking, following closely’, from the verb consequi .
meaning: following as a result or effect.;(of a stream or valley) having a direction or character determined by the original slope of the land before erosion.

origins: late Middle English (originally as ensurance in the sense ‘ensuring, assurance, a guarantee’): from Old French enseurance, from enseurer (see ensure). insurance (sense 1) dates from the mid 17th century.
meaning: an arrangement by which a company or the state undertakes to provide a guarantee of compensation for specified loss, damage, illness, or death in return for payment of a specified premium.;a thing providing protection against a possible eventuality.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a croaking especially of frogs

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a large German dirigible airship of the early 20th century, long and cylindrical in shape and with a rigid framework. Zeppelins were used during World War I for reconnaissance and bombing, and after the war as passenger transports until the 1930s.

origins: late 18th century: from Italian, from Latin glaber, glabr- ‘smooth’.
meaning: a dark, coarse-grained plutonic rock of crystalline texture, consisting mainly of pyroxene, plagioclase feldspar, and often olivine.

origins: early 19th century: from Latin pomum ‘fruit’ + -logy.
meaning: the science of fruit-growing.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the money or other means needed for a particular purpose

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a deep cut or tear in skin or flesh

origins: mid 19th century: from modern Latin campanologia, from late Latin campana ‘bell’.
meaning: the art or practice of bell-ringing.

origins: Italian.
meaning: chicory of a variety which has dark red leaves.

origins: early 17th century (as basse relieve ): from Italian basso-rilievo ‘low relief’, later altered to the French form.
meaning: another term for low relief (see relief (sense 4)).

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the chemical element vanadium.;(in mathematical formulae) volume;the twenty-second letter of the alphabet.;volt(s).;voltage or potential difference;the Roman numeral for five.;a shape like that of a letter V

origins: Middle English: from Old French coriandre, from Latin coriandrum, from Greek koriannon .
meaning: an aromatic Mediterranean plant of the parsley family, the leaves and seeds of which are used as culinary herbs.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: unskillful; inept

origins: late Middle English: alteration (suggested by semblance) of obsolete dissimule, via Old French from Latin dissimulare ‘disguise, conceal’.
meaning: conceal or disguise one's true feelings or beliefs.

origins: Middle English: from Old French contenance ‘bearing, behaviour’, from contenir (see contain). The early sense was ‘bearing, demeanour’, also ‘facial expression’, hence ‘the face’.
meaning: a person's face or facial expression.;support or approval.

origins: Unknown
meaning: an area of older land ranging in size from a few square feet to several square miles surrounded by later lava flows

origins: French.
meaning: a French type of black pudding.;a series of elongated parallel sections formed by the fracturing of a sedimentary rock stratum during folding.

origins: Middle English (originally axle-tree ): from Old Norse ǫxultré .
meaning: a rod or spindle (either fixed or rotating) passing through the centre of a wheel or group of wheels.

origins: early 20th century: from Nauga(tuck), the name of a town in Connecticut, US, where rubber is manufactured, + -hyde (alteration of hide2).
meaning: an artificial material designed to resemble leather, made from fabric coated with rubber or vinyl resin.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘something inspiring trust; credentials’): from Latin fiduciarius, from fiducia ‘trust’, from fidere ‘to trust’.
meaning: involving trust, especially with regard to the relationship between a trustee and a beneficiary.;(of a paper currency) depending for its value on securities (as opposed to gold) or the reputation of the issuer.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin, ‘itching’ (see prurigo).
meaning: severe itching of the skin, as a symptom of various ailments.

origins: late 17th century: from French ménagerie, from ménage (see ménage).
meaning: a collection of wild animals kept in captivity for exhibition.

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin dissonantia, from Latin dissonant- ‘disagreeing in sound’, from the verb dissonare .
meaning: lack of harmony among musical notes.

origins: early 17th century. From French pendeloque religious medallion, probably in the form of a pendant, something which hangs from an object, little piece of crystal, piece of crystal suspended from a chandelier from pendeler to dangle + -oche, suffix forming nouns, of uncertain origin, with ending subsequently altered to -oque, perhaps after breloque
meaning: A gem, especially a diamond, cut in the shape of a drop and used as a pendant; a piece of jewellery of similar design. Also as adjective: designating such a gem.

origins: mid 19th century: from Greek toreutikos, from toreuein ‘to work in relief’.
meaning: the art of making designs in relief or intaglio, especially by chasing, carving, and embossing in metal.

origins: late 18th century (in an earlier sense). In some forms from Spanish puchero from classical Latin pultārius kind of cooking pot (from pult-, puls + -ārius; compare Spanish (plural) puches)
meaning: A Latin American or Spanish stew or thick soup typically made with meat and vegetables or pulses.

origins: mid 19th century: from French, perhaps via Breton from Cornish tolmen ‘hole of a stone’.
meaning: a megalithic tomb with a large flat stone laid on upright ones, found chiefly in Britain and France.

origins: late 16th century: via Portuguese or Spanish from Mande.
meaning: a long curved fruit which grows in clusters and has soft pulpy flesh and yellow skin when ripe.;the tropical and subtropical palmlike plant that bears bananas, having very large leaves but lacking a woody trunk.

origins: Middle English: from Old French deposer, from Latin deponere (see deponent), but influenced by Latin depositus and Old French poser ‘to place’.
meaning: remove from office suddenly and forcefully.;testify to or give (evidence) under oath, typically in a written statement.

origins: late Middle English (also denoting length and tallness): from Latin longitudo, from longus ‘long’.
meaning: the angular distance of a place east or west of the Greenwich meridian, or west of the standard meridian of a celestial object, usually expressed in degrees and minutes.

origins: late 18th century: from French épaulette, diminutive of épaule ‘shoulder’, from Latin spatula in the late Latin sense ‘shoulder blade’.
meaning: an ornamental shoulder piece on an item of clothing, especially on the coat or jacket of a military uniform.

origins: 1960s: from French, literally ‘author’.
meaning: a film director who influences their films so much that they rank as their author.

origins: 1940s: from fibro- + myalgia
meaning: a chronic disorder characterized by widespread pain and other symptoms such as fatigue, muscle stiffness, and insomnia.

origins: mid 16th century: from Latin, ‘birth, race, stock’.
meaning: a principal taxonomic category that ranks above species and below family, and is denoted by a capitalized Latin name, e.g. Leo.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the condition of being spontaneous; spontaneous behavior or action

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the dominant social system in medieval Europe, in which the nobility held lands from the Crown in exchange for military service, and vassals were in turn tenants of the nobles, while the peasants (villeins or serfs) were obliged to live on their lord's land and give him homage, labor, and a share of the produce, notionally in exchange for military protection.

origins: late 19th century: from Wemba-wemba (an Aboriginal language of SE Australia).
meaning: a small freshwater crayfish.

origins: mid 18th century: from Latin reminiscent- ‘remembering’, from the verb reminisci .
meaning: tending to remind one of something.;suggesting something by resemblance.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a monetary unit of Saudi Arabia equal to ╣/??? riyaláŚ seeáriyaláatáMoney Table; riyal

origins: late 16th century: from obsolete French pluche, contraction of peluche, from Old French peluchier ‘to pluck’, based on Latin pilus ‘hair’. The sense ‘luxurious’ dates from the 1920s.
meaning: a rich fabric of silk, cotton, wool, or a combination of these, with a long, soft nap.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin nivalis, from nix, niv- ‘snow’.
meaning: relating to or characteristic of a region of perpetual snow.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a Philippine jitney bus converted from a jeep

origins: early 20th century: blend of ethane and alcohol.
meaning: a colourless volatile flammable liquid which is produced by the natural fermentation of sugars; alcohol.

origins: mid 16th century: from Old French, from accepter (see accept).
meaning: the action of consenting to receive or undertake something offered.;the process or fact of being received as adequate, valid, or suitable.;agreement with or belief in an idea or explanation.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person whose job is to transcribe speech in shorthand

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: giving out light due to radioactivity

origins: from Sanskrit, literally ‘sitting near (i.e. at the feet of a master)’, from upa ‘near’ + ni-ṣad ‘sit down’.
meaning: each of a series of Hindu sacred treatises written in Sanskrit c. 800–200 BC, expounding the Vedas in predominantly mystical and monistic terms.

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin contractio(n- ), from contrahere ‘draw together’ (see contract).
meaning: the process of becoming smaller.

origins: late 18th century; earliest use found in Robert Adam (1728–1792), architect. From French rinceau from an unattested post-classical Latin form *ramuscellus small branch, alteration of post-classical Latin ramusculus small branch
meaning: An ornamental motif consisting of a band of scrolling or spiralling foliage (especially vine or acanthus leaves), frequently carved, moulded, or painted.

origins: from Greek Dios ‘of Zeus’ + anthos ‘a flower’.
meaning: a flowering plant of a genus that includes the pinks and carnations.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a medical practitioner specializing in the diagnosis and treatment of mental illness.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a first edition of a work;  also  a copy of this edition; the head of the state under the Roman Empire; any of various chief officials (as the headman of a tribe) among the ancient Teutons and Anglo-Saxons

origins: Old English hysope (reinforced in Middle English by Old French ysope ), via Latin from Greek hyssōpos, of Semitic origin.
meaning: a small bushy aromatic plant of the mint family, the bitter minty leaves of which are used in cooking and herbal medicine.;(in biblical use) a wild shrub of uncertain identity whose twigs were used for sprinkling in ancient Jewish rites of purification.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: mentionedd before

origins: early 19th century: from French légionnaire, from légion ‘legion’, from Latin legio (see legion).
meaning: a member of a legion, in particular an ancient Roman legion or the French Foreign Legion.

origins: Middle English: from Old French assouagier, asouagier, based on Latin ad- ‘to’ (expressing change) + suavis ‘sweet’.
meaning: make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense.

origins: late 19th century: from Greek haploos ‘single’ + -graphy.
meaning: the inadvertent omission of a repeated letter or letters in writing (e.g. writing philogy for philology ).

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘interrupt’): from Latin interpellat- ‘interrupted (by speech)’, from the verb interpellare, from inter- ‘between’ + pellere ‘to drive’. interpellate (sense 1) dates from the late 19th century; interpellate (sense 2) is from the works of Althusser.
meaning: (in a parliament) interrupt the order of the day by demanding an explanation from (the minister concerned).;(of an ideology or discourse) bring into being or give identity to (an individual or category).

origins: Old English glisnian, of Germanic origin; related to Middle Low German glisen . The noun dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: (of something wet or greasy) shine with a sparkling light.

origins: mid 19th century: abbreviation.
meaning: a professional, especially in sport.;a prostitute.

origins: late Middle English: from anger + -y1.
meaning: feeling or showing strong annoyance, displeasure, or hostility; full of anger.

origins: 1930s (in bazooka (sense 2); originally US): apparently from US slang bazoo in the original sense ‘kazoo’.
meaning: a short-range tubular rocket launcher used against tanks.;a kazoo shaped like a trumpet.

origins: late 17th century: from modern Latin vascularis, from Latin vasculum (see vasculum).
meaning: relating to, affecting, or consisting of a vessel or vessels, especially those which carry blood.

origins: mid 17th century: from French, from badiner ‘to joke’, from badin ‘fool’, based on Provençal badar ‘gape’.
meaning: humorous or witty conversation.

origins: early 18th century: from chaos, on the pattern of words such as hypnotic .
meaning: in a state of complete confusion and disorder.

origins: mid 18th century: from modern Latin adiposus, from adeps, adip- ‘fat’.
meaning: (especially of body tissue) used for the storage of fat.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: Something that is sinuous moves with smooth twists and turns.

origins: late Middle English (as a medical term denoting colic or in the sense ‘twisting’ (especially of a loop of the intestine)): via Old French from late Latin torsio(n- ), variant of tortio(n- ) ‘twisting, torture’, from Latin torquere ‘to twist’.
meaning: the action of twisting or the state of being twisted, especially of one end of an object relative to the other.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: lack of thoroughness, depth of character, or serious thought

origins: late Middle English: via Old French from medieval Latin caelestialis, from Latin caelestis, from caelum ‘heaven’.
meaning: positioned in or relating to the sky, or outer space as observed in astronomy.

origins: Unknown
meaning: áhaving the pinkish color of flesh

origins: late 15th century: from late Latin nocturnalis, from Latin nocturnus ‘of the night’, from nox, noct- ‘night’.
meaning: done, occurring, or active at night.

origins: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘beat, thrash’): from lam1 + baste3. The current sense dates from the late 19th century.
meaning: criticize (someone or something) harshly.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘in the highest degree’): from late Latin essentialis, from Latin essentia (see essence).
meaning: absolutely necessary; extremely important.;(of a disease) with no known external stimulus or cause; idiopathic.

origins: late 16th century: from Latin procrastinat- ‘deferred till the morning’, from the verb procrastinare, from pro- ‘forward’ + crastinus ‘belonging to tomorrow’ (from cras ‘tomorrow’).
meaning: delay or postpone action; put off doing something.

origins: 1960s: from elements of the chemical name.
meaning: a synthetic compound used widely as an analgesic and anti-inflammatory drug.

origins: late 16th century: via Latin from Greek amnēstia ‘forgetfulness’.
meaning: an official pardon for people who have been convicted of political offences.

origins: late 19th century: French, ‘buttonhole’, from bouton ‘button’.
meaning: a spray of flowers worn in a buttonhole.

origins: early 20th century: from endo- ‘within’ + Greek krinein ‘sift’.
meaning: relating to or denoting glands which secrete hormones or other products directly into the blood.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from medieval Latin seniscalus, from a Germanic compound of words meaning ‘old’ and ‘servant’.
meaning: the steward or major-domo of a medieval great house.;a governor or other administrative or judicial officer.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘hurl a missile, discharge with force’): from Anglo-Norman French launcher, variant of Old French lancier (see lance).
meaning: set (a boat) in motion by pushing it or allowing it to roll into the water.;start or set in motion (an activity or enterprise).

origins: 1950s: from Swedish, ‘legal representative’.
meaning: an official appointed to investigate individuals' complaints against a company or organization, especially a public authority.

origins: French, literally ‘rust’, with reference to the colour.
meaning: a Provençal sauce made from pounded red chilli peppers, garlic, breadcrumbs, and other ingredients blended with stock, typically added to bouillabaisse.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: clear space allowed for a thing to move past or under another;official authorization for something to proceed or take place;the action or process of removing or getting rid of something or of something's dispersing

origins: late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French purseute ‘following after’, from pursuer (see pursue). Early senses included ‘persecution, annoyance’ and in legal contexts ‘petition, prosecution’.
meaning: the action of pursuing someone or something.;an activity of a specified kind, especially a recreational or sporting one.

origins: early 20th century. From ancient Greek ἄκρος highest, topmost + -al, after Hellenistic Greek ἀκράλεα extremities of the body (rare: see note), use as noun of neuter plural of an otherwise unattested adjective ἀκράλεος from ancient Greek ἄκρος + -αλεος, suffix forming adjectives (common in medical vocabulary)
meaning: Designating the extremities or peripheral parts of the body, especially the hands and feet (or forefeet and hind feet), tip of the nose, and ears; of, relating to, or affecting these parts.

origins: Unknown
meaning: a turret or shelter for a sentry on an old fort

origins: late Middle English: from Old French araisnier, based on Latin ad- ‘to’ + ratio(n- ) ‘reason, account’.
meaning: call or bring (someone) before a court to answer a criminal charge.

origins: Old English ege  ‘terror, dread, awe’, replaced in Middle English by forms related to Old Norse agi .
meaning: a feeling of reverential respect mixed with fear or wonder.

origins: mid 17th century: from Latin ancillaris, from ancilla ‘maidservant’.
meaning: providing necessary support to the primary activities or operation of an organization, system, etc.

origins: late Middle English (in dimension (sense 1 of the noun)): via Old French from Latin dimensio(n- ), from dimetiri ‘measure out’. dimension (sense 2 of the noun) dates from the 1920s.
meaning: a measurable extent of a particular kind, such as length, breadth, depth, or height.;an aspect or feature of a situation.

origins: Old English elles, of Germanic origin; related to Middle Dutch els and Swedish eljest .
meaning: in addition; besides.;different; instead.;short for or else.

origins: late Middle English: imitative; compare with German dialect muttern .
meaning: say something in a low or barely audible voice, especially in dissatisfaction or irritation.

origins: early 17th century; earliest use found in Edward Topsell (d. 1625), Church of England clergyman and author. From (i) post-classical Latin agalma statue, image, specifically image or impression of a seal
meaning: An image, representation, or emblem; specifically the image on a seal.

origins: late 16th century: via medieval Latin from Greek, literally ‘doing’, from prattein ‘do’.
meaning: practice, as distinguished from theory.;accepted practice or custom.

origins: late 18th century: from Latin otiosus, from otium ‘leisure’.
meaning: serving no practical purpose or result.;indolent or idle.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin corpulentus, from corpus ‘body’.
meaning: (of a person) fat.

origins: Middle English: from Old French compaignon, literally ‘one who breaks bread with another’, based on Latin com- ‘together with’ + panis ‘bread’.
meaning: a person or animal with whom one spends a lot of time or with whom one travels.;each of a pair of things intended to complement or match each other.;a member of the lowest grade of certain orders of knighthood.

origins: late Middle English (denoting a person who imparts motion): from Latin, literally ‘mover’, based on movere ‘to move’. The current sense of the noun dates from the mid 19th century.
meaning: a machine, especially one powered by electricity or internal combustion, that supplies motive power for a vehicle or for another device with moving parts.;a car.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: relating to or characteristic of a traitor; treacherous

origins: early 19th century: from Latin competit- ‘striven for’, from the verb competere (see compete), + -ive.
meaning: relating to or characterized by competition.;as good as or better than others of a comparable nature.

origins: mid 19th century: modern Latin, from Greek muelos ‘marrow’ + -oma.
meaning: a malignant tumour of the bone marrow.

origins: late 15th century: from French, or from Latin turpitudo, from turpis ‘disgraceful, base’.
meaning: depraved or wicked behaviour or character.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: the process of turning from liquid into vapor

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin martialis, from Mars, Mart- (see Mars).
meaning: relating to fighting or war.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: one who studies time

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a flammable hydrocarbon gas of the alkene series, occurring in natural gas, coal gas, and crude oil and given off by ripening fruit. It is used in chemical synthesis, especially in the manufacture of polyethylene.

origins: late 19th century: from French intransigeant, from Spanish los intransigentes (a name adopted by the extreme republicans in the Cortes, 1873–4); based on Latin in- ‘not’ + transigere ‘come to an understanding’.
meaning: unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something.

origins: Yiddish.
meaning: (in Jewish cooking) a pancake, especially one made with grated potato.

origins: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin divergere, from Latin dis- ‘in two ways’ + vergere ‘to turn or incline’.
meaning: (of a road, route, or line) separate from another route and go in a different direction.;(of a series) increase indefinitely as more of its terms are added.

origins: Old English windwian, from wind (see wind1).
meaning: blow a current of air through (grain) in order to remove the chaff.;(of the wind) blow.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: a person who has to perform official functions or duties; an official.

origins: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin perseverantia, from perseverant- ‘abiding by strictly’, from the verb perseverare (see persevere).
meaning: persistence in doing something despite difficulty or delay in achieving success.

origins: Middle English (in the sense ‘become faint, feeble, or ill’): from Old French languiss-, lengthened stem of languir ‘languish’, from a variant of Latin languere, related to laxus ‘loose, lax’.
meaning: (of a person, animal, or plant) lose or lack vitality; grow weak.;be forced to remain in an unpleasant place or situation.

origins: mid 16th century: via French from Latin Vaticanus, the name of a hill in Rome
meaning: the palace and official residence of the Pope in Rome.

origins: late 18th century: from statue, on the pattern of picturesque .
meaning: (of a woman) attractively tall, graceful, and dignified.;reminiscent of a statue in size, posture, or stillness.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin, from Greek tetanos ‘muscular spasm’, from teinein ‘to stretch’.
meaning: a bacterial disease marked by rigidity and spasms of the voluntary muscles.;the prolonged contraction of a muscle caused by rapidly repeated stimuli.

origins: Etymology Unknown
meaning: showing great courage in the face of danger, especially in battle

origins: Unknown
meaning: áwelcomeáŚformerly common in English but now usually a conscious borrowing from the French; obsolete : an entry fee demanded from a new worker by fellow workers

origins: late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin patent- ‘lying open’, from the verb patere . The noun sense is from letters patent.
meaning: a government authority or licence conferring a right or title for a set period, especially the sole right to exclude others from making, using, or selling an invention.;patent leather.

origins: Old English ǣl, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch aal and German Aal .
meaning: a snake-like fish with a slender elongated body and poorly developed fins, proverbial for its slipperiness.

origins: late Middle English: from French, or from Latin sutura, from suere ‘sew’.
meaning: a stitch or row of stitches holding together the edges of a wound or surgical incision.;an immovable junction between two bones, such as those of the skull.

origins: late Middle English: from Latin desolatus ‘abandoned’, past participle of desolare, from de- ‘thoroughly’ + solus ‘alone’;Etymology Unknown
meaning: (of a place) deserted of people and in a state of bleak and dismal emptiness;make (a place) bleakly and depressingly empty or bare

origins: Old English cierlisc, ceorlisc  (see churl, -ish1).
meaning: rude in a mean-spirited and surly way.

origins: late 16th century (in the sense ‘evidence’): from Old French, or from medieval Latin remonstrantia, from remonstrare ‘demonstrate, show’ (see remonstrate).
meaning: a forcefully reproachful protest.

origins: Unknown
meaning: cooked in or served with browned butter

origins: Middle English: via Old French from Latin humor ‘moisture’, from humere (see humid). The original sense was ‘bodily fluid’ (surviving in aqueous humour and vitreous humour ); it was used specifically for any of the cardinal humours (humour (sense 3 of the noun)), whence ‘mental disposition’ (thought to be caused by the relative proportions of the humours). This led, in the 16th century, to the senses ‘mood’ (humour (sense 2 of the noun)) and ‘whim’, hence to humour someone ‘to indulge a person's whim’. humour (sense 1 of the noun) dates from the late 16th century.
meaning: the quality of being amusing or comic, especially as expressed in literature or speech.;a mood or state of mind.;each of the four chief fluids of the body (blood, phlegm, yellow bile (choler), and black bile (melancholy)) that were thought to determine a person's physical and mental qualities by the relative proportions in which they were present.

origins: mid 16th century: from the name of Niccolò Machiavelli (see Machiavelli, Niccolò.
meaning: cunning, scheming, and unscrupulous, especially in politics.

origins: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘inclined to sickness’): from obsolete mawk ‘maggot’, from Old Norse mathkr, of Germanic origin.
meaning: sentimental in an exaggerated or false way.

origins: Japanese.
meaning: a Japanese form of pinball.
